title: Two Arrested in Killings of Transgender Women in Puerto Rico
description: A week after the bodies of two transgender women were found in a badly burned car in Puerto Rico, the police said Thursday that they had arrested two men in connection with the killings and had turned them over to the F.B.I.

title: Fiona Ex Machina
description: Fetch the Bolt Cutters is Fiona Apples master class in channeling frustration and anger into what can only be called wisdom. Also, we hear from listeners all over the planet, sharing how they are taking care of the people in their lives.

title: No Graduation Ceremony? You Get Oprah!
description: They will not get to share in the memories synonymous with college graduation  the collective tossing of caps, the hugs from friends and the walk across the stage to get their diplomas.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: As Americans wrestle with how to emerge from weeks of social-distancing restrictions, tensions are building between those who remain desperate to suppress the coronavirus and those who are desperate to get out of the house. And the nations beaches have become a flash point.

title: Closing Number of a Musical
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  This puzzle by Trenton Charlson is another Friday dazzler worth showing up for. Not only does it have a generous sprinkling of high-score Scrabble letters (just take a gander at the four Zs in the northeast!), the entries are flashy and fun. The topics covered in the puzzle are plentiful, giving even a Friday-averse solver a chance at conquering it. And overall, the tone of the puzzle is cheery and optimistic, the perfect antidote to what we are all going through right now during the pandemic.

title: Labs Across U.S. Join Federal Initiative to Study Coronavirus Genome
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday announced a national initiative to speed research into how the coronavirus was spreading around the country, bringing together at least 75 public health, academic and commercial institutions studying its genome.

title: Corrections: May 1, 2020
description: An article on Saturday about some states that are allowing businesses to reopen misidentified the location of a drive-by protest in Atlanta. It was outside the Governors Mansion, not the governors office.

title: Quotation of the Day: Billions Slide Down Ladder That Took Decades to Climb
description: The garment factory helped me and my family to get out of poverty. But the coronavirus has pushed me back in.

title: Making Space in Marriage, Even as the Walls Close In
description: It was a week before our 25th anniversary, and I wanted out.

title: U.S. Stocks End the Week Lower After Tech Earnings
description: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

title: Companies Sell the Blood of Recovered Coronavirus Patients for Exorbitant Prices
description: Some biotech companies are cashing in on the race to produce coronavirus antibody tests, taking blood samples from people who have been infected and selling them at exorbitant prices.

title: Coronavirus, E.C.B., Chinese Lab: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Anderson Cooper Announces Birth of His First Child
description: Anderson Cooper signed off from a weekly CNN coronavirus town hall Thursday night by sharing some uplifting news, telling viewers that earlier in the week, he had become a father.

title: Will New N.C.A.A. Rules Really Keep Agents and Boosters at Bay?
description: The world of college sports was rocked nearly 30 years ago when a Las Vegas newspaper published a photograph of three U.N.L.V. basketball players casually drinking beer in a hot tub with Richard Perry, a man nicknamed the Fixer who was known for rigging horse races and basketball games.

title: Hundreds of Rohingya Refugees Stuck at Sea With Zero Hope
description: BANGKOK  Somewhere in turquoise waters, perhaps where the Bay of Bengal meets the Andaman Sea, wooden boats filled with Rohingya refugees are listing, adrift now for more than 10 weeks.

title: Michigan Governor Reinstates State of Emergency as Protests Ramp Up
description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, a prime political target in partisan clashes over stay-at-home orders during the coronavirus outbreak, signed three executive orders on Thursday to reinstate a state of emergency during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Tennis Coming Back Slowly With Exhibition Matches
description: Tennys Sandgren, who was on a roll before professional tennis shut down, has had enough of video games and self-isolation in his home near Nashville, Tenn.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Hollywood and Prop Culture
description: HOLLYWOOD Stream on Netflix. Hollywoods golden era is viewed through a gilded but piercing lens in this soapy new mini-series, from Ryan Murphy and Ian Brennan, both of Glee. Set in a sumptuous version of 1940s Los Angeles, Hollywood imagines a more inclusive version of that eras Tinseltown. Many characters are people to whom the real Hollywood would have been hostile. They include Archie (Jeremy Pope), an aspiring screenwriter who is black and gay, and has a movie to sell. He teams up with a young director (Darren Criss) to make that dream a reality. The bid to make Archies movie starts as a glitzy, funny, gimlet-eyed dissection of bigotry and power, James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times. Then it lurches, halfway through, into a pep talk about what some kids can accomplish if they gather up their moxie and put on a show.

title: Locked Inside, Were Like Whitman, Finding Joy in Smallness
Racing Against the Virus From Inside Australias Healthcare System
description: When my director cut short his camping holiday on Australia Day, to come back to the emergency department at the Melbourne hospital where I work as an emergency physician, I thought he was unnecessarily sacrificing his life for the sake of his work. Covid-19 was still mainly confined to China. Italy was not yet in crisis and New York wasnt even on our radar. But in hindsight, his return was prudent.

title: Word + Quiz: peroration
Hospital Needs to Be Quarantined, but Works On in Country at War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even when their city was repeatedly overrun by the Taliban and fighting reached their doorsteps, the doctors and nurses in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz kept working. They dressed wounds and saved lives at the main government hospital even as a nearby trauma center was bombed, killing more than 40 people.

title: Eyeballs
description: What is this image saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?

title: #CancelRent Is New Rallying Cry for Tenants. Landlords Are Alarmed.
description: As unemployment soars across the country, tenants rights groups and community nonprofits have rallied around an audacious goal: to persuade the government to halt rent and mortgage payments  without back payments accruing  for as long as the economy is battered by the coronavirus.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in May
description: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.

title: Rome Has Been Sacked, Conquered and Abandoned. Now Its the Pandemics Turn.
description: ROME  Rome turned 2,773 last week.

title: All Day and a Night Review: Growth Behind Bars
description: In the early moments of All Day and a Night, a gut-wrenching drama now streaming on Netflix, comes an emotional courtroom scene. Jahkor Lincoln (Ashton Sanders) sits with a look of stoic resignation in a room packed with the loved ones of the two people he has murdered. Before the judge delivers Jahkors life sentence, the mother of one of the deceased stands to speak. My granddaughter is only 10 years old, she says. You took away her whole family and never even given a reason why. Thats all I want to know. Why?

title: The Half of It Review: Being Yourself (and That Person, Too)
description: Every generation gets its own Cyrano de Bergerac, from the Steve Martin comedy Roxanne to Netflixs Sierra Burgess Is a Loser. But Alice Wus new high school-set film, The Half of It (also on Netflix), transcends the limitations that frequently serve as obstacles to ingenuity in young adult movies. By exploring issues of race and queerness with emotional complexity, it treats teenagers with the sophistication they deserve.

title: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Remdesivir, Bill de Blasio
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?

title: Lesson of the Day: Their Met Gala, Their Way. Youre Invited.
description: Featured Article: Their Met Gala, Their Way. Youre Invited. by Vanessa Friedman

title: Late Night Hosts Are Starting to Feel the Strain
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: I Watched These Pandas Have Sex. Ive Never Been So Happy.
description: Our critic Amanda Hess explains her complicated love of watching nature reclaim civilization on the internet as humans remain in quarantine.

title: The Worlds Stadiums Become a Lifeline
description: Soccer fields, football stadiums, tennis courts and martial arts arenas have been filling gaps in health care systems overwhelmed by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The New Saturday Night
description: With billions of people staying home, the world is reinventing the weekend.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, Sunshine and 4-Second Workouts
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Parks and Recreation Reunion: Isolate Yo Self
description: The 2015 finale of Parks and Recreation, the NBC comedy set in a small-town bureaucracy, took place in the future. I would not suggest that you watch it right now. I say that not so much as a judgment of its quality but because its vision of the years it flash-forwarded to  from 2017 to 2048  is, in retrospect, painfully optimistic.

title: New in Paperback: Lanny and The Unwinding of the Miracle
description: LOST AND WANTED, by Nell Freudenberger. (Vintage, 336 pp., $16.95.) In this ghost story in which scientific metaphors abound, a physics professor is haunted by the death of a close friend whom she never truly knew. The effect is beautiful, wrote our reviewer, Louisa Hall, evoking the gravitational pull of dormant, unobservable attachments and discarded hopes.

title: Lois Lowrys Ode to the Fallen in World War II
description: ON THE HORIZON By Lois Lowry Read by the author

title: How the N.R.A. Became the Most Feared Lobbying Force in America
description: THE N.R.A. The Unauthorized HistoryBy Frank Smyth Read by the author

title: Some Personal News From Samantha Irby
description: WOW, NO THANK YOU. Essays By Samantha Irby Read by the author

title: Consider Virtual Dog Training for Your Pandemic Puppy
description: Raegan Delgado, 40, was told Bolt was a mouthy puppy when she met him at the Paw Works rescue facility in Camarillo, Calif.

title: How to Run for President in the Middle of a Pandemic
description: Is it possible to run for president during a pandemic, without the handshaking and the baby-kissing? Can Joe Biden and Donald Trump stay a safe six feet from their own campaigns? Ever since the arrival of the coronavirus, weve all wondered whether democracy can operate at such a distance.

title: Virtual Galas and Foodathons
description: With the New York party scene on hiatus, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

title: The Big Impact of a Small Hobby
description: When I would tell people that drawing saved my life, I thought I was being hyperbolic. Then the coronavirus hit. Drawing had helped me survive another very dark period of my life, earlier. Could it now be helping me to stay healthy?

title: A Significant, Yet Ordinary, Sunday in Chicago
description: Marielle Sophia Newman and Jason Leverett had originally planned on having their March 29 wedding and reception at Schubas Tavern in Chicago, a live-music spot in the couples Lakeview neighborhood. We can walk to our wedding, said Ms. Newman, 37, a manuscript editor at the Journal of the American Medical Association, explaining her choice.

title: Nobody Has Seen Kim Jong-un for 19 Days. What Does It Mean?
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Nineteen days have elapsed since North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, was seen on his countrys state media, on April 12, a day after he presided over a meeting of the Politburo of the ruling Workers Party.

title: Could Innate Immunology Save Us From the Coronavirus?
description: As the world waits for a coronavirus vaccine, tens of thousands of people could die. But some scientists believe a vaccine might already exist.

title: Documenting All the Small Things That Are Easily Lost
Why Americans Need a Guaranteed Income
description: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, on Monday said what many in her caucus have been saying for weeks: A guaranteed income to help Americans struggling because of the coronavirus pandemic is worthy of attention. As recently as just a few months ago, an income guarantee was widely written off as unrealistic. But two-thirds of the members of the House Democratic caucus now support the idea of some kind of cash payment that would continue until the end of the crisis.

title: Help! My Flight Was Canceled and I Still Cant Get a Refund
description: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Timess Covid-19 coverage here.

title: This Weekends Livestreaming Events: Oprah Joins 200 Stars for a 24-Hour Benefit
description: Here are a few of the best events happening Friday through Sunday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern Daylight).

title: Bored at Work? The Solution Involves a Small Orange Man
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

title: An Upstate N.Y. Backlash Over Virus Shutdown: Its Not Up Here
description: HERKIMER, N.Y.  Scott Tranter knows how deeply the coronavirus has affected New York, with 300,000 people testing positive in the state, 18,000 dead and the economy shut down.

title: How Coronavirus Shifted the Stakes of Teenage Rebellion
description: The weekend before New York Citys stay-at-home order went into effect, my 15-year-old daughter and I had an argument. She asked if she could hang out with friends in our neighborhood, promising to be very careful and bring Purell. Acknowledging the necessity of friends and fun, I said yes and sent her off.

title: Biden Denies Tara Reades Assault Allegation: It Never Happened
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday denied an allegation of sexual assault by a former Senate aide, Tara Reade, breaking a monthlong silence that had frustrated some Democratic activists as his presidential campaign navigated issues of gender that are vitally important to many members of his party.

title: Justin Amash Can Only Cause Trouble
description: Justin Amash is running for  president?

title: When Does a Small Business File for Bankruptcy? And 8 More Questions
description: All the forecasts point in the same direction: A wave of small-business bankruptcies is coming.

description: This article is part of The New York Times True Crime storytelling project.

title: Art Biennials Were Testing Grounds. Now They Are Being Tested.
description: The Prospect New Orleans art triennial in October has been postponed to next year. So has the Liverpool Biennial. So Paulos Bienal is delayed by at least a month. The Dakar Biennale has yet to set new dates. Front International, in Cleveland, has decided to skip 2021 altogether and return in 2022.

title: A Pandemic Isnt a Reason to Abolish the SAT
description: Because of the threat posed by the coronavirus pandemic, the College Board, which administers the SAT and Advanced Placement exams, has canceled spring and summer testing and raised the possibility of offering SATs online in the fall.

title: An Accidental Navy Chief Steers His Service Through a Storm
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. Michael M. Gilday landed the top job in the Navys uniformed ranks largely by accident.

title: How New Mexico Is Beating the Virus
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  On March 13, the same day that a reluctant President Trump admitted that the coronavirus pandemic was a national emergency, a storied New Mexico hospital established the nations first drive-through testing for the virus.

title: Where Are the Photos of People Dying of Covid?
description: Recently, a friend, colleague and mentor, the cultural historian and critic Maurice Berger, died at 63 of complications from the coronavirus.

title: Find a Vaccine. Next: Produce 300 Million Vials of It.
description: In the midst of national shortages of testing swabs and protective gear, some medical suppliers and health policy experts are looking ahead to another extraordinary demand on manufacturing: Delivering a vaccine that could potentially end the pandemic.

title: How Our Reporter Digs Into Data on Unemployment
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: For Most Food Stamp Users, Online Shopping Isnt an Option
description: Whether they need more yeast for stress baking or the comfort of Kraft macaroni and cheese, Americans sequestered by social distancing are shopping for groceries online. But for many low-income households using food stamps, that can happen only in person.

title: This Feels Very Different
description: MIDLAND, Texas  In just over a month, scores of drilling rigs have been dismantled and tucked away in storage yards. Pump jacks, those piston pumps that lift crude out of the ground, have seesawed to a standstill as operators shut down wells.

title: 3 Africans in Mexico City Grave Tell Stories of Slaverys Toll
description: The three skulls were unlike hundreds of others in the 16th-century mass grave uncovered at the San Jos de los Naturales Royal Hospital in Mexico City. Their front teeth were filed decoratively, perhaps as a ritual custom, unlike those of los naturales, the Indigenous people who made up the majority of bodies at the colonial burial site. Archaeologists concluded the three individuals were most likely enslaved Africans, but they needed more evidence to be certain.

title: A Life and Death Battle: 4 Days of Kidney Failure but No Dialysis
description: Orphaned as a youth in Bangladesh, Jamal Uddin worked in a ribbon factory in Lower Manhattan while attending high school, before graduating from college and ultimately finding a career helping people with H.I.V./AIDS.

title: Streets Should Be Car-Free During Lockdown. And After.
description: Late Tuesday afternoon, New Yorks City Council speaker, Corey Johnson, was on a nine-mile walk, one the current crisis has him taking everyday  the quest for fresh air and decompression. Beginning from his boyfriends apartment in Williamsburg, he heads north into Queens over the Pulaski Bridge and through Hunters Point South Park. That is where he was when I caught up with him by phone, watching people for the most part diligently perform the choreography of social distance without, he noted, the interventions of the police.

title: How De Niro Gave Us Sinatras New York, New York, Our 7 P.M. Anthem
description: The old friend shows up every night, big and brawny as ever. Hes on a Brooklyn familys seventh-floor balcony in Windsor Terrace, and above the Portofino Ristorante in Forest Hills, and bellowing out of a truck rolling slowly up and down the empty canyons of Manhattans avenues, right on time to  with the crash of a cymbal  start spreadin the news.

title: How a Food Bank Manager Spends His Sundays
description: As a food programs manager at New York Common Pantry, a poverty reduction nonprofit, Jorge Negron works the Sunday shift in East Harlem, making sure that hungry New Yorkers can pick up a brown-bag meal on a day when most pantries and soup kitchens are closed.

title: Street Art Confronts the Pandemic
description: Street art is the ultimate visual source of social commentary and the pandemic has lit a fire under the feet of muralists around the world.

title: The Business of Burps: Scientists Smell Profit in Cow Emissions
description: LANCASTER, England  Peaches, a brown-and-white Jersey cow weighing 1,200 pounds, was amiably following Edward Towers through a barn on a sunny March morning when the 6-year-old dug in her front hooves.

title: We the People, in Order to Defeat the Coronavirus
description: The tension between private liberty and public health in the United States is hardly new. Americans have demanded the latter in times of plague and prioritized the former in times of well-being since at least the Colonial Era. Politicians and business leaders have alternately manipulated and deferred to that tension for about as long.

title: Tilly Remembers Her Grandfather
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Its Not Too Late for a Flower Garden
description: My farmer-florist neighbor Jennifer Elliotts 15-acre organic operation in the Hudson Valley is like a giant cutting garden from April to November. So it was to Ms. Elliott and another flower-focused friend that I turned for a strategy in a year when having some version of what she has, at least in miniature  the cheer of homegrown color  seemed like just the thing.

title: Jeff Bezos Doubles Down on Amazons Pandemic Response
description: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

title: Big Government? For Now, Most Americans Say Bring It On
description: The White House and some Republican governors are angling toward a cautious reopening of the economy, while G.O.P. leaders in Congress have tried to pump the brakes on future federal stimulus spending.

title: New York Closes Schools Through End of Academic Year
description: Schools throughout New York State will remain shuttered through the end of the school year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Friday, confirming what educators, union leaders and Mayor Bill de Blasio had said was inevitable weeks earlier.

title: Film Club: What My Spacewalk Taught Me About Isolation
description: Were over a month into social distancing and many of us are feeling that time and space have lost all meaning. Perhaps no one understands this better than astronauts, who spend months drifting in isolation.

title: Are You an Optimist or a Pessimist?
description: Would you say you are more of a glass is half-full or a glass is half-empty type of person? That is, are you generally an optimist, someone who tends to see the positive sides of situations, or a pessimist, someone who more often sees the negative?

title: Can Street Artists Survive a City in Lockdown?
description: LONDON  One recent Friday, Nathan Bowen, a graffiti artist, was spray painting a boarded-up storefront in East London.

title: All Day and a Night | Anatomy of a Scene
description: The writer and director Joe Robert Cole narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ashton Sanders.

title: In Philanthropy, Race Is Still a Factor in Who Gets What, Study Shows
description: Philanthropy often sets out to mitigate inequality. But a research report set to be released next week by two leading philanthropic organizations shows that race remains a defining factor when looking at which organizations get funded and how much they receive.

title: Health Savings Accounts Add Options in Pandemic, Including Telehealth
description: People with a health savings account now have more flexibility in how they use the money because of rule changes prompted by the coronavirus outbreak.

title: How All Day and a Night Dazzles With a Street Scene
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: How to Spend Your Weekend Outside
description: Good morning.

title: A Record Sale in Brooklyn Among Aprils Closings
description: New York Citys real estate market reached new highs in April, even as the coronavirus outbreak threatened future home sales.

title: Tanzanian Cartoonist Has a Stick for Every Powerful Eye
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In a quiet office on the third floor of a building in Nairobis central business district, the cartoonist known by his pen name, Gado, was sketching a satire  about the coronavirus.

title: Sheltering in Place in an R.V. Is Not as Fun as It Sounds
description: In the six years since they decided to sell their house and move into a 40-foot motor home, Julie and Marc Bennett have crisscrossed the country and become masters of the R.V. lifestyle  all while still working and saving for retirement, as they note on their website, RVlove.com. They even wrote a book, Living the RV Life, with tips on how to choose the right vehicle, how to get mail and how not to get electrocuted.

title: Setback for Harry and Meghan in Legal Battle With U.K. Tabloids
description: LONDON  In a setback to Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, in their bitter legal battle against the British tabloids, a high court judge struck down key claims on Friday in a lawsuit that Meghan brought against The Mail on Sunday for publishing a letter she sent to her father.

title: Job Interviews Are Broken. Theres a Way to Fix Them.
description: Within the first few minutes of the interview, I knew the candidate was a bad fit for a sales position. His rsum had tipped me off: He was a math major and built robots in his spare time. Now we were sitting face-to-face in my office, but he hardly made any eye contact. When I told my boss I wasnt going to hire him because of that, she said, You know this is a phone sales job, right?

title: A Private Equity Firm Is Blocked From Buying .Org
description: A private equity firm will not gain control of dot-org, the digital real estate that is home to millions of nonprofits, nongovernmental organizations and community groups.

title: The Credibility Bookcase Is the Quarantines Hottest Accessory
description: Imagine that you are a member of the expert class  the kind of person invited to pontificate on television news programs. Under normal circumstances, your expertise might be signaled to the public by a gaudy photograph of skyscrapers superimposed behind your head. But now the formalities of the broadcast studio are a distant memory, and the only tools to convey that you truly belong on television are the objects within your own home. Theres only one move: You talk in front of a bookcase.

title: A Composer and Her (Very) Long String Instrument
description: Like most people these days, the sound artist Ellen Fullman is sheltering in place. But she has an unusual roommate: a massive installation she calls the Long String Instrument.

title: What Rights Do Pregnant Workers Have in a Pandemic?
description: In the middle of March, when it was clear coronavirus shutdowns were imminent, Anna, 29, was at her obstetricians office for a pregnancy well visit. She was supposed to travel from her home in the Midwest to Florida that weekend to see her in-laws, but her doctor advised against it. Annas obstetrician also recommended that she work from home going forward  pregnant womens immune systems are already taxed, and experts cant say with certainty how the coronavirus might affect them.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. The mailbags been interesting these days, missives from all over the world, from up and down the socio-economic ladder: people eating rillettes in the Alps and canned beans in rural Maine; front-line medical workers craving fresh strawberries, unemployed car salesmen grilling pork ribs and wondering whats going to happen next.

title: The Healing Power of Baseball
description: A friend and fellow baseball fan recently sent an email and an old photo to offer his appreciation to our medical staff. Gleaned from the archives of the National Baseball Hall of Fame, the image showed an exhibition game played in Pasadena, Calif., in Jan. 1919. The scene shows the batter, catcher and umpire all wearing surgical masks, as are those watching from the grandstand. The image was captured just a few months before the third and final wave of the devastating influenza pandemic that emerged in 1918.

title: Beyonc Amps Up Savage, and 12 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Porches, Yards, Driveways, Parking Lots: Where the Neighborhood Is Now
description: We walk the dogs across the meadow in the rain. We dont talk much. We say the same things over and over, and yet somehow theres comfort in the repetition. Yesterday someone wrote on the town listserv that certain dog owners had been spotted in the meadow less than six feet away from each other. Suddenly, everybodys a cop, yardsticks in their minds.

title: Behind the Cover: Race and Covid-19
Congress Calls on Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Testify
description: WASHINGTON  The House Judiciary Committee on Friday called on Jeff Bezos, Amazons chief executive, to testify before Congress, in a major escalation of its investigation into the countrys largest technology companies.

title: At New Yorks Museums of Plants, the Art Is Blooming Lonely
description: Phil Macaluso, a gardener, bikes to work at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden four days a week from his home about a five-minute ride away. The garden is closed, but the trees and everything else in Brooklyn are still growing, even if other aspects of the citys life have come to a standstill.

title: Why Trump Is Obsessed With the Flynn Case
description: In the middle of the coronavirus crisis, a cratering economy and plummeting approval ratings, perhaps its not surprising to see President Trump return to a favorite theme: abusing the rule of law.

title: To the Readers of This Newsletter
description: This article originally ran as part of David Leonhardts newsletter, which will be named Opinion Today starting May 4. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

title: Full Transcript: Joe Biden Addresses Tara Reade Allegations on Morning Joe
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. appeared on MSNBCs Morning Joe on Friday to publicly address, for the first time, Tara Reades allegation that Mr. Biden sexually assaulted her. Mr. Biden denies the allegation.

title: Farewell to the Friendly Cheek Kiss
description: I never meant to kiss Miuccia Prada. Not on the lips, anyway. It was a muggy afternoon in the spring of 2015, and I was in Tokyo at the opening of her new Miu Miu store. I had been waiting in line to congratulate her. The lights above me hung bright and hot, and I knew without looking that I had sweated through the tailored suit Id been given to wear for the occasion. A famous French actress stood two people ahead of me at the front of the line. Her arms Pietd out as she approached the Italian designer, hands landing confidently on Mrs. Pradas shoulders, and, as if tracing the line of a toppled-over parabola, she kissed her  mwah  on the left cheek, and then again  mwah  on the right. The next person followed suit, making it through the exchange without incident. Then it was my turn. I kind of cranked forward and cupped Mrs. Pradas waist the way a high school junior might initiate a slow dance. Then I lurched even closer, barely grazing one side of her cheek on the first try. On the second, determined this time to make contact, I touched the hinge of her lips to mine.

title: Introducing Rhubarb Bars, Lemon Bars Pinker Cousins
description: Is it me, or have rhubarb desserts gotten pinker and more vivid in the last few years?

title: Life in Trumps Coronavirus Ghetto
description: In 2018, I wrote an Op-Ed for this paper under the headline Were All in the Ghetto Now. I criticized Donald Trumps flagrant disregard of constituents and constituencies he didnt like or consider allies.

title: Bonds Beat Stocks Over the Last 20 Years
description: You can count on stocks to beat bonds over the long haul. That, at least, is the common wisdom, and much of the time it has even been true.

title: The C.E.O. at the Center of New Yorks Coronavirus Crisis
description: Dr. Steven Corwin was a doctor during the AIDS crisis. He was the chief medical officer at NewYork-Presbyterian on Sept. 11, 2001. He has never seen anything like this.

title: Fatigue Is Here, but the Economic Fight Is Just Beginning
description: As early as we are in the fight against the Covid-19 virus, I fear that many Americans may already be exhausted by it.

title: Blood Pressure Drugs Dont Increase Coronavirus Risk, Studies Find
description: Drugs that are widely prescribed to treat high blood pressure do not make patients more susceptible to coronavirus infection, or to severe illness if they do become infected, researchers reported on Friday.

title: Murals Send a Message of Hope in Grim Times
description: On Wilshire Boulevard in Santa Monica, five artists gathered recently, with appropriate social distancing. They painted Togetherness in huge letters vibrantly embellished across the plywood panels protecting the windows of the shuttered kitchenware store Sur La Table.

title: Bill de Blasio Finds His Scapegoat
description: Bill de Blasio was hankering for a scapegoat. The need was entirely understandable.

title: The Hunt for Moby Dick Moves Online
description: If these were normal times, Ger Tysk, a sailor, would be getting her tall ship ready for an expedition along the coast of New England.

title: 7 Savory Pancakes for Any Time of Day
description: Simple to assemble, savory pancakes are a universal comfort food. Their versatility is indicated by the many variations served around the world: Turkish zucchini pancakes, Korean vegetable pajeon and Japanese okonomiyaki. Fluffy and light or crisp and pan-fried, savory pancakes are a natural vehicle for using up leftovers or pantry ingredients.

title: Parmesan! Crusted! Chicken!
description: Welcome back to Five Weeknight Dishes. This week, Ive been thinking about The Timess original weeknight columnist, the French chef Pierre Franey, who wrote 60-Minute Gourmet. (He pretty much invented boneless chicken breasts, and before chicken nuggets were a thing, he had us making goujonettes for dinner parties.) When he started in 1975, the ingredients available to most home cooks were pretty limited, as they are right now: a lot of dried, canned and frozen staples; the most basic fresh produce; and only the occasional fresh herbs or tomatoes or raspberries.

title: Now Is the Time to Learn to Play Bridge
description: Bridge will reward you early on  but the first few hours are utterly disorienting. Using a combination of apps, books and computer players who wont berate you for mistakes is the easiest way to power through that vicious learning curve into the fun part.

title: Hollywood Offers Alternate History, and Glimpses of a Real One
description: Let me guess, Patti LuPone says as she plinks olives into a martini. You came here to be a movie star.

title: David Najem Has Been Reading a Lot, but Hed Rather Be Playing Soccer
description: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: This Snickerdoodle in Poundcake Form Is Your Next Baking Project
description: Whether its called a loaf cake, tea cake, poundcake or one of those slyly named breads of the banana-pumpkin-zucchini variety, if I can bake it in a 9-by-5-inch pan, it will find a place in my lockdown kitchen. Theres something about loaf cake's sturdy, bricklike shape that makes it feel like a bulwark against the chaos of the moment.

title: An Eerily Prescient Pandemic Novel Thats Guaranteed to Terrify
description: THE END OF OCTOBERBy Lawrence Wright

title: Elon Musk Says Tesla Share Price Is Too High
description: Teslas chief executive, Elon Musk, said on Twitter on Friday that the companys stock price, which had been surging in recent weeks, was too high in his opinion. The stock fell sharply after the post, and closed 10.3 percent down.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend and to a new month. Maybe this is the weekend for a big lasagna, or to catch a film starring Irrfan Khan or Rishi Kapoor, both great Indian actors who died this week. You also might want to start looking at what you can send Mom because Mothers Day is next weekend in the United States. Whatever youre doing, make time for some great journalism.

title: Big Techs Worries Should Worry You
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: As Students Put Off College, Anxious Universities Tap Wait Lists
description: Ahead of the traditional May 1 deadline to decide where she would go to college, Tiffany Tang had four schools to choose from. Then on Tuesday, the University of California, Los Angeles emailed to offer her a spot off the wait list. That evening, she received a call from a Houston area code  an admissions officer from Rice. On Wednesday, Cornell got in touch.

title: Hoteliers Push for $126 Million in Small-Business Aid Draws Scrutiny
description: Monty Bennetts sprawling hospitality company is the biggest known applicant of the governments small-business relief program. The Texas conservative has remained unwilling to return his loans even as public anger builds over large companies getting the funds  a fact now drawing the scrutiny of a key lawmaker.

title: Canada Bans Assault Weapons in Wake of Deadly Mass Shooting
description: OTTAWA  Nearly two weeks after the deadliest mass shooting in Canadas history, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday introduced an immediate ban on what he described as military-style assault weapons.

title: What Is Covid Toe? Maybe a Strange Sign of Coronavirus Infection
description: Before the coronavirus outbreak, Dr. Lindy Fox, a dermatologist in San Francisco, used to see four or five patients a year with chilblains  painful red or purple lesions that typically emerge on fingers or toes in the winter.

title: Democrats Seek Investigation Into Claims of Meddling at Consumer Bureau
description: Democratic lawmakers called on Friday for a formal investigation into allegations that President Trumps political appointees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau improperly interfered in the drafting of a planned regulation on payday lending.

title: Love Letter: Living With Loneliness
description: The coronavirus pandemic has forced many of us into isolation; now family gatherings and weekend brunches with friends are a thing of the past. While were all finding ways to cope  and maybe even trying to channel some optimism  living alone presents its own unique challenges (and possibly benefits too!).

title: The New York City Wine and Food Festival Moves Online
description: The annual summer Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., has been canceled. But the New York City Wine and Food Festival, a four-day fall fund-raiser that sprawls across the city in restaurants and event spaces? Not so fast. Lee Schrager, the organizer and founder, is going digital with it, starting this week, and still hopes the festival will return in October. (He was able to slip in the South Beach edition in Miami just under the wire in February.) Now with the gala atmosphere at tastings, lunches, cocktail gatherings and dinners falling victim to social distancing, the festival has added NYCWFF at Home, with sessions, mainly classes, featuring food celebrities and chefs a few times a week. Participants, up to 300 per session, pay $20 each and can join via Zoom. There will even be a 15-minute Q. and A. at the end of each event. All the money goes to the National Restaurant Associations Restaurant Employee Relief Fund. First up on Monday at 2:30 p.m. will be Neil Patrick Harris cooking with his husband, David Burtka; Wednesday will feature Alex Guarnaschelli and her daughter. Plans are for it to continue for months to come.

title: Blood Samples, Vital for Antibody Tests, Sold at Exorbitant Rates
description: After 10 terrible days of chills, nausea, a fever of 103 and a headache of such intensity that her nose bled, Aleacia Jenkins knew she had been stricken with the coronavirus even before she tested positive.

title: Fauci, Leading Fight Against Coronavirus, Misses Baseball, Too
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the federal governments top infectious disease expert, spends 19-hour days helping to lead the fight against the coronavirus.

title: Bolsonaro Fights for Survival, Turning to Empowered Military Elders
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Jair Bolsonaro ascended to Brazils presidency with a sweeping set of promises, like cutting out the rot of corruption, firing up the economy and doing away with the countrys notorious pork-barrel politics.

title: The Coronavirus Still Is a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Warns
description: The World Health Organization extended its declaration of a global health emergency on Friday amid increasing criticism from the Trump Administration about its handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Best Part of the Campaign Trail (the Food!) Comes Home
description: It started on my birthday. I received, on the same blessed day in April, a package of ribs from the Memphis restaurant Central BBQ, courtesy of my brother and sister-in-law, and a box of Eastern North Carolina barbecue and hush puppies from Kings BBQ Restaurant, by way of my parents.

title: A Suicide Highlighting the Stresses Doctors Face
description: To the Editor:

title: In Odd Turn With Israel, Gazans Get Economic Adrenaline Shot from Virus
description: GAZA CITY  Ziad Qassems 25 years as a tailor seemed worthless in the cruel economy of the blockaded Gaza Strip: Unemployed for eight months, piling up debt, he sat idle in his apartment, worried how he would provide for his wife and five children.

title: Drive-Throughs Are Now a Lifeline for Fast-Food Chains
description: For decades, the fast-food drive-through has been a greasy symbol of Americana, a roadside ritual for millions of travelers with a hankering for burgers and fries.

title: Pride at the Plate for a Little League All-Star
description: Fairly often one of my students raises a hand in class just as Im saying something that feels important. When the palm hangs there, imploring but impertinent, I turn and ask, You have a question, or you want a high-five? The joke, however middling, cuts the tension. Almost always, the student replies, Both. We slap a high-five. The question is asked and answered. Class gets back to business.

title: Your Life or Your Livelihood: Americans Wrestle With Impossible Choice
description: When Maine finally announced this week that hair salons could reopen, Sarah Kyllonen, a stylist in Lewiston, stayed up late wondering what to do, feeling overwhelmed.

title: In a City Frozen in Fear, Time Freezes, Too
description: NEW DELHI  The first thing that disappeared was the annoying sound of a power drill up the street, from a house under construction.

title: Lawrence Wright on Researching a (Fictional) Pandemic
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

title: What the Proponents of Natural Herd Immunity Dont Say
description: The coronavirus moved so rapidly across the globe partly because no one had prior immunity to it. Failure to check its spread will result in a catastrophic loss of lives. Yet some politicians, epidemiologists and commentators are advising that the most practical course of action is to manage infections while allowing so-called herd immunity to build.

title: How to Also Keep Your Car Healthy
description: The response of the auto industry in times of national peril is legendary. Detroits reputation as the Arsenal of Democracy, producing the tens of thousands of bombers and tanks that helped the Allies win World War II, is well-deserved.

title: Fertility Clinics Stay Open Despite Unclear Guidelines
description: Since March, fertility clinics across the country have halted treatments for tens of thousands of people because of Covid-19, forcing patients to suspend their family planning. In recent days, some clinics have reopened, resuming services and procedures despite ongoing coronavirus concerns.

title: Helen McGehee, a Martha Graham Dancer and Teacher, Dies at 98
description: Helen McGehee, a powerful dancer in Martha Grahams company since the 1940s and a prominent teacher known for her tough-love rigor, died on April 9 in Lynchburg, Va., where she lived. She was 98.

title: Your Chicken Is No Longer Pink. That Doesnt Mean Its Safe to Eat.
description: As we wait out this pandemic, chances are youre at home, cooking. Perhaps youve baked a million loaves of bread and your sourdough starter is overflowing. If Google Trends is any indication of what comes next, after banana bread and pancakes, people are seeking chicken recipes.

title: The Courage to Be Alone
description: My youngest daughter has told me that Annabelle, her baby doll, might have the coronavirus. We talk about it as we take a daily walk up the road. Shes not sure yet whether it is diabetes or the virus. Annabelles symptoms vary, but she has not left the small cradle by the side of my daughters bed in days. I have been told I can babysit for Annabelle, but only if I promise to hold her gently and not give her candy. My daughter holds my hand as we walk. She wants to talk about her dolls sickness every day. Not surprisingly, shes not sure when or if Annabelle will get a test.

title: Tara Reades Sexual Assault Claim Against Joe Biden
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit of Relief: Tea and Toast
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Is Physics on the Wrong Track? And Other Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Matty Simmons, a Force Behind Animal House, Is Dead at 93
description: Matty Simmons, who helped launch National Lampoon magazine and was instrumental in bringing into being its most famous side project, the 1978 movie National Lampoons Animal House, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: May: The Month That Sports, Kind of, Come Back
description: The month of April in sports was almost barren. Live events amounted to a ragtag collection of badminton from Armenia, short-format ice hockey from Russia and video games.

title: Lynn Harrell, Acclaimed American Cellist, Is Dead at 76
description: Lynn Harrell, a leading American cellist whose acclaimed playing, begun when he was 8 years old, combined robust sound, insightful musicianship and feeling for nuances, died on April 27 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76.

title: The Berlin Philharmonic Tests a Musical Path Out of Lockdown
description: On March 12, the mighty Berlin Philharmonic went ahead with a concert it had scheduled before the coronavirus outbreak. I watched it from my apartment in New York, and it was like little I had ever seen: a livestreamed performance in an empty hall. It was uncanny, and intensely moving, to realize that the only audience was us watching in our homes around the world.

title: Scholars Plea: U.S. and China, Work Together on the Pandemic
description: To the Editor:

title: U.K. Virus Tests Surpass Target, but Britains Deaths May Overtake Italys
description: LONDON  For Britons looking to judge their governments desperate response to the coronavirus pandemic, the verdict has increasingly come down to two numbers: 100,000, the number of tests that officials promised to conduct every day by the end of April; and 27,510, the latest death toll.

title: Kitchen Confidential: Three Culinary Memoirs
description: EVERYTHING IS UNDER CONTROL

title: A Texas-Size Reopening Has Many Wondering: Too Much or Not Enough?
description: HOUSTON  Texas pushed its way out of a statewide coronavirus lockdown on Friday, a wide-ranging reopening of restaurants, businesses and beaches in the midst of an ongoing outbreak that still left at least one local official hoping for even more.

title: Is It Safe to Come Out of Lockdown? Check the Sewer
description: The world is eager to come out of lockdown. But if countries simply return to business as usual, new outbreaks of Covid-19 will follow. The only solution that public health experts see is to keep careful track of the coronavirus and clamp down on new flare-ups.

title: The Immunity of the Tech Giants
description: If power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely, how can we best describe the kind of power Big Tech will wield when the coronavirus crisis is over?

title: Will Biden Play by the Rules?
description: So here we Democrats have it, a nightmare spun from the looms of Steve Bannons imagination: The problem of Tara Reade.

title: Barr Defends Response to Virus in Stormy Twitter Session
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General William P. Barr defended the Justice Departments response to the pandemic on Friday in a rare online question-and-answer session that was marred by vitriolic criticism directed at him over the treatment of inmates in federal prisons ravaged by the coronavirus and other issues.

title: A Matter of Taste
description: Enjoying this newsletter? Tell a friend to sign up at nytimes.com/rory and then youll have something new to talk about every Friday.

title: SpaceX to Bring Crew to Short-Staffed Space Station for Longer Stay
description: What was intended as a two-week test flight of SpaceXs new astronaut-carrying capsule will now be a mission planned to last more than a month to help a short-handed crew aboard the International Space Station.

title: Zev Buffman, Prolific Theatrical Producer, Is Dead at 89
description: Zev Buffman had been a prominent Broadway producer for two decades when he met Elizabeth Taylor in 1980 at the opening night of his revival of Brigadoon, the Lerner and Loewe musical, at the National Theater in Washington.

title: Lace Up Your Running Shoes
description: With gyms and spin studios closed, running has become the de facto sport of enthusiastic and reluctant athletes. And as more people find new joy in it, and more die-hard runners see races canceled or postponed, virtual races, in which you record your time for a particular distance via an app and compete against others doing the same, are on the rise.

title: Kim Jong-un Resurfaces, State Media Says, After Weeks of Health Rumors
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, resurfaced in public view on Friday, the Norths state news media reported Saturday, controverting three weeks of rumors and unconfirmed news reports that he was in grave danger after undergoing heart surgery.

title: Takuo Aoyagi, an Inventor of the Pulse Oximeter, Dies at 84
description: Takuo Aoyagi, a Japanese engineer whose pioneering work in the 1970s led to the modern pulse oximeter, a lifesaving device that clips on a finger and shows the level of oxygen in the blood and that has become a critical tool in the fight against the novel coronavirus, died on April 18 in Tokyo. He was 84.

title: Harvard Kept Ties With Jeffrey Epstein After 08 Conviction, Report Shows
description: He had no official Harvard affiliation, yet Jeffrey Epstein had his own office, key card and Harvard phone line. He would often swing by on weekends to host dinners with academics he wanted to meet.

title: Colleges Wont Refund Tuition. Autumn May Force a Reckoning.
description: If you didnt get what you paid for, and the thing you bought cost five figures, it stands to reason that youd get some of your money back.

title: States Reopen, Joe Biden, Street Art: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Think Twice, Mnuchin Tells Prep Schools Seeking Virus Loans
description: As a number of elite private preparatory schools consider taking federal stimulus loans, they received a stark warning on Friday that they risked invoking the ire of the countrys top financial official.

title: Two Medical Systems, Two Pandemic Responses
description: After lamenting in a recent Canada Letter about my inability to find an expert who could offer an informed comparison of how the medical systems in Canada and the United States were responding to the coronavirus pandemic, I soon heard from Prof. Peter Berman.

title: A Onetime Leader of Fox News Returns to the Murdoch Fold
description: David Rhodes, a former Fox News executive who also led CBS News, has quietly begun consulting for Rupert Murdochs media empire.

title: Doctor Who Promoted Malarial Drug Draws Scrutiny of Federal Prosectors
description: WASHINGTON  A federal prosecutor has opened a preliminary inquiry into whether an obscure New York doctor who won White House attention by claiming he could treat the coronavirus broke the law by falsely claiming that a hospital study of drugs he had promoted had won federal approval.

title: Marvin Schick, Advocate for the Orthodox Community, Dies at 85
description: Marvin Schick, a pioneering advocate for the rights of Orthodox Jews to maintain their religious practices in the places they worked, died on April 23 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85.

title: Transcending Space and Time Through Tape
description: READER CALLOUT: Want relationship advice from Esther Perel? Submit a question about your personal relationships during the pandemic, and the therapist and author may answer it in a future episode of The Daily.

title: Some Trump Officials Take Harder Actions on China During Pandemic
description: WASHINGTON  Some top Trump administration officials are moving to take a more aggressive stand against China on economic, diplomatic and scientific issues at the heart of the relationship between the worlds two superpowers, further fraying ties that have reached their lowest point in decades.

title: Should Surfing Be Allowed During the Pandemic?
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.  Many surfers like me believe that surfing is more than just a sport; we consider it a way of life. Being in the ocean and riding waves can be ecstatic and spiritual.

title: Olympic Gymnast Recalls Emotional Abuse So Twisted That I Thought It Couldnt Be Real
description: For the longest time, Laurie Hernandez, an Olympic champion gymnast, thought she was crazy for thinking that her coach had emotionally abused her.

title: How Remdesivir, New Hope for Covid-19 Patients, Was Resurrected
description: Remdesivir, an antiviral drug designed to treat both hepatitis and a common respiratory virus, seemed fated to join thousands of other failed medications after proving useless against those diseases. The drug was consigned to the pharmaceutical scrap heap, all but forgotten by the scientists who once championed it.

title: Blue Bells Ex-C.E.O. Charged in Conspiracy to Cover Up Listeria Outbreak
description: The former chief executive of Blue Bell Creameries was charged with conspiracy in connection with his repeated efforts to cover up what became a deadly outbreak of listeria in some of the companys products in 2015, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

title: I Will Never Lie to You, McEnany Says in First White House Briefing
description: WASHINGTON  Kayleigh McEnany stepped on the podium in the White House Briefing Room on Friday, 417 days since a press secretary for President Trump last held a news briefing, with a promise to the sparse group of journalists allowed in the room under the current social distancing guidelines.

title: Capitol Lacks Tests for Returning Senators While White House Tests Many in Trumps Circle
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Brian P. Monahan, the tight-lipped doctor who attends to Congress, sent up on Thursday what some have construed as a warning: His office, he told senior Republican officials on a private conference call, cannot screen all 100 senators for the coronavirus when they return to work on Monday.

title: A Shortage of Steak? Yes, and Ranchers Knew It Was Coming
description: PERKINS COUNTY, S.D.  I live on a ranch. When I stand on the gravel road that runs along the section line by my house I can look in any direction across the waving grass and, other than the modest huddle of buildings and fencing that compose our ranch, see little evidence of human development. To say it is remote is like saying water is wet. We arent Iowa remote or Wisconsin remote. This is the American steppe, where the population density is one person per square mile.

title: As Businesses Resurface After State Shutdowns, So Does Divisiveness
description: CHICAGO  Texas lifted stay-at-home orders for its 29 million residents. Hair salons in Maine welcomed customers back inside. In Alabama, clothing boutiques flung open their doors.

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Teams Equal Pay Demands Are Dismissed by Judge
description: The judge in the United States womens soccer teams equal pay lawsuit rejected the players most important claims on Friday, delivering a crushing blow to the teams four-year legal campaign against the United States Soccer Federation.

title: No One Needs Botox in a Pandemic. But Some in Beverly Hills Are Now Getting It.
description: With a hoodie over her ears, a surgical mask over her nose and an eye on the clock  I have four boys under the age of 12, and theyre home-schooling  42-year-old Ally Sample was making up for lost time at her Beverly Hills plastic surgeons office on Friday.

title: Wild Ideas to Bring Back Sports Might Say More About Cities Than Leagues
description: Sports leagues are desperate for a safe way to start playing games again. Las Vegas has tens of thousands of empty hotel rooms and a tourism-based economy that has been wracked by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Who Knows Where the Time Goes
description: Absent any other marker, nature indicates the passage of time. Daffodils and hyacinths give way to roses. Blossoms fall, new leaves bud, pink petals are gone from empty New York streets. Frozen figures in rumpled clothes may note some slight change in the canvas. Who knows where the time goes?

title: Judge Vacates Oil and Gas Leases on 145,000 Acres in Montana
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday vacated 287 oil and gas leases on almost 150,000 acres of land in Montana, ruling that the Trump administration had improperly issued the leases to energy companies in 2017 and 2018.

title: Native American Tribes Sue Treasury Over Stimulus Aid as They Feud Over Funding
description: WASHINGTON  A group of Native American tribes is suing the Treasury Department for failing to provide billions of dollars in coronavirus relief allocated for tribes in the $2.2 trillion stimulus package, setting off one of the most significant legal battles between tribal governments and the United States in years.

title: Joe Biden and the Presumption of Innocence
description: Regarding Tara Reades allegation that she was sexually assaulted by Joe Biden in 1993, and what the allegation could mean for Democrats this fall, some stock phrases come to mind. Hoisted on their own petard. Whats sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. Be careful what you wish for.

title: What Does Modern Love Mean in a Pandemic?
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Investigate Tara Reades Allegations
description: Former Vice President Joe Biden, the Democrats presumptive nominee for president, has forcefully denied allegations of sexual harassment and assault made against him by Tara Reade, a former staff assistant in his Senate office.

title: Poker-Faced
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is a really cool-looking and inviting grid from Paolo Pasco; it might be a slightly sloppy smiley face, or a postmodern dollar sign. The actual solve is hard to break into, but the middle portion winds up being pretty doable. The stepping stacks at the top and bottom are almost all debuts, including a bit of lingo, so you need a good ear for catchphrases and a little luck to finish.

title: Quotation of the Day: Risky New Phase Brings Discord and Unease
description: It is like having a smoking section on a plane or in a restaurant. It doesnt work.

title: Trump Moves to Replace Watchdog Who Identified Critical Medical Shortages
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump moved on Friday night to replace a top official at the Department of Health and Human Services who angered him with a report last month highlighting supply shortages and testing delays at hospitals during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Photos of Life Transformed by a Pandemic
description: Restaurants are receiving patrons into dining rooms that are partially cordoned off for social distancing, friends are seeking safe conversation in the sunshine and some people are trying to continue a productive path forward in isolation.

title: Corrections: May 2, 2020
description: An article on Friday about the overnight closing of New Yorks subway referred imprecisely to the citys public transit schedule. It is the only system in the United States that runs all of its train lines 24 hours a day; it is not the only system in the country to operate 24 hours a day.

title: As Restrictions Lift, Countries Brace for a New Reality
Whats on TV Saturday: Beanpole and The Half of It
description: BEANPOLE (2020) Stream on Mubi; rent on Kino Now. The young Russian director Kantemir Balagov wowed critics with this, his sophomore feature, a drama set in Leningrad in 1945. World War II is over, but the wounds it sowed are still fresh and apparent in every frame. Iya (Viktoria Miroshnichenko), nicknamed Beanpole because she is unusually tall, was once on the front lines, but a concussion made her unfit for battle. Now she tends to soldiers at a military hospital and cares for the child of her friend and former fellow soldier, Masha (Vasilisa Perelygina), who returns to the city only to hear devastating news. Together, the women try to heal themselves and find hope. Manohla Dargis named the movie a Critics Pick in her review for The New York Times, calling it a brilliantly told, deeply moving story about love  in all its manifestations, perversity and obstinacy.

title: With No Kentucky Derby, Live and Virtual Substitutes Emerge
description: There will be a derby on Saturday. Three of them, in fact. Churchill Downs is hosting a virtual Kentucky Derby, one pitting all 13 Triple Crown winners against one another in a simulated race, while Oaklawn Park will run the Arkansas Derby. Twice.

title: Track Where Your Money Goes
description: Where does your money go each month? Now, especially, with financial goals and priorities in flux, its important to know in granular detail.

title: French Muslims Face a Cruel Coronavirus Shortage: Burial Grounds
description: PARIS  The middle-aged men, some wearing masks and gloves, leaned over a freshly excavated grave and gingerly slid a coffin into it. Arching their backs and bending their knees, they were burying a 60-year-old French-Moroccan woman in the Muslim section of a cemetery in a town north of Paris.

title: Kim Jong-un Is Back. What Happens When Hes Really Gone?
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, reappeared in dramatic fashion this weekend when he was shown on North Korean media after three weeks of unexplained absence, cutting the ribbon on a fertilizer factory  and quieting rumors that he was gravely ill.

title: With Over Two Dozen Deaths, London Bus Drivers Fear Coronavirus Risk
description: London is a city gone quiet. Yet, with a stringent coronavirus lockdown in place and the normal bustle largely halted, bold red buses are still winding their way through the sprawling capital offering frequent service.

title: A Wedding Under the St. Louis Arch
description: Sean Gottlieb and Matthew Kerns met for the first time on gay pride day last year in St. Louis, after finding each other on Scruff, a site that helps gay men connect.

title: Their Perfect Date: April 25 (and Each Other)
description: Ariel Ball and Ross Weinstein held fast to their original wedding date, and were married April 25 in Stuyvesant Cove Park along the East River in Manhattan. Mark Stokely, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, rode his bicycle from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to officiate.

title: A Delayed Yes From Each of Them
description: Adrianna Kruyt, a Canadian in the first year of graduate studies in Manhattan at the New School, didnt have plans for Thanksgiving in 2016. So her parents arranged for her to spend the long weekend celebrating the American holiday with friends in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Standing on a Step Stool to Kiss the Groom
description: Martin Schmaltz, a physics professor at Boston University, preferred to study the rate of the expansion of the universe over dating.

title: Seeing an Old Friend With New Eyes
description: When Bennett Eastham needed a mental-health break last June from working long hours at a Virginia law firm, he made plans to travel to Copenhagen to see Andrew Bird, an American singer, perform there.

title: They Shrunk a 450-Plus Guest List. For Now.
description: Ayana Coston and Clinton Jordan Jr., friends for 17 years who began dating about 18 months ago, had set a wedding date for May 23 with a guest list that kept growing.

title: Melvilles Whale Was a Warning We Failed to Heed
description: In 1841, while aboard the whaler Acushnet, Herman Melville met William Chase among another ships complement. William lent Melville a book by his father, Owen Chase: Narrative of the Most Extraordinary and Distressing Shipwreck of the Whale-Ship Essex. Melville had read Jeremiah Reynoldss violent account of a sperm whale white as wool, named  for his haunt near Mocha Island, off the coast of Chile  Mocha Dick. Its unknown what led Melville to tweak Mocha to Moby. Good thing he did, and that Starbuck was the name he gave his first mate rather than his captain. Otherwise the novel would follow Starbucks obsession with a Mocha.

title: New York Is Wounded. I Miss It More Than Ever.
description: I live in Beirut, Lebanon, but in this season of confinement I could be anywhere. I have left my apartment eight times in six weeks; my brushes with the city where Ive lived for a year and a half are so brief, I forgot that I lived near the sea until I went up on a roof and my eyes confronted the blue fact of the Mediterranean. In my apartment, with friends nine time zones away as accessible as friends down the block, I Zoom far and wide. I could be anywhere, but some part of me wants to be in New York.

title: Stark Symbol of Pandemic in N.Y.: Homeless People Huddled on the Subway
description: Every No. 2 train that lumbered into the last stop in the Bronx late Wednesday night had, at most, a couple of dozen passengers. And when the doors swooshed open, half of them had no intention of getting off.

title: Married Doctors Learn to Meet in the Middle
description: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In Its No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

title: Is This the Future of the Fashion Show?
description: The next round of fashion shows will be virtual fashion shows. This is not in doubt.

title: Murder Hornets in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet
description: BLAINE, Wash.  In his decades of beekeeping, Ted McFall had never seen anything like it.

title: Play This: The Paperback Game
description: My family didnt invent the paperback game (I dont know who did), but weve played it for years. Its for four to 10 people and perfect for lockdown. You can play at the table after dinner, after the dishes have been cleared and everyone is loosened up. An Earl Hines record on in the background sets the mood perfectly. Heres how to play:

title: 9/11 Prisoners May Get Video Chats to Bridge the Coronavirus Divide
description: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

title: Jewish Characters Star in Saudi TV Show, Igniting an Arab Debate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a mud-walled village in the Persian Gulf, a Christian woman sheds tears of love for a Muslim merchant. But he is stuck in a miserable marriage to a woman who longs for another Muslim man. But she cant have him, because he is crazy about the local rabbis daughter.

title: After a Lifetime Together, Coronavirus Takes Them Both
description: For most of her life, Maranda Lender, 32, has lived with her parents in Lewisberry, Pa.

title: Fearing Political Peril, Republicans Edge Away From Trump on Pandemic Response
description: WASHINGTON  Every evening from his kitchen table in southwestern Michigan, Representative Fred Upton, a moderate Republican running for his 18th term in office, posts a coronavirus dispatch for his constituents, highlighting his own efforts to respond to the crisis and the news from Washington, often with cameos from Democrats.

title: My Retirement Plan Is You
description: Sian-Pierre Regis, 35, is used to living with roommates. For the past 10 years, he has split the rent on his apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan with two (in some cases, three) friends. But in June, hes getting a co-tenant of a different sort: his 78-year-old mother, Rebecca Danigelis.

title: I Could Solve Most of Your Problems: Eric Schmidts Pentagon Offensive
description: In July 2016, Raymond Thomas, a four-star general and head of the U.S. Special Operations Command, hosted a guest: Eric Schmidt, the chairman of Google.

title: Antarctica vs. Science
description: At the start of January, the same month the world marked the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica, scientists on snowmobiles were zipping across its diamantine ice, dragging a rig of metal detectors in their wake. Researchers were hoping to discover a hypothesized cache of iron-rich meteorites, the remnants of ancient asteroids and would-be planets, under the frozen wastes.

title: A Family Rallied on 2 Continents as a Loved One Fought Covid-19
description: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.

title: Grandma Rocket, the Virus and a Family Whose Love Bridged 2,500 Miles
description: When Eliana Marcela Rendn was finally able to visit her grandmother, who had spent four weeks at a Long Island hospital, a staff member met her in the lobby to ask if the 74-year-old patient had a favorite song.

title: Can Golden Boy Bring Boxing Back?
description: Oscar De La Hoya, the boxing champion turned promoter, spends a part of each day running up and down his half-mile long driveway in Pasadena, Calif., to stay in shape.

title: Relaxed Rules and Warm Weather Test States
description: Warmer weekend temperatures and fatigue over weeks of confinement lured millions of Americans outside on Saturday, adding to the pressure on city and state officials to enforce, or loosen, restrictions imposed to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Coronavirus Deaths in New York Increase Slightly, Cuomo Says
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived on Saturday to the New York City Transits Corona Maintenance Facility in Queens to deliver a sliver of bad news in the fight against the coronavirus: The states daily death toll went up slightly after a consistent decline in the past few days.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Lost $49.7 Billion in First Quarter Stung by Coronavirus
description: Not even Warren E. Buffett was spared financially from the coronavirus, as his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, reported a $49.7 billion loss in the first quarter on Saturday, reflecting the outbreaks toll on an investment portfolio that includes big stakes in major airlines and financial firms.

title: Filmmaker Who Mocked Egypts President Dies in Prison
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian filmmaker imprisoned over a music video that mocked President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi died at a maximum-security facility on Friday after two years in detention without trial, his lawyer said.

title: Put Your Children to Work
description: As noted earlier this week, I do not enjoy generating fun for my children. So I was very pleased to read our piece from Michaeleen Doucleff, an NPR correspondent who has spent years reporting on how different cultures around the world raise cooperative and generous children. In these cultures, you find a striking commonality: Mothers and fathers do not feel the need to constantly entertain and play with children, Michaeleen wrote. Instead parents give children an opportunity that many American kids do not have  to participate in adult work. How do we get our American children to behave this way? She has suggestions.

title: Houston Helicopter Crash Kills 1 Police Officer and Injures Another
description: A Houston police officer was killed and another critically injured after their helicopter crashed early Saturday morning as they were responding to a report of bodies in a bayou, the citys police chief said.

title: 41 Classic Dishes You Should Master
description: It might be time to brush up on some of the basics: Mark Bittmans simplest roast chicken, Alison Romans eggs Benedict (above), Julia Moskins classic French toast and more recipes in the collection below.

title: No More Jenga, No More Amen as Cities Learn to Live With Coronavirus
description: Worshipers at one of Seouls largest Catholic churches must refrain from singing hymns or saying amen for fear of spreading saliva. Priests sanitize their hands during communion. Holy water has been removed from the chapel.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD  For the record, I declared 2020 the Year of the Cryptic Crossword well before we got quarantined, and now there are still more reasons to show them some love.   Many of us find that our lives are moving at a slower pace, perfect for mulling and letting the problem-solving part of our brain get a chance to work with less commotion.

title: Lets (Not) Shake on It
description: Handshaking for self-protection became anachronistic long before Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nations leading infectious-disease expert, said wistfully in early April that as far as even greeting one another, we may never shake hands again. As a personal defense mechanism and for sealing deals, though, it was outdated as soon as people began openly brandishing guns and hiring lawyers to vet contracts.

title: The War Between Middle Schoolers and Their Parents Ends Now
description: Millions of American parents are now stuck at home with their middle schoolers and becoming intimately reacquainted, in far too close quarters, with the look, smell and feel of life  24/7  in the sixth, seventh and eighth grades.

title: The Father I Never Forgave
description: In the summer of 1980, I was 7 years old and crazy about the Pittsburgh Pirates. The team had won the World Series the year before, and because the Steelers won the Super Bowl in 1979 and 1980, people started calling the place City of Champions. To a kid, this was the center of the world.

title: How Do You Fight the Coronavirus Without Running Water?
description: Several weeks ago, Larry Welch and his mother, Mary Ann, contracted Covid-19 and died. In the midst of a pandemic in which one of the first lines of defense is vigorous hand washing, they were among more than two million Americans who lack running water.

title: The New Great Depression Is Coming. Will There Be a New New Deal?
description: Until very recently, Andrew Yang thought that the need for a universal basic income would be a big issue in the 2024 election, as many of the trends that I campaigned on were going to become completely clear to more and more Americans over the next four years. He was arguing, for example, that between now and then, 30 percent of our stores and malls were going to close because of Amazon.

title: Some Small Businesses That Got Aid Fear the Rules Too Much to Spend It
description: When a $192,000 loan from the federal governments small-business aid program arrived in his bank account last month, George Evageliou, the founder of a custom woodworking company, felt like one of the lucky ones.

title: Exiled Pakistani Journalist Found Dead in Sweden
description: ISLAMABAD  A Pakistani journalist forced into exile in Sweden after covering violence, crime and a simmering insurgency in his home country was found dead on Friday in a river north of Stockholm, the Swedish police said.

title: Go Ahead, Blow Out the Candles on Zoom
description: In a strange twist, a pandemic birthday party might actually be the easiest party you ever throw.

title: Votes, Deployment and Now Parenthood in the Middle of a Pandemic
description: WASHINGTON  As lawmakers gathered in the well of the House in the early hours of March 14 to vote on a sweeping coronavirus relief bill, Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, felt that the pandemic that had already begun spreading through the ranks of Congress was about to upend life as he knew it.

title: The Allegation Is Against Joe Biden, but the Burden Is on Women
description: He may not have been their first choice.

title: Peter Jonas, Innovative Opera Impresario, Is Dead at 73
description: Peter Jonas, an impresario who turned the English National Opera in London and the Bavarian State Opera in Munich into influential hotbeds of innovation, died on April 22 in Munich. He was 73.

title: Profits and Pride at Stake, the Race for a Vaccine Intensifies
description: WASHINGTON  Four months after a mysterious new virus began its deadly march around the globe, the search for a vaccine has taken on an intensity never before seen in medical research, with huge implications for public health, the world economy and politics.

title: 10 Florists Delivering Vibrant Bouquets for Mothers Day
description: Sending flowers on Mothers Day has long been a way to convey closeness despite physical distance. Now, with many people self-isolating away from their families, this small act feels especially poignant. But as businesses have closed on account of the coronavirus, and as events have been postponed or canceled, the demand for flowers has withered and growers have been forced to destroy millions of blooms. Flowers are a very low-margin, high-labor, perishable medium, and our supply chains are complex and vulnerable, explains the Manhattan-based floral designer Emily Thompson, who hopes to reopen soon.

title: Can U.S. Soccer and Its Womens Team Make Peace on Equal Pay?
