description: After a federal judge dismissed the equal pay claims of the World Cup-winning womens national team on Friday night, it was not the words in the United States Soccer Federations response that stuck out. It was the ones that werent there.

title: Afghanistan Investigating Claims Migrants Were Killed by Iranian Guards
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The foreign ministry of Afghanistan on Saturday said it was investigating claims that dozens of Afghan migrants detained in Iran were tortured by that countrys border guards and thrown into a river, where many of them drowned.

title: A 27-Year-Old Doctors Fight Against Coronavirus
description: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.

title: Joe Says It Aint So
description: WASHINGTON  One of my quarantine diversions was revisiting the first season of Mad Men, where women in the workplace were sexual playthings and where a young womans assay at writing ad copy was so unorthodox that it was, as one ad man marveled, like watching a dog play the piano.

title: Did Closing Schools Actually Help?
description: As different countries and states tentatively start reopening their economies, there seems to be no clear plan, and no clear way to figure out which of the lockdown measures made a difference in slowing the spread of Covid-19.

title: She Predicted the Coronavirus. What Does She Foresee Next?
description: I told Laurie Garrett that she might as well change her name to Cassandra. Everyone is calling her that anyway.

title: A Young Doctor, Fighting for His Life
description: Dr. Andres Maldonado normally bounded into the Emergency Department, fit and vigorous, but this time he had to be escorted in, pale and fighting for breath, with a patient bracelet on his right wrist. A nurse, seeing her colleague struggle, burst into tears.

title: How Coronavirus Made Our Church Stronger
description: In public life we spend a lot of time talking about what should be done. When it comes to who should do it, the discussion often becomes an impersonal, contentious and dehumanizing debate that reduces people to the poor or the middle class or the 1 percent. No one really likes it, but thats the way we talk about politics.

title: Balmy Weekend Presents a Challenge: New Yorkers Rushing to Parks
description: On the second day of May, New Yorkers were greeted with sunny skies and the warmest weekend so far this spring. People got up off their couch, put on their shoes, donned their face coverings, and left their cramped houses and apartments for the nearest park  desperate for fresh air and a little exercise.

title: We Had to Do Something: Trying to Prevent Massive Food Waste
description: While millions of Americans are worried about having enough to eat and lines at food banks grow, farmers have been plowing under vegetable fields, dumping milk and smashing eggs that cannot be sold because the coronavirus pandemic has shut down restaurants, hotels and schools.

title: Pences Virus Role Enhances His Profile While Showing Limits of His Influence
description: WASHINGTON  The paradox of Vice President Mike Pence getting in trouble for failing to wear a mask is that perhaps no member of the Trump administration is more shrouded behind an invisible one of his own making.

title: Kansas Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results from the Kansas presidential primary election.

title: Shifting Sounds
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  This is probably a celebrity puzzle for a lot of word lovers out there; Ben Zimmer is a prolific writer on language, formerly at the Times, currently at The Wall Street Journal and The Atlantic. According to Will Shortzs print introduction, Mr. Zimmer and Brendan Emmett Quigley met about 12 years ago while working on the Visual Thesaurus. (Mr. Zimmer had a column there as well, Word Routes, which we have cited before in Wordplay.) This grid is a collaboration from start to finish, a fusion of two maven brains on a molecular level, if you will.

title: Hamilton Bohannon, Driving Disco Drummer, Dies at 78
description: Hamilton Bohannon, a drummer whose disco records propelled people onto dance floors in the 1970s and 80s, and then lived on as popular samples for major hip-hop artists, died on April 24 at his home in Atlanta. He was 78.

title: Tony Allen, Drummer Who Created the Beat of Afrobeat, Dies at 79
description: Tony Allen, the drummer who created the steadfast, subtle beat of the Nigerian protest funk known as Afrobeat, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 79.

title: Was That a Cough? Going Back to the Movies in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO  It happened early inside the cool, darkened cineplex, before Vin Diesel even had a chance to turn superhuman, as people sat munching popcorn and sipping sodas in their plush recliner seats.

title: Colorado Paramedic Who Came to Help New York Dies From Covid-19
description: On the same day that New York Citys 911 dispatchers fielded a volume of calls not seen since the Sept. 11 attacks, Paul Cary, a paramedic, set out for the nearly 1,800-mile drive from Denver to New York City in an ambulance.

title: N.F.L. Players Union Will Review Disability Benefits
description: The N.F.L. Players Association announced plans to review provisions in the collective bargaining agreement ratified in March that are set to take away tens of thousands of dollars in benefits from permanently disabled former players.

title: Hotel Group Will Return Tens of Millions in Small Business Loans
description: One of the biggest beneficiaries of the governments small business lending program said on Saturday that its companies will return at least $70 million in loans received through the Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Antivaccination Activists Are Growing Force at Virus Protests
description: The protest on Friday in Sacramento urging Californias governor to reopen the state resembled the rallies that have appeared elsewhere in the country, with crowds flocking to the State Capitol, pressing leaders to undo restrictions on businesses and daily life.

title: Sam Lloyd, Scrubs Actor, Dies at 56
description: Sam Lloyd, a longtime television and film actor who appeared in the television shows Scrubs and Desperate Housewives, died on Thursday at the Barlow Respiratory Hospital  in Los Angeles. He was 56.

title: North and South Korea Exchange Gunfire Across Demilitarized Zone
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Gunshots fired from North Korea struck a guard post in South Korea on Sunday inside the Demilitarized Zone separating the two countries, and South Korean soldiers fired back, the Souths military said.

title: Pompeo Blames Wuhan Lab for Coronavirus As Backlash Against China Grows
description: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

title: Quotation of the Day: As Last refuge for Homeless, Subway Is Risk
description: At the end of the day, we understand that this is a very dangerous situation people are going through. But before this, homeless people were already going through a dangerous situation.

title: George W. Bush Calls for End to Pandemic Partisanship
description: WASHINGTON  Former President George W. Bush called on Americans on Saturday to put aside partisan differences, heed the guidance of medical professionals and show empathy for those stricken by the coronavirus and the resulting economic devastation.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: Billions and Westworld
description: BILLIONS 9 p.m. on Showtime. Billions, a critics darling about power politics and high finance in New York, returns just in time to fill the Homeland-shaped void in Showtimes schedule. Last seasons dtente between the federal government watchdog Chuck (Paul Giamatti) and the hedge-fund king Axe (Damian Lewis) did not last long. In Season 5, the pair are yet again determined to take each other down, while new foes complicate matters. Julianna Margulies (The Good Wife) and Corey Stoll (House of Cards) join the show as recurring cast members. She plays a professor and author on sex and relationships; he takes the role of a social impact pioneer that challenges Axes power. And as Chuck butts heads with a dogged district attorney (Roma Maffia), his increasingly independent wife, Wendy (Maggie Siff), forges unexpected alliances.

title: As I Came Up the Stairs to Street Level, I Spied a Shining Lincoln Head
description: Dear Diary:

title: One Bright Thing: Reader Edition
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: As Putin Dallies, Russias Small Businesses Are Withering Away
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Two weeks into the coronavirus lockdown, Aleksandr B. Zatulivetrov, a Russian businessman, had had enough.

title: Andy Warhol, Superstar
description: WARHOL

title: Concert for One: I.C.U. Doctor Brings Classical Music to Coronavirus Patients
description: Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19  live classical music concerts.

title: The Coronavirus Becomes a Battle Cry for U.S. Extremists
description: Americas extremists are attempting to turn the coronavirus pandemic into a potent recruiting tool both in the deep corners of the internet and on the streets of state capitals by twisting the public health crisis to bolster their white supremacist, anti-government agenda.

title: These Are the Bedside Concerts Comforting Virus Patients
description: In chaotic emergency rooms and intensive care units around New York City, coronavirus patients struggle to survive in isolation, with masked doctors and nurses keeping their distance and family visits barred. Alarms, monitors and overhead announcements blare incessantly.

title: One of Amazons Most Powerful Critics Lives in Its Backyard
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Pramila Jayapal was walking a fine line when she arrived at Amazons Seattle headquarters on a chilly day last October to meet with some of the companys top executives.

title: Percival Everett Has a Book or Three Coming Out
description: Once youve finished Telephone, the latest book by Percival Everett, you may be talking about it with another reader and finding that you disagree on what happened.

title: Trump Nominee Is Among Judges Opposed to Banning Membership in Conservative Group
description: As the Senate this week considers elevating a politically connected judge to an influential federal appeals court, the judge has stepped into a fierce ideological debate about a legal group shaping President Trumps rightward overhaul of the judiciary.

title: I Bought a Car From Northern Italy as the Pandemic Took Hold
description: Imagine what it would have been like to unwittingly arrange to buy an oxcart in Pompeii on or about the 23rd of August, 79 A.D.  Im the 21st-century version of that guy.

title: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
description: The coronavirus has killed so many people in Iran that the country has resorted to mass burials, but in neighboring Iraq, the body count is fewer than 100.

title: Reopening, Vaccine, Spring Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Maintenance Tips for a Virus-Idled Car
description: Every January during my early teenage years, my parents would fly to Miami to spend about six weeks in the sun. Theyd leave the car  usually a Pontiac, one time a Cadillac  in our driveway in Boston, along with some instructions.

title: My Co-Anchor Is Pawing at the Door: Back to You in the Studio
description: Scott Connell, a Missouri weatherman, was trying to record a tease last month, but Maple, his Cavalier King Charles spaniel, had other plans.

title: Global Backlash Builds Against China Over Coronavirus
description: BRUSSELS  Australia has called for an inquiry into the origin of the virus. Germany and Britain are hesitating anew about inviting in the Chinese tech giant Huawei. President Trump has blamed China for the contagion and is seeking to punish it. Some governments want to sue Beijing for damages and reparations.

title: The Week in Business: Whos Ready to Go Shopping?
description: Limping businesses are preparing to reopen across the country, and some Americans are raring to get out of the house. Is this the beginning of the economys recovery or will it lead to a resurgence of coronavirus infections? Heres the business news you need to know for the week ahead.

title: Kashmir Gun Battle Kills at Least 7
description: NEW DELHI  A gun battle between the Indian Army and militants in Kashmir left at least seven people dead, Indian officials said on Sunday, and the violence threatened to heighten tensions in the disputed region.

title: Trump Says U.S. Death Toll Could Reach 100,000
description: This briefing has ended. Follow the latest updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.

title: The Sunday Read: Alone at Sea
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Seven States to Coordinate on Amassing Medical Equipment to Fight Coronavirus
description: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Mondays live coverage.]

title: Corrections: May 3, 2020
description: An article on Page 6 about the filmmaker Alice Wu misstates the given name of her firefighter friend. It is CJ, not TJ.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. What are we, a year into this now? Stuck at home, out of work, too much work, low on funds, plenty money but worried all the same? Its getting to the point where the beautiful days are the hardest, when itd be great to be out in the world, cruising the boardwalk on a rusty bike, hiking a tree line near the Labrador border, laughing at the sunshine in a crowded Trafalgar Square.

title: Ronan ORahilly, Pioneer of Pirate Radio, Is Dead at 79
description: It was on the Saturday before Easter 1964 that Radio Caroline sent out its opening salvo, the Rolling Stones cover of Buddy Hollys Not Fade Away, from a rehabilitated Dutch ferry anchored three miles off the coast of England. For British teenagers, used to a bland diet of childrens programs, 1950s ballads and farm news on the BBC  also known by the nickname Auntie  it was a revelation.

title: Tracing and Sampling to Monitor Covid-19
description: To the Editor:

title: Im Staying Put in New York. Its Still Glorious.
description: To the Editor:

title: Fly Him to the Moon. Or at Least, Fly Him Home.
description: Ryan Driscoll is the sort of celebrity unique to luxury cruise lines. A singer and entertainer, dapper and dandy, he plays the big room at night, crooning like Sinatra and Darin. He spends days schmoozing by the pool and strolling the decks, handing out smiles and leaving behind swoons. He belts out arias at sunset. If you are lucky, he is assigned to your table for dinner.

title: Beiruts Nightlife Survived Civil War. Can It Withstand Pandemic?
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  When the disruptive threat of the coronavirus first came for Beirut, I was, appropriately enough, in a local bar.

title: Italians Find Promise of Antibodies Remains Elusive, for Now
description: ROME  Cooped up, stir crazy and desperate for their lives back, many Europeans and Americans have seized on antibodies and their promise of potential immunity to the coronavirus as the golden ticket to reopen societies and economies.

title: Murder Hornets vs. Honeybees: A Swarm of Bees Can Cook Invaders Alive
description: SEATTLE  When a pack of Asian giant hornets targets a hive of honeybees for slaughter, the carnage can be swift.

title: Helping Black Artists, But at What Price?
description: For many African-American artists looking for gallery representation in the 1980s, George NNamdi was the only game in town. One of the few black art dealers, then and now, Mr. NNamdi opened his first gallery in Detroit in 1981 and focused on black artists working in abstraction. They had been largely ignored by the mainstream art world and marginalized, as well, within black communities that expected their artists to make socially and politically oriented work.

title: On Subways as Riders Return: Odes to Their Resilience
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will use many tools in coming weeks in its effort to restore faith in a subway system that has been seen as a vector for infection.

title: Why Bidens Choice of Running Mate Has Momentous Implications
description: WASHINGTON  For decades the vice-presidential selection process has had an air of cloak-and-dagger to it. The partys nominees would say little about their thinking, the would-be running mates would reveal even less, and an elaborate game of subterfuge would unfold that mostly captivated political insiders and usually had little bearing on the election.

title: Therapists and Patients Find Common Ground: Virus-Fueled Anxiety
description: On a good day, New York City is awash in its neuroses, a tightly wound place where a wide assortment of sky-scraping anxieties can build to an almost comic crescendo.

title: Man Camped on Disney World Island at Shuttered Park, Police Say
description: It had the makings of an adventure straight from Disneys Swiss Family Robinson  being on an uninhabited island and living off the land.

title: Dominos Is Raking in Money. What About Its Employees?
description: Some Dominos workers finally got Covid-19 protections, but it took an outbreak and a strike.

title: Dominos Is Raking in Money. What About Its Employees?
description: Some workers, particularly Latino ones, have never had the luxury of sheltering in place during the coronavirus outbreak. The countrys millions of fast food employees cant continue to ensure pizzas, pasta and salads make it to their destinations, guaranteeing that both their customers and their families are fed, by working from home. These essential workers  most making minimum wage without health benefits  have to fight for basic safeguards from the virus while their employers rake in profits.

title: Flattening the Truth on Coronavirus
description: The People (P): What is happening?

title: Democrats, Its Time to Consider a Plan B
description: If youre lucky when you report your sexual assault, youll become known as a person who was sexually assaulted. If youre unlucky, youll become known as a person who lied about being sexually assaulted.

title: President Trump, I Am Not Your Enemy. I Am a Doctor.
description: BOSTON  On April 20, I had just gotten home from a particularly difficult 14-hour shift when I saw President Trumps tweet about closing the United States border to immigrants. He said that he was acting as a response to the coronavirus pandemic and to protect the jobs of American citizens. This was alarming news to me, especially since some of the reporting on the announcement suggested that visas for highly skilled workers could also be banned. As a foreign-born doctor on a work visa, I was very worried about how this would impact my ability to remain in the country.

title: The Coronavirus Is Killing Too Many Nursing Home Residents
description: BRISTOL, Conn.  My family has owned an assisted living home in this town for over 44 years. Both of my grandmothers have lived in it, and my mother might soon need its care. As much as I admired my parents, I did not think I would someday lead it. I went to Yale, served three tours in Iraq as a Marine infantry officer and earned a Ph.D. in political science from Harvard. I had planned to turn my dissertation into a book.

title: More Readers, Fewer Ads: Britains Local Newspapers Are Struggling
description: LONDON  Normally, when Michael Purton has a question for one of his reporters about a story, he shouts it across the newsroom. An answer usually follows within a few seconds.

title: A Thousand Goodbyes for McCarter Theaters Emily Mann
description: Had this been a normal spring, Emily Mann would have wrapped up her three decades as artistic director of McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., in the traditional way, with colleagues and patrons gathered under a tent to toast her at a gala. Instead, on Saturday night, they gave her a virtual tribute on Zoom, which she watched, teary-eyed, from her living room.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A backlash is building against China for its initial mishandling of the coronavirus outbreak, which has grown into a global crisis.

title: Face Masks and Crowd Control: The Race to Make Your Subway Ride Safer
description: Businesses in New York City will be asked to change workers schedules to reduce rush-hour density on the subway. A new squad of guards will patrol stations, reporting overcrowding to supervisors and directing riders to emptier train cars. Brightly colored markers will be added to encourage riders to keep a distance from one another on platforms, following the advice of transit agencies in China, Singapore and Britain.

title: Warren Buffetts Optimistic? Pessimistic? No, Realistic
description: You could always count on the folksy and cheery optimism of Warren Buffett.

title: Venezuelan Officials Claim to Have Stopped an Armed Incursion
description: CARACAS  The Venezuelan government said security forces foiled an armed incursion Sunday morning near the capital, Caracas, killing eight men and capturing the remaining two.

title: Disruptions Add to Risks for Athletes With Eating Disorders
description: On a recent weekend, feeling bored and a little out of sorts, the tennis player Madison Keys whipped up a batch of chocolate chip cookies at her home in Orlando, Fla.

title: Principals Find Novel Ways to Honor Seniors During Shutdown
description: With school closed and graduation canceled, the principal of a high school in suburban Dallas set out on April 17 with his wife, a bag of Snickers bars and a mission: visiting each of the 612 seniors at their homes.

title: Virus Pushes a Staid Supreme Court Into Revolutionary Changes
description: WASHINGTON  A few months ago, a coalition of news organizations asked the Supreme Court to allow live audio coverage of major arguments on gay rights and immigration. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. rejected the request within hours, in keeping with longstanding practice at an institution that almost never departs from tradition.

title: Before Covid-19, Trump Aide Sought to Use Disease to Close Borders
description: From the early days of the Trump administration, Stephen Miller, the presidents chief adviser on immigration, has repeatedly tried to use an obscure law designed to protect the nation from diseases overseas as a way to tighten the borders.

title: Like Neon and Argon
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Happy Monday, everyone! Emily Carroll returns with a fun puzzle for us all to solve from our individual nests.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | May 4, 2020
description: Students

title: Pompeo Ties Coronavirus to China Lab, Despite Spy Agencies Uncertainty
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Sunday backed President Trumps assertion that the coronavirus originated in a research laboratory in Wuhan, China, though the nations intelligence agencies say they have reached no conclusion on the issue.

title: J. Crew Files for Bankruptcy in Viruss First Big Retail Casualty
description: J. Crew, the mass-market clothing company whose preppy-with-a-twist products were worn by Michelle Obama and appeared at New York Fashion Week, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday. It is the first major retailer to fall during the coronavirus pandemic, though other big industry names including Neiman Marcus and J.C. Penney are also struggling with the toll of mass shutdowns.

title: A New Companion for Your Morning
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: The Pandemic Isnt Changing Everything
description: A crisis as life-altering as the coronavirus pandemic naturally inspires speculation about how it will change everything. But it is worth recalling that a far deadlier predecessor, the Spanish Flu, killed 50 million to 100 million people between 1918 and 1920, and was followed by the Roaring 20s. So did it change anything?

title: What One Doctors Suicide Taught Us
description: Just over a month ago, I got a call at 10:30 at night from a doctor friend who works in one of the busiest emergency rooms in New York City. Shed just returned from a brutal shift, a miserable slog of impossible intubations and fruitless C.P.R. One patient, more or less her age, died just minutes after shed placed him on a ventilator. She was so stunned she burst into tears.

title: Blame the Justice Department for Andrea Circle Bears Death
description: Andrea Circle Bear of the Cheyenne River Sioux will never get to watch her baby grow up. She died more than three weeks after having an emergency C-section while on a ventilator, a victim of the coronavirus and a cruel justice system that saw fit to send a woman eight and a half months pregnant to a crowded federal womens prison in Fort Worth. She had received a two-year sentence on a minor, nonviolent drug charge. She had just turned 30.

title: Trump Foresees Virus Death Toll as High as 100,000 in the United States
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump predicted on Sunday night that the death toll from the coronavirus pandemic ravaging the country may reach as high as 100,000 in the United States, twice as many as he had forecast just two weeks ago, even as he pressed states to reopen the shuttered economy.

title: Leaders Are Crying on the Job. Maybe Thats a Good Thing.
description: Charlie Baker, the Republican governor of Massachusetts, broke down while speaking about the death of his best friends mother.

title: Masks Become a Flash Point in the Virus Culture Wars
description: ATLANTA  As the nation edges away from lockdown and people once again share public spaces in the middle of a pandemic, wearing a face mask  or refusing to  has become a flash point in a moment when civic rules are being rewritten, seemingly on the fly.

title: How a New Breed of Union Activists Is Changing the Rules (and Newsrooms)
description: As the coronavirus crisis wreaked havoc in the news business last month, the newly installed president of the most prominent journalists union in the country, the NewsGuild, crossed a line that once seemed unimaginable: He asked the government for money.

title: Covid-19s Race and Class Warfare
description: People  mostly white, sometimes armed, occasionally carrying Confederate flags or hoisting placards emblazoned with a Nazi slogan from the Holocaust  have been loudly protesting to push their state governments to reopen business and spaces before enough progress has been made to contain the coronavirus. This is yet another illustration of the race and class divide this pandemic has illuminated in this country.

title: Billions Season 5 Premiere Recap: Chopping Heads
description: Move over, Bobby Axelrod: Youre not the only pugnacious redhead in Axe Caps hallowed halls anymore.

title: Rap Soundtracks the Michael Jordan Doc. The N.B.A. Wasnt Always That Way.
description: How one experiences The Last Dance, ESPNs 10-part documentary series about Michael Jordans final season with the Chicago Bulls, depends largely on the viewers relationship with the man commonly regarded as the most famous  if not best  player to professionally dribble a basketball.

title: Quotation of the Day: For New Yorks Therapists, Steering Relentless Waves of External and Internal Angst
description: We are doing everything and anything to help each other and our patients to get through this. Sometimes, thats crying together.

title: Corrections: May 4, 2020
description: Because of a production error, a cover article on Saturday about the effects of the coronavirus on the production of oil in the Permian Basin included columns of type that were out of order.

title: Coronavirus, Italy, China: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: China Quiets Talk of Coronavirus Cover-Up in Wuhan
Stocks Waver as China Tensions Climb
description: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest stock market developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

title: The U.K. Needs a Real Government, Not Boris Johnsons Puppet Cabinet
description: LONDON  On the day a paler, thinner, notably less boisterous Boris Johnson returned to work after his near-death coronavirus experience, a Tory member of Parliament tweeted a GIF of a magnificent lion perched on a mountaintop, his mane blowing in the wind. Good to see @BorisJohnson back at the helm! he wrote.

title: Whats on TV Monday: My Brilliant Friend and Cane River
description: MY BRILLIANT FRIEND 10 p.m. on HBO. Elena and Lila began their lives in the same poor neighborhood of Naples but over the course of two seasons of television their paths have diverged significantly. Elena (Margherita Mazzucco) has put some distance between herself and her humble origins by successfully pursuing education while Lila (Gaia Girace), despite her intelligence and will, remains largely stuck. The distance between the two has complicated but not diminished their deep connection. This season they traveled together to the island of Ischia for vacation. The time away was supposed to help Lila relax enough to get pregnant by her husband but during the sojourn she connected with Nino, a young man that Elena was drawn to first. After the summer, Elena departed Naples for university and Lila eventually returned to her husband.

title: Word + Quiz: creche
Run 100 Miles, 100 Times, in 100 Weeks. Now in a Brooklyn Apartment.
description: The first time Michael Ortiz ran 100 miles inside his 960-square-foot Brooklyn apartment was the hardest. He laid out a roughly rectangular 40-foot cardboard track around the rugs on his living room floor and ran 13,200 laps on it. To save his knees from so many turns, Ortiz stopped every mile and reversed direction. It wasnt really running, he said. It was more like fast shuffling.

title: Many N.B.A. Stars Lack Home Court Advantage: Basketball Hoops
description: When he kept getting the same downbeat message from various Miami Heat teammates about their long spell of inactivity, Jimmy Butler knew he had to do something.

title: The Pandemic May Mean the End of the Open-Floor Office
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The modern corporate office is renowned for open, collaborative work spaces, in-house coffee bars and standing desks with room for two giant computer monitors.

title: 3 Hospital Workers Gave Out Masks. Weeks Later, They All Were Dead.
description: They did not treat patients, but Wayne Edwards, Derik Braswell and Priscilla Carrow held some of the most vital jobs at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens.

title: Lesson of the Day: Murder Hornets in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet
description: Featured Article: Murder Hornets in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet by Mike Baker

title: What Do the Objects in Your Home Say About You?
description: What could someone learn about you by visiting your home  or by seeing it in the background of a Zoom meeting or video call? Choose three objects and explain what each says about you.

title: Whats Scaring the Pediatricians
description: Pediatric patients are not the sickest group right now, or the group most in danger.

title: Jane Brodys Guide to Life in Lockdown
description: Fear not, dear reader. Im not about to tell you how much fun Im having sheltering under the umbrella of Covid limitations, wondering whether the next unmasked person who passes too close to me on the street or in a store will transmit a deadly virus. But I hope to offer some useful survival tips and help you realize that however distressed you may feel, you are neither abnormal nor alone.

title: How Not to Be a Tiger King
description: NASHVILLE  Once in the bluest of blue moons, the zeitgeist produces a cultural phenomenon so bizarre and so universally discussed as to be nearly inescapable. This spring, in the spirit of pet rocks, mood rings and streaking, Netflix launched Tiger King, a documentary series that landed online at the very moment a pandemic moved our lives online, too.

title: Coronavirus and the Sweden Myth
description: For countries battling the coronavirus pandemic, Sweden sets a seductive example. While the worlds biggest economies have shut down, one small, well-governed Scandinavian country has allowed most businesses to stay open. The strategy apparently relies on herd immunity, in which a critical mass of infection occurs in lower-risk populations that ultimately thwarts transmission.

title: We Should Never Have to Vote in Person Again
description: As the coronavirus continues to spread throughout the country, there are growing concerns about whether in-person voting can be conducted safely in the months ahead, including for the November presidential election. A huge expansion of mail voting is one way to ensure that participating in democracy wont undermine public health.

title: What We Lose When We Go From the Classroom to Zoom
description: When life was normal, my students and I gathered in classrooms.

title: Jerry Seinfeld Is Making Peace With Nothing: Hes Post-Show Business
description: Many of us have been wondering lately what Jerry Seinfeld, the sitcom character, would be doing in this current era of home quarantines and social distancing: how his extreme fastidiousness, self-centeredness and constant scrutiny of quotidian details (not to mention the hyperbolic traits of his fictional friends and neighbors) would be stretched to hilarious extremes in an environment of isolation and anxiety.

title: A Moment of Calm With Jewel, and More Live Events This Week
description: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern). You can find the full calendar here.

title: Four Students Were Killed in Ohio. America Was Never the Same.
description: On Friday, May 1, 1970, just after noon, about 300 students at Kent State University, outside Cleveland, gathered in the grassy campus Commons to protest President Nixons expansion of the Vietnam War into Cambodia. As part of the protest, they buried a copy of the Constitution, a symbol of their outrage that Congress had never formally declared war on Vietnam or Cambodia, and they announced another rally, set for May 4.

title: Shopping for Desk Organizers
description: When youre working from home, the goal should be to create an environment thats positive and upbeat, said Kelly Hoppen, a London-based interior designer.

title: What Joe Biden Needs to Do to Beat Trump
description: Joe Bidens most memorable moments on the campaign trail have come through spontaneous, intensely moving encounters with people who, like Mr. Biden, have endured searing struggle and loss. His authentic sense of empathy is a quality uniquely suited to this agonizing moment.

title: How Bailout Backlash and Moral Hazard Outrage Could Endanger the Economy
description: The United States economy is in free fall, with tens of millions of people unemployed and countless businesses at risk of collapse. Congress has already allocated nearly $3 trillion to contain the crisis, and it is widely understood that it will need to do more.

title: In the Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, We Must Go Big. Really, Really Big.
description: The Covid-19 virus has killed over 200,000 people, overwhelmed health systems and confined billions of people in their homes. Large sections of the world economy have been locked down.

title: For A.O.C., Existential Crises as Her District Becomes the Coronavirus Epicenter
description: The dash to overnight millennial celebrity can take abrupt detours.

title: Smash a Coronavirus Piata. Youll Feel Better.
description: If you cannot join, beat. Such is the resolve of creative people bashing piatas to defeat a pandemic (or at least, excise some of their feelings about it).

title: Mondays Livestreaming Events: A Met Gala Celebration and a Nora Ephron Play
description: Here are a few of the best events happening on Monday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern Daylight).

title: Caught Between Worlds? For Elizabeth Acevedo, Its a Familiar Feeling
description: Two months after 9/11, an American Airlines flight bound for the Dominican Republic crashed in Queens, N.Y. It was largely overshadowed by the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack, but it shook New York Citys close-knit Dominican community. All 260 people on board were killed, most of them Dominican, and everyone seemed to know someone who was grieving.

title: 15 Funerals a Day: The Pace of Death Stuns Brooklyn Muslims
description: All day long, wood coffins are carried in and out of Al-Rayaan Muslim Funeral Services in Brooklyn. What is meant to be a peaceful, reflective moment for grieving families has given way to a chaotic rhythm. Workers climb into a refrigerated truck and carefully carry the dead into the funeral home for a prayer, then back out to be transported to their final resting place.

title: I Spent a Weekend Bingeing Airbnbs Virtual Experiences. Was it Worth It?
description: In the Great Lockdown, two-way video has become our primary social channel. Meetings, parties, concerts, music lessons, exercise classes: Any interactions that can be adapted to a Zoom video call, have been. Surely theres nothing left to be Zoomified.

title: The Cloud Forming Over Americas Spies
description: The appointment in February of Richard Grenell, a political operative and Donald Trump loyalist, as acting director of national intelligence after the renomination of former Congressman John Ratcliffe to permanently fill the position once he is confirmed, has many current and former intelligence professionals deeply concerned.

title: Both Parties Wonder: How Much Do Conventions Even Matter Anymore?
description: Political conventions have been a balloons-and-bunting mainstay of American campaigns since the Republican Party gathered in Baltimore to nominate Henry Clay for president in 1831. But this year, they may join the list of crowded events  concerts, baseball games, movies and Broadway shows  forced off the stage because of the coronavirus.

title: Why Liberal Californians Dont Want to Go Back to Normal
description: LOS ANGELES  Housing for those who are homeless. Criminal justice reform. Addressing the digital divide for schoolchildren in rural areas.

title: In Sydney, the Magic Hour Means Noise. Its Heavenly to Hear.
description: SYDNEY, Australia  At night, the crickets make my street sound like the wilderness. In the morning, I hear the birds chirping at top volume from sun up until deep into what used to be rush hour.

title: A Family Business Survived One Pandemic. Its Determined to Do It Again.
description: By the time Robert L. Stevenson gathered his work force at Eastman Machine in Buffalo in mid-March, businesses nationwide were shutting down. But Eastman, which makes fabric-cutting machines, has been in family hands for four generations, and Mr. Stevenson wasnt about to turn off the lights.

title: For Walt Disney Co., a Stricken Empire
description: LOS ANGELES  It was once a prospering kingdom, the envy of all the land. But in crept an invisible menace.

title: Chinas Coronavirus Vaccine Drive Empowers a Troubled Industry
description: China wants to beat the world in the race to find a coronavirus vaccine  and, by some measures, it is doing just that.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Models Project Sharp Rise in Deaths as States Reopen
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: One Meat Plant. One Thousand Infections.
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Working From Home, Celebrities Grapple With Revealing Too Much
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda seems to be everywhere these days: riffing on the term OK, Boomer for Conan OBrien on Conan; belting out Hamilton ballads for Jimmy Fallon on The Tonight Show; even singing Old McDonald Had a Farm for Elmo and Friends on a special Covid-19-focused Sesame Street.

title: Westworld and Devs Asked Big Questions. A Physicist Responds.
description: After weve made a decision, to stay home rather than go to a dinner party, say, or to profess our love to someone, we ruminate over what we imagine as equally plausible alternative outcomes. Would we be happier if we had decided to go to the party? Would we regret not having shared how we feel?

title: Coronavirus, Murder Hornets, Star Wars Day: Your Monday Briefing
description: Washington, D.C., has become one of the new hot spots for the coronavirus.

title: Warren Buffett Isnt Buying Anything
description: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

title: On Politics: Biden Speaks on an Allegation
description: President Trump at the White House on Sunday after spending a few days at Camp David.

title: New York Looks Toward Restarting; New Jersey Will Keep Schools Closed
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday provided new details about the process that New York plans to follow for reopening as the coronavirus continues to decline in the state.

title: How Much Do You Know About Cuba?
description: Can you find Cuba on a map? What else do you know about this Caribbean nation with a population of about 11.3 million people?

title: Westworld Season 3 Finale Recap: Choosing Beauty
description: The end of David Finchers 1999 provocation Fight Club and the end of this weeks Season 3 finale of Westworld are essentially the same moment, one mapped onto the other like a Dolores pearl dropped into another hosts body. After a revolution deliberately premised on bringing anarchy to a well-ordered, antiseptic world, a man and a woman can only watch helplessly as the bombs detonate in high rises and chaos engulfs the city.

title: What You Get for $1.6 Million in California
description: A condominium in a Victorian in San Francisco, a Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1863 home in Mendocino.

title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: This house, which now contains two residential units, was built in 1900 and recently renovated by Jeff Schlarb Design Studio. (Mr. Schlarbs studio occupies the buildings ground-floor commercial space.) It is in the Presidio Heights neighborhood, within walking distance of well-known restaurants, the Sacramento Street Shopping District, known for its concentration of high-end design stores, and the Laurel Heights campus of the University of California, San Francisco. The Presidio, an 18th-century Spanish fort and the beloved outdoor space that surrounds it, is four blocks away.

title: Will Smoke From Controlled Burns Hurt Covid-19 Patients?
description: Good morning.

title: Too Cold for an Oil Cut? Russias Move Reveals a Long-Running Bluff
description: MOSCOW  For most of the post-Soviet period, energy officials in Russia have resisted OPEC entreaties to participate in production cuts to help prop up oil prices, arguing that doing so was impossible because of the countrys cold climate.

title: Make That 101: Cunningham Centennial Moves Online
description: Last year, dance companies around the world celebrated the centennial of Merce Cunninghams birth by performing some of his vast repertory. Now, over the next few months, more than a dozen of those performances will be viewable online, the Cunningham Trust announced today.

title: J. Crew Didnt Need to Live Forever
description: Anyone wondering how J. Crews fashion fairy tale came to such a crashing halt this week, as the company became the first retailer to declare Chapter 11 bankruptcy during the new coronavirus pandemic, need look no further than its own home page. Featuring an attractive cast of windswept young men and women in various nautical stripes and florals on a sailboat off the coast of some New England town, it declares: Blue skies ahead

title: Become an Indoor Plant Parent
description: Whether you want to grow a single trailing vine, a luscious leafy monstera, or some herbs, fruits or vegetables that you can use in your spring and summer cooking, this is the perfect time to get into indoor planting. Even if you dont have a green thumb.

title: F.D.A. Orders Companies to Submit Antibody Test Data
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Monday that companies selling coronavirus antibody tests must submit data proving accuracy within the next 10 days or face removal from the market.

title: Your New Favorite Beans
description: Good morning. It is the 125th day of the year, and youd be forgiven for believing that youve spent the bulk of them inside this year, or the bulk of them at work, or both, or that youve been out of work that long, or that its possible time itself has become moot, a clock spinning without measure.

title: Social Distancing Informants Have Their Eyes on You
description: Kevin Rusch was at home on a recent Sunday evening scrolling through Facebook when he saw a photo that shocked him: A man with an American flag bandanna wrapped around his head stood at a rally demanding Wisconsin lift orders that had shuttered schools and businesses.

title: Stephenie Meyer to Publish a New Twilight Book, Midnight Sun
description: Fans of Edward Cullen, the brooding vampire hero from Stephenie Meyers best-selling Twilight series, will have something fresh to bite into this summer.

title: Don Shula, N.F.L. Coach Who Won, and Won, and Won, Dies at 90
description: Don Shula, who won more games than any head coach in National Football League history, led the Miami Dolphins to the leagues only perfect season and helped usher pro football into its modern era, died on Monday in Florida. He was 90.

title: The Essential Stephen King
description: If youve never read his books, heres where to start.

title: What the Heck Is That?
description: An OLLA is a ceramic jar, often unglazed, used for cooking stews or soups, for the storage of water or dry foods, or for other purposes like garden irrigation. The Spanish word translates to cooking pot.

title: Coronavirus Survivors Want Answers, and China Is Silencing Them
description: The text messages to the Chinese activist streamed in from ordinary Wuhan residents, making the same extraordinary request: Help me sue the Chinese government. One said his mother had died from the coronavirus after being turned away from multiple hospitals. Another said her father-in-law had died in quarantine.

title: Fire Up Your Laptop: A Curated Guide to Theater Now Online
description: When Broadway closed on March 12, it was only the tip of the iceberg: live theater has since suspended operations around the country.

title: Supreme Court Hears First Arguments via Phone
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. played traffic cop. Justice Clarence Thomas asked his first questions in more than a year. Justice Sonia Sotomayor disappeared for a few moments, apparently having failed to unmute her phone.

title: As World Comes to Halt Amid Pandemic, So Do Migrants
description: MEXICO CITY  A migrant shelter in southern Mexico called La 72 has for years been a popular way station for those traveling from Central America to the United States. Last year it received a record number of visitors, sometimes sheltering more than 2,000 a month.

title: If You Have Five Simple Ingredients, You Have This Dutch Baby
description: The upside of feeling like weekends no longer exist is that, by the same logic, neither do Monday mornings. Which means that making a Dutch baby (also called a German pancake) for breakfast on a weekday is a perfectly reasonable thing to do. Advisable, even.

title: Sewer Cleaners Wanted in Pakistan: Only Christians Need Apply.
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Before Jamshed Eric plunges deep below Karachis streets to clean out clogged sewers with his bare hands, he says a little prayer to Jesus to keep him safe.

title: How Will We Buy Our Perfume Now?
description: The way fragrance is introduced, advertised and sold to the world hasnt changed in nearly a century. No. 5, a seductive scent for the modern woman introduced by Coco Chanel in the 1920s, is marketed similarly to Tom Fords Black Orchid, a modern and alluring potion that came out in 2006. Both designers fragrances depend on an in-store experience that conjures these ideas and feelings through smell, somehow enticing people to spend over $100 on a bottle of scented water.

title: An Amazon Vice President Quit Over Firings of Employees Who Protested
description: A prominent engineer and vice president of Amazons cloud computing arm said on Monday that he had quit in dismay over the recent firings of workers who had raised questions about workplace safety during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: New Mexico Invokes Riot Law to Control Virus Near Navajo Nation
description: GALLUP, N.M.  All the roads into this city on the edge of the Navajo Nation are closed. The soldiers at the checkpoints have their orders: Outsiders must turn around and drive away.

title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Earns a Second No. 1 Album in 7 Months
description: Back in October, YoungBoy Never Broke Again, a 20-year-old Louisiana rapper with a big following on YouTube, topped the Billboard album chart for the first time. Now, just seven months later  and still at age 20  he is back with another No. 1 release, even though his numbers have slipped.

title: Eta Aquarids: Watch Halleys Comets Meteor Shower Peak in Night Skies
description: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if youre lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.

title: Dr. Richard Friedman, Who Debunked Homosexuality Myth, Dies at 79
description: In the 1980s, when marriage and adopting children seemed impossible dreams for gay men, the psychoanalyst Richard C. Friedman became their champion.

title: A Swiss Fitness Movement From the 1970s Comes Back Into Vogue
description: ZURICH  When the Covid-19 pandemic forced gyms in Switzerland to close, Beat Schlatter looked for a way to replace his five weekly training sessions.

title: Marvel Comic Books Are Returning to Stores Later in May
description: It will still be several months before the superheroes of the Marvel Cinematic Universe return to theaters in new adventures, but Marvel Entertainment, the publishing home of Iron Man, Captain America and the Hulk, is preparing to bring its characters back to comic books.

title: When Tech Helps the Vulnerable
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Body of Fifth Amish Child Is Found After Buggy Accident
description: An Amish family was holding a funeral service on Saturday for four of their children who died in a buggy accident in northeastern Kentucky when authorities arrived with news: The body of a fifth child in the accident, missing for days, had just been found.

title: The Bang on a Can Marathon, Still Lovably Scruffy Online
description: With the performing arts landscape ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic, a new online ecosystem has risen  temporarily, we hope  in its place.

title: How to Cook and Freeze a Large Piece of Meat, and Eat for Weeks
description: On my last bimonthly trip to the supermarket to stock up on staples, I noticed the beef offerings had transitioned from mostly steaks and chops to large, inexpensive roasts like top round, eye rounds and tri-tip. This makes sense, given our slowed shopping cadence. But whats the best way to deal with big, inexpensive cuts of beef?

title: Beyond Black Mirror: 7 Shows That Serve Bite-Size Scares
description: Sure, my feeds are full of friends requests for shows that will take their minds off troubled times. This list is not for them.

title: Reducing Jail Populations
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Ally Sees Easier Path to Intelligence Post in Second Attempt
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump first picked Representative John Ratcliffe of Texas to be the nations intelligence chief last summer, but resistance in the Republican Senate was so firm that Mr. Ratcliffes name was withdrawn before his nomination ever became official.

title: Streaming Plays Give Big-Name Actors a Chance to Give Back
description: It doesnt look like Broadway is going to reopen any time soon. So one producer has decided to start making shows online.

title: Positive Coronavirus Tests Bring Scrutiny to German Soccers Reopening Plans
description: LONDON  As one of the first major sports leagues to detail plans to return to action, Germanys soccer league has become the bellwether for the thorny task of restarting sports events postponed by the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Newspapers Top Editor Is Now a Homeless Blogger
description: He was laid off on April 24. A week later he was living in a Motel 6.

title: They Survived the Holocaust. Now Theyre Confronting the Virus.
description: One got out of Nazi Germany on a Kindertransport train to Sweden, never again seeing his parents, who were exterminated in the death camps. One survived two notorious concentration camps, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and was discovered by British troops on a pile of bodies, half-dead with typhus. One endured freezing temperatures and near starvation in a slave-labor camp in Siberia.

title: Pictures From the Met Gala! (Yes, Last Years)
description: Its the first Monday in May, which means that civilization requires that oodles of celebrities assemble in outlandish clothing and, with their terror quite visible, slowly ascend the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for an unnaturally expensive dinner or perhaps human ritual sacrifice. Why? Because Anna Wintour, the artistic director of Cond Nast and editor of Vogue, compels them to.

title: ESPNs Live Sport Savior: Korean Baseball
description: ESPN, in its desperate search for sports programming during the coronavirus pandemic, has been showing a wide range of events, from the acclaimed Michael Jordan documentary The Last Dance to classic basketball games, to, well, cup stacking and cherry-pit spitting.

title: Senate Office Says It Cant Release Records Biden Requested
description: On Friday, as he forcefully denied an allegation of sexual assault made against him by a former Senate aide, Joseph R. Biden Jr. called on the National Archives to release any complaint related to the accusation.

title: The World Is Helping Americans Who Dont Always See It
description: Its hard to imagine that 97 percent of Americans could agree on anything right now. But that is how many told Pew Research they either strongly (86 percent) or somewhat (11 percent) support international cooperation to fight infectious disease.

title: Americans Are Lining Up for Food. What Is Team Trump Doing?
description: Americans are lined up dozens, hundreds and sometimes thousands deep at food pantries across the nation. One in every six Americans has lost their job in the pandemic, and the number will likely grow much larger before we start adding jobs again. Since March when business shutdowns began to prevent exposure to Covid-19, 1.9 million Texans have filed applications for benefits. Thats more than double all the claims submitted in the state in the entire year of 2019. In Iowa, more people filed for unemployment in March than in all of 2019.

title: How Italy Coped, and Will Keep Coping
description: CREMA, Italy  The first country outside Asia to experience the coronavirus pandemic on a large scale was Italy. It was the first to go into lockdown and impose a national quarantine, on March 9. And it is the part of Europe that suffered most. As of May 3, 29,000 people were known to have lost their lives because of Covid-19. The actual figures are likely to be higher, as they will be everywhere else. My northern region  Lombardy, Italys economic powerhouse  has registered half of the countrys deaths. Army truck convoys carried coffins to crematories around the country from Bergamo  where the death rate in March and April rose to more than four times what it was last year. Brescia, Lodi, Cremona and Crema  where I live  were also deeply affected. My hometown has been a ghost town for two months. People moaned but stayed at home.

title: As Virus Deaths Jump, Boris Johnsons Press Relations Turn Testy
description: LONDON  When Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced journalists last week for the first time since recovering from the coronavirus, he took his leadoff question from a member of the public, Michelle from Cornwall, who asked him about the dangers of infected tourists coming to her seaside region after the lockdown is lifted.

title: For Artists in Need, a New Coalition Brings $11.6 Million in Speedy Relief
description: Anne Finger is a writer of fiction and nonfiction who, like many others in her field, cant rely on income from her creative work alone. A polio survivor and wheelchair user, Ms. Finger bought her loft in Oakland, Calif., 22 years ago with the idea that it would serve as a steady financial source. She rents out the space for photo and video shoots and also began listing her sons former bedroom on Airbnb once he moved out.

title: The Ghost Dogs of the Amazon Get a Bit Less Mysterious
description: It is one of the Amazon rain forests most elusive and enigmatic mammals. Experts call the species shy or even a ghost.

title: Remember Audiences?
description: The photographer Jessica Lehrman specializes in getting deep into crowds  a lost luxury during the coronavirus quarantine. Shes been documenting Flatbush Zombies, a Brooklyn rap crew with a loyal community of fans, since 2012: So many kids come to their shows having overcome suicide and depression and feeling alone and find community, she said. Its beautiful.

title: Vaccine Race, U.S.-China Tensions, Travel Bubble: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The New York Times, Anchorage Daily News and ProPublica Win Pulitzers
description: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Monday to news organizations that delved into corruption, law enforcement and the legacy of racism in the United States, recognizing journalists examinations of inequality and other societal ills.

title: A New Line From a Dries Van Noten Alumna
description: As a teenager living in rural Belgium in the late 1990s, Meryll Rogge, inspired in part by her love of European fashion magazines and the Canadian TV show Fashion File, wrote a list of the three designers she most wanted to work for later in life: Marc Jacobs, Dries Van Noten and Miuccia Prada. Since graduating from the prestigious fashion program at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp in 2008, Rogge, now 35, has checked off two of the three. After university, she moved to New York and worked with Jacobs for seven years, first as an intern and eventually as one of the lead womens wear designers, before relocating to Antwerp and heading womens wear design at Van Notens eponymous brand for three years. In 2019, when the time came to make her next move, rather than try for a hat trick, Rogge instead decided to found her own namesake label  not in Milan or New York or Antwerp but in a 19th-century Flemish barn nine miles southwest of Ghent.

title: Pulitzer Prize: 2020 Winners List
description: The Anchorage Daily News, in collaboration with the nonprofit outlet ProPublica, won the prestigious public service award for a yearlong investigation of sexual violence in Alaska. The series, led by the reporter Kyle Hopkins, uncovered a two-tiered criminal justice system in the state, in which rural communities, disproportionately populated by Indigenous people, had limited or no access to law enforcement and four times as many sex offenders as other areas in the United States, per capita.

title: Billions Could Live in Extreme Heat Zones Within Decades, Study Finds
description: As the climate continues to warm over the next half-century, up to one-third of the worlds population is likely to live in areas that are considered unsuitably hot for humans, scientists said Monday.

title: Andrew Lack Is Out as the Head of NBC News After a Stormy Tenure
description: The chairman of NBC News, Andrew Lack, will depart his role at the end of May, NBC Universal said on Monday, an abrupt end to the tenure of an executive whose tenacity and ability to withstand turmoil made for a long career in the fickle television news business.

title: Per Olov Enquist, Literary Lion of Sweden, Dies at 85
description: Per Olov Enquist, an acclaimed Swedish novelist, playwright and journalist who for decades was a leading voice in Scandinavian literary and cultural life, died on April 25 in Vaxholm, Sweden, a village northeast of Stockholm. He was 85.

title: Joe Biden and Tara Reade: Whom to Believe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Yang, Who Offered Advice for Urban Gardeners, Dies at 83
description: Linda Yang, a gardening writer and author, died on April 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: For Joanna Gaines, Home Is the Heart of a Food and Design Empire
description: The first Chip Gaines heard of avocado toast was in 2017.

title: When Can Child Care Resume?
description: I used to work for hours in a row without interruptions. Now, there is an astronaut-themed Lego set on my desk that seems to move a little bit each day. As I write this, my 7-year-old is sitting next to me, deconstructing pencils instead of doing his schoolwork. In listening to an interview I had recorded, I heard a young voice in the background and then heard myself say, Ill help you in a second. Im still on the phone.

title: Maj Sjowall, Godmother of Nordic Noir, Dies at 84
description: Maj Sjowall, a Swedish novelist who collaborated with her companion on a series of celebrated police procedurals that heralded the crime-fiction genre of Nordic Noir (including the wildly successful books of Stieg Larsson), died on Wednesday in a hospital in Landskrona, Sweden. She was 84.

title: Live From D.C., Its the Supreme Court!
description: Justice Sotomayor?  Justice Sotomayor?

title: Almar Latour Is Named Chief Executive of Dow Jones
description: Almar Latour has been appointed publisher of The Wall Street Journal and chief executive of its parent company, Dow Jones, the company announced on Monday.

title: Hope and Worry Mingle as Countries Relax Coronavirus Lockdowns
description: ROME  Wearing a Plexiglas visor, large white mask and blue rubber gloves, Catia Gabrielli looked ready for whatever could come her way on Monday as Italy tentatively loosened some of its strictest lockdown provisions against the coronavirus.

title: The New York Times Won 3 Pulitzers. Read the Winning Work.
description: The New York Times won three Pulitzer Prizes on Monday, bringing the publications total to 130 since Columbia University began presenting the annual journalism award in 1917.

title: Books Have Literally Saved My Sanity: Readers Respond to Our Letter to the Literary Community
description: Last month, editors at the Book Review wrote to our readers, expressing our concern for those whose livelihoods depend on books. Readers responded in droves, telling us how literature had helped them during this time of fear and instability, and sharing how they were supporting local bookstores and authors. One common theme: Books are a way to bring us together, even in these worrying times. Below are some of those responses, which have been edited and condensed for clarity.

title: Appeals Court Vacancy Is Under Scrutiny Ahead of Contested Confirmation Hearing
description: Just days before a high-profile Senate confirmation hearing to fill a vacancy on the prestigious U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, the courts chief judge has opened the door to an inquiry into whether ethical improprieties occurred in the creation of the coveted opening.

title: Daniel and Valerie Zane, Married 71 Years, Die 2 Days Apart
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Trump and His Infallible Advisers
description: You have 15 people, and the 15 within a couple of days is going to be down close to zero.

title: Kennedy Center Cancels Performances Through August
description: Amid continued coronavirus concerns  and following a contentious debate over its funding  the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Monday postponed or canceled all live events through Aug. 9, including a summer production of Hamilton.

title: Watch This: The Brockmire Finale
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: Virus Deaths, Migration, Disney: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bearing With the Present While Recalling the Past
description: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Biden Camp Finds Selling Point in Ailing Economy: His Work on 2009 Recovery
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. had just been sworn in as vice president. All he needed now was a job.

title: World Leaders Join to Pledge $8 Billion for Vaccine as U.S. Goes It Alone
description: BRUSSELS  Prime ministers, a king, a prince and Madonna all chipped in to an $8 billion pot to fund a coronavirus vaccine.

title: Be a New Orleanian Wherever You Are
description: Youll need to assemble your own jazz band or find a playlist on Spotify to do justice to a Commanders Palace dinner at home, especially for Mothers Day. For the first time, the legendary New Orleans restaurant, in business since 1893, is serving a limited menu for delivery, shipped frozen and nationwide through Goldbelly. The menu offers a three-course dinner for two ($179) or four ($299), with turtle soup, garlic bread, sweet and spicy quail, and pecan pie.  la carte options, serving two or four, are also available. Though the soup just takes a reheat once its thawed, for the quail youll have to channel your inner Paul Prudhomme and Emeril Lagasse  the birds come raw with the ingredients and instructions for stuffing, glazing and roasting them. All the items in the package can be refrigerated for a couple of days, so you have wiggle room in terms of timing. They send an entire pecan pie regardless of the order. There is a limited number of orders filled each day, and delivery is usually about two days from when the order is placed.

title: A Farmer to Restaurants Now Delivers
description: For decades, the Chefs Garden, a 350-acre farm in Huron, Ohio, has been a source of first-rate produce for restaurants across the country. Now the hundreds of items it cultivates are available for home delivery. What makes the offerings so compelling to the discerning cook is not just the dazzling seasonal variety  including sultry purple asparagus, glossy little squashes and bundles of frilly braising greens  but its utter freshness. And when it comes to some items like lettuces, just-picked freshness makes a huge difference. The vegetables look and taste better and even last longer in your fridge. There are assorted produce boxes containing the farms choices starting at $59, or you can assemble your own item by item.

title: Victorias Secret Sale to Private Equity Firm Falls Apart
description: The plan to sell Victorias Secret to a private equity firm was mutually terminated on Monday after the buyer, Sycamore Partners, tried to back out of the deal because it said it did not agree with steps the lingerie brand took in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Travel Somewhere Else via Your Dinner Plate
description: The League of Kitchens, an organization that offers classes in the homes of accomplished immigrant cooks, will now put some of those courses online. No, you wont enjoy passing the rice around the table afterward, and you will be left with the pots to wash, but you can prep the ingredients and cook along with the group, viewing and interacting with the instructor and the other participants. For most of May, the classes, usually two-and-a-half-hours long and starting in late afternoon, will cover Uzbek and Persian cooking.

title: Spain Covid Map and Case Count
description: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

title: A Nice Thing for Spring
description: For springtime and beyond, Hay, a Danish tableware and home furnishing company, has just introduced a line of tailored cotton place mats and napkins in pastel yellow, lavender, beige and gray, each trimmed with contrasting borders. The beige, for example, has sky blue trim. They come in sets of four.

title: Do Not Resuscitate
description: We are in middle of a pandemic. The decision you make is not just about your family member, I yelled into the phone. It was the only way I could be heard through my respirator helmet.

title: After 301 Days in Egyptian Prison, an American Teacher Flies Home
description: CAIRO  An American woman held without trial in an Egyptian prison for more than 300 days, over a Facebook page that criticized Egypts president, has been freed and returned to the United States, her supporters and American officials said on Monday.

title: With Inflation Ravaging Currency, Iran Is Changing Names and Numbers
description: For many years, Irans government debated changing the national currency, the rial, by basically slashing four zeros off its face value  an acknowledgment of how American sanctions and economic mismanagement have contributed to inflation in the country.

title: As Trump Pushes to Reopen, Government Sees Virus Toll Nearly Doubling
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trump presses states to reopen their economies, his administration is privately projecting a steady rise in coronavirus infections and deaths over the next several weeks, reaching about 3,000 daily deaths on June 1  nearly double the current level.

title: Heres Cuomos Plan for Reopening New York
description: ALBANY, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday presented a soft blueprint for how New York States economy might begin to restart, a set of criteria that will determine which regions allow what sectors to reopen and when.

title: Carnival Plans to Sail Again in August, Maybe
description: The Carnival Corporation, the giant cruise company widely criticized for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, announced on Monday that some of its ships may begin sailing again as soon as August.

title: Pulitzer Prizes: A Guide to the Winning Books and Finalists
description: Fifteen books were recognized as winners or finalists for the Pulitzer Prize on Monday, in the categories of fiction, general history, biography, poetry and general nonfiction.

title: Most Events in the Lincoln Memorial Are Banned. Trump Got an Exception.
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trumps aides ran down the list of possible backdrops for his latest Fox News event, they eventually landed on their favorite: the Lincoln Memorial, an iconic tribute to an American life, and one of Mr. Trumps preferred places to add a prime-time touch of drama to his presidency.

title: Money for Welfare Instead Funded Concerts, Lobbyists and Football Games, Audit Finds
description: ATLANTA  The state of Mississippi allowed tens of millions of dollars in federal anti-poverty funds to be used in ways that did little or nothing to help the poor, with two nonprofit groups instead using the money on lobbyists, football tickets, religious concerts and fitness programs for state lawmakers, according to a scathing audit released on Monday.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Most of the United States has hunkered down for the past seven weeks, but the spread of the coronavirus has not stopped. It has slowed a bit in some places, including the hard-hit New York area, while accelerating in others.

title: Mr. Trumps War on Accountability
description: President Trump cant handle the truth  at least, not when it makes his administration look bad. With his move Friday night to replace the top watchdog for the Department of Health and Human Services, the latest in a series of direct attacks on statutory oversight of his administration, its clear that the president remains committed to withholding the truth from the American people as well.

title: Democrats, Tara Reade and the #MeToo Trap
description: Here is one thing that Christine Blasey Ford and Tara Reade have in common: The Intercept reporter Ryan Grim was pivotal in publicizing their stories. Before anyone had heard of Blasey, Grim reported that Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, had a letter from a constituent represented by a lawyer specializing in sexual harassment and assault cases. It was about the Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.

title: Don Shula Kept Winning Interesting
description: Don Shula owns some of the most hallowed records in N.F.L. history: the most wins by a coach, the most games coached, the leagues only perfect season.

title: Lawmakers Ask I.R.S. to Help Companies That Keep Paying Health Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of lawmakers, including the chairmen of the tax-writing committees in the House and the Senate, asked the Internal Revenue Service on Monday to allow companies that continue paying the cost of health benefits for furloughed workers to remain eligible for a new tax credit.

title: In Harms Way: Fighting the Summer Surge
description: Meet health care workers in the South and Southwest battling outbreaks they hoped would never happen.

title: A Swing of the Hips
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  The constructor Lee Taylor made her New York Times debut with a Sunday puzzle in 2015, and after two Sundays and a Monday puzzle, she is back with a Tuesday grid that asks more questions than it answers.

title: A Coronavirus Vaccine Project Takes a Page From Gene Therapy
description: Researchers at two Harvard-affiliated hospitals are adapting a proven form of gene therapy to develop a coronavirus vaccine, which they expect to test in people later this year, they announced on Monday.

title: Greg Zanis, Who Made Crosses for Mass Shooting Victims, Dies at 69
description: Many people knew Greg Zanis simply as the cross man.

title: Liu Shouxiang, Champion of Watercolor in China, Dies at 61
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Quotation of the Day: Airing Worries for Amazons Workers
description: Two things can be true at the same time. A company can be doing tremendous work that is incredibly valued and essential, and it can be treating workers badly.

title: Coronavirus, Vaccine Race, Boris Johnson: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Corrections: May 5, 2020
description: An article on Sunday about couples who have died from Covid-19 misspelled the North Carolina town in which Lois King was raised. It is Ahoskie, not Ohaskie.

title: Watching South Korean Baseball on TV? Let Us Help
description: Josh Lindblom, a pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers, was not expecting a lot last weekend when he turned on his television looking for sports. But what he found was a bit much.

title: Top U.K. Scientist Resigns Over Coronavirus Distancing Violation
description: This briefing has ended. Read live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.

title: Venezuela Claims 2 Americans Were Captured in Failed Invasion
description: President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela said on Monday that two United States citizens were among 13 terrorists captured by the authorities in connection with what officials have called a failed plot to invade the country and topple his government.

title: Wall Street Rallies for a Second Day as Oil Prices Rise: Live Updates
description: Even as they have substantially reduced service, the largest U.S. airlines are averaging just 17 passengers on domestic flights and 29 on international flights, according to a copy of congressional testimony from the head of Airlines for America, an industry group.

title: 15 Children Are Hospitalized With Mysterious Illness Possibly Tied to Covid-19
description: Fifteen children, many of whom had the coronavirus, have recently been hospitalized in New York City with a mysterious syndrome that doctors do not yet fully understand but that has also been reported in several European countries, health officials announced on Monday night.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: Jerry Seinfeld and Arde Madrid
description: JERRY SEINFELD: 23 HOURS TO KILL (2020) Stream on Netflix. If anyone can draw laughs from the mundane  particularly the trivial problems that nagged at us before the coronavirus crisis struck  its Jerry Seinfeld. The comedy giant makes something of a comeback in 23 Hours to Kill, his first original standup special since Im Telling You for the Last Time debuted 22 years ago. Onstage at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan, Seinfeld explores the magic of Pop-Tarts and argues that everyones life sucks, including his, although perhaps not quite as much.

title: Soccers River of Money Isnt Flowing, Worrying Teams Downstream
description: Jonathan David was already thinking about what might come next. He had been in Belgium for almost two years, his first taste of professional soccer in Europe since moving from Canada. He had met every target that had been set for him: He was K.A.A. Gents leading goal scorer in his first season and the joint top scorer for the whole Belgian league in his second.

title: Word + Quiz: decry
Parking Lots Have Become a Digital Lifeline
description: As the sun set on a recent evening in Rutherfordton, N.C., the author Beth Revis drove her green S.U.V. into the parking lot of a closed elementary school and connected to the buildings free Wi-Fi. Then, for the third time since the coronavirus pandemic had taken hold, she taught a two-hour writing class from her drivers seat.

title: This Drug May Cause Birth Defects. Japans Pushing It for Coronavirus.
description: TOKYO  As President Trump was extolling the promise of a malaria drug in the desperate hunt for coronavirus treatments, one of his top global allies was selling the world on his own trump card, a pale yellow pill that he said could be crucial to fighting the pandemic.

title: Masks
description: As the nation edges away from lockdown and people once again share public spaces in the middle of a pandemic, wearing a face mask  or refusing to  has become a flash point in a moment when civic rules are being rewritten, seemingly on the fly, reports The Times this week.

title: The Thinnest Paper in the World
