title: The Results Are In for the Sharing Economy. They Are Ugly.
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The coronavirus pandemic has gutted the so-called sharing economy. Its most valuable companies, which started the year by promising that they would soon become profitable, now say consumer demand has all but vanished.

title: N.F.L. Teams Preparing for Games With Fewer Fans
description: The N.F.L. announced its schedule for the upcoming season on Thursday night in a prime time TV event. But a handful of teams have begun tempering expectations that fans will be able to attend some of those games  assuming they will be played in front of fans at all.

title: Bacteria Bombs, Fat Tongues and Microrobots: The Winners of Our STEM Writing Contest
description: Have you ever wondered why the world doesn't go black every time you blink? Or how incompetent people can seem so confident in their abilities? Or what all that plastic in the ocean means for our food?

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The authorities are looking into whether the rush to reopen a chemical plant in eastern India after a long coronavirus lockdown contributed to a deadly gas leak on Thursday morning that killed at least 11 people and sickened hundreds.

title: Memers are Taking Over TikTok
description: Since launching in the U.S. in 2018, TikTok has cemented itself in viral culture. It has given birth to dance crazes, popular catchphrases and food trends. It also jump-started the careers of a generation of young influencers.

title: Tiny in Size, but Goliath in Force: The Colonization of Ant-Based Microrobotics
description: This essay, by Celina Zhao, 17, from North Oconee High School in Athens, Ga., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: An Unexpected Dinner Guest: Marine Plastic Pollution Hides a Neurological Toxin in Our Food
description: This essay, by Vivian Li, 16, from Montgomery Blair High School in North Potomac, Md., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: In the Blink of an Eye
description: This essay, by Rivka Shields, from Yeshiva of Greater Washington  Tiferes Gedaliah in Silver Spring, Md., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: The Dunning-Kruger Effect: Why Incompetence Begets Confidence
description: This essay, by Allison He, 17, from the Texas Academy of Math and Science in Plano, Tex., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: A New Cancer Treatment That Is Faster, More Efficient and Less Risky Is Coming: Bacteria Bombs
description: This essay, by William Chesney, 15, from Ethical Culture Fieldston School in the Bronx, N.Y., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Quorum Sensing: What We Can Learn From Eavesdropping on Bacteria
description: This essay, by Jenny Mao, 17, from Carlmont High School in San Mateo, Calif., is one of the top eight winners of The Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Circadian Rhythms: The Conductor of Our Bodys Symphony
description: This essay, by Aliya Fisher, 16, from the Bronx High School of Science in the Bronx, N.Y., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: After Recovery From the Coronavirus, Most People Carry Antibodies
description: A new study offers a glimmer of hope in the grim fight against the coronavirus: Nearly everyone who has had the disease  regardless of age, sex or severity of illness  makes antibodies to the virus.

title: Tara Reade Says Joe Biden Should Withdraw From Presidential Race
description: Tara Reade, the former Senate aide who has accused Joseph R. Biden Jr. of sexual assault, said that the former vice president should not be running on character, and that she thought he should withdraw as the Democratic presidential candidate.

title: Fat Got Your Tongue?
description: This essay, by Nicole Fang, 16, from Richard Montgomery High School in North Potomac, Md., is one of the top eight winners of the Learning Networks first-ever STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 1,618 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Gil Schwartz, CBS Spokesman With a Biting Alter Ego, Dies at 68
description: Gil Schwartz, the CBS networks longtime chief communications officer who, under the pen name Stanley Bing, skewered corporate misbehavior throughout the business world in columns for Esquire and Fortune magazines, died on Saturday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 68.

title: 21 Quarantine Baking Recipes for Every Skill Level
description: Whats more comforting than stirring together a bowl of brown, beige and white ingredients, sliding it into the oven and watching as it transforms into something golden and spectacular?

title: Reopenings Mark a New Phase: Global Trial-and-Error Played Out in Lives
description: The world is entering a period of high-stakes experimentation, with cities and countries serving as open-air laboratories for how to most safely and effectively reopen amid the coronavirus.

title: Nearly 20,000 Georgia Teens Are Issued Drivers Licenses Without a Road Test
description: Last month, Georgia waived its road-test requirement for most drivers in an effort to help fight the spread of the coronavirus. This week, the state said it had issued drivers licenses to thousands of teenagers without one.

title: Moderna Gets OK to Start Larger Trial for a Coronavirus Vaccine
description: One of the first biotech companies to begin human trials of an experimental vaccine for the coronavirus is now ready to move onto the next phase of testing.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: Scientists Consider Indoor Ultraviolet Light to Zap Coronavirus in the Air
description: As society tries to rebound from the coronavirus pandemic, some scientists hope a decades-old technology could zap pathogens out of the air in stores, restaurants and classrooms, potentially playing a key role in containing further spread of the infection.

title: Elizabeth Scholtz, Barrier-Breaking Garden Director, Dies at 98
description: In 1972, when Elizabeth Scholtz became director of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the splendid 52-acre urban garden founded in 1910, she was not only the first female director of a major botanic garden in the United States; she was also one of the few women in charge of a large New York City cultural institution. This made for some awkward collisions.

title: Is Food Delivery During the Coronavirus Pandemic Ethical?
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: An Epidemic of Hardship and Hunger
description: Covid-19 has had a devastating effect on workers. The economy has plunged so quickly that official statistics cant keep up, but the available data suggest that tens of millions of Americans have lost their jobs through no fault of their own, with more job losses to come and full recovery probably years away.

title: An Incursion Into Venezuela, Straight Out of Hollywood
description: BOGOT, Colombia  A disenchanted band of Venezuelan politicians and military deserters gathered in secret last year to plot the overthrow of Venezuelas authoritarian leader, Nicols Maduro. They determined they would need four tools to succeed: men, money, a plan and guts.

title: Scrutiny of Social-Distance Policing as 35 of 40 Arrested Are Black
description: A police officer enforcing social-distancing rules broke up a group of people on a stoop during a nighttime cookout in East New York, Brooklyn, punching one man in the face. Another dispute between officers and residents of the same predominantly black neighborhood over the guidelines led to a man being knocked unconscious. Days later, three men were arrested after taking part in a sprawling vigil at the Queensbridge Houses for a rapper who was said to have died of the coronavirus.

title: Review: Mark Ruffalo, Times Two, in the Saddest Story Ever Told
description: The new HBO mini-series I Know This Much Is True takes a character and puts him through a wringer that is so unforgiving, youd expect it to flatten him completely, to squeeze out everything but the allegory of suffering. That it doesnt  that theres enough juice in him to keep you moderately interested for most of the six-hour-plus story  is almost entirely thanks to the man playing him, Mark Ruffalo. Its hard to imagine anyone else who could find this much life in the shows modern-day Job.

title: F.D.A. Paves Way for Home Testing of Coronavirus
description: In a move that could significantly expand the nations testing capacity, the Food and Drug Administration has posted new guidelines that could pave the way for millions of people to test themselves for the coronavirus at home.

title: Reopening Guidelines, Michael Flynn, Yeast: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The New Culture War
description: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Alfredo and Susana Pabatao Die; Health Care Aides on the Front Lines
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Criticized on Virus, Trump Goes to His Playbook: Deflect, Reject and Minimize
description: Faced with intense criticism of his handling of the coronavirus pandemic, stubbornly high rates of new infections across much of the country and questions about whether he is pushing too soon to get the economy going again, President Trump has settled into a messaging routine: deflect, reject and minimize.

title: 11 Great Movies and Shows Leaving Netflix in May
description: Our entertainment  and lets be honest, our sanity  is more reliant on Netflix than ever before, and thus the whims and expirations of their licensing deals are a bit more urgent. These are the noteworthy titles scheduled to disappear from the service in May, so if youre prioritizing your binge viewing for the near future, move them to the top of your queue.

title: G.O.P. Revolt in Ohio: Governor Faces Attacks From Within Over Shutdowns
description: In the early days of the pandemic, Mike DeWine, the mild-mannered Republican governor of Ohio, gained a national profile for moving quickly to shut down his state while other leaders hesitated. The rates of infection in Ohio have stayed lower than elsewhere in the Midwest.

title: We Need National Service. Now.
description: There is now a vast army of young people ready and yearning to serve their country. There are college graduates emerging into a workplace that has few jobs for them. There are more high school graduates who suddenly cant afford college. There are college students who dont want to return to a college experience. This is a passionate, idealistic generation that sees the emergency, wants to serve those around them and groans to live up to this moment.

title: Screenings Were Porous as Trump Spurred Exodus From Virus Hot Spots
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps go-to defense of his early response to the coronavirus is his decision to close down travel from China, the viruss original epicenter, and then from ravaged Europe.

title: Postal Service Pick With Ties to Trump Raises Concerns Ahead of 2020 Election
description: WASHINGTON  The installment of one of President Trumps financial backers and a longtime Republican donor as the postmaster general is raising concerns among Democrats and ethics watchdogs that the Postal Service will be politicized at a time when states are mobilizing their vote-by-mail efforts ahead of the 2020 election.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: To prepare for the day when stay-at-home orders would be eased, public health experts at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention drew up guidelines detailing what schools, restaurants,  churches and other gathering places should do to reopen safely.

title: Report Paints Scathing Picture of Nursing Home Where 17 Bodies Piled Up
description: One patient at a troubled nursing home in northern New Jersey was found dead in bed, 12 hours after falling on a wet floor and suffering a head injury. Rigor mortis had set in. The patient had suffered from a high fever for days, but a doctor was never told.

title: White House Rattled by a Military Aides Positive Coronavirus Test
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump said on Thursday that the White House staff would be tested every day for the coronavirus after a military aide who has had contact with him was found to have the virus.

title: Dont Forget, Michael Flynn Pleaded Guilty. Twice.
description: It can be hard to recall, since so many members of President Trumps inner circle have been indicted, convicted of federal crimes and even sent to prison, but the first felon to emerge from this administration was Michael Flynn.

title: De Blasio Strips Control of Virus Tracing From Health Department
description: New York City will soon assemble an army of more than 1,000 disease detectives to trace the contacts of every person who tests positive for the coronavirus, an approach seen as crucial to quelling the outbreak and paving the way to reopen the hobbled city.

title: 2 Suspects Charged With Murder in Ahmaud Arbery Shooting
description: ATLANTA  The two white men who were seen on a widely shared video as one of them fatally shot Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man, were arrested and charged on Thursday in connection with the shooting  two days after the graphic footage became public and more than two months after the killing itself.

title: N.F.L. Releases 2020 Schedule Even as Start Remains in Doubt
description: In a time of great uncertainty, the N.F.L.s 2020 regular-season schedule, which was revealed Thursday night, abounds with optimism. A full 17-week slate was released, with no obvious contingency plan in case the coronavirus pandemic prevents the season from starting on time.

title: Never Seen Anything Like This: Experts Question Dropping of Flynn Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments decision to drop the criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, President Trumps former national security adviser, even though he had twice pleaded guilty to lying to investigators, was extraordinary and had no obvious precedent, a range of criminal law specialists said on Thursday.

title: Billing Partner
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I chose a really pretty picture of the DESERT BLOOM in Chiles Atacama Desert, but then I remembered that Daniel Larsen had debuted SCHRDINGERS CAT and thought of the interesting character that was Socks. This photo predates the constructor of todays puzzle by three presidential terms, give or take. Just to remind you all that Mr. Larsen is extremely young, and that Socks was awfully cute with those little white socks.

title: New York Man Charged With Fraud Over Coronavirus Home Tests
description: A New York man is facing fraud charges after he conned several people into buying stolen test kits for the coronavirus and then never gave them the results, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Quotation of the Day: A Knock at the Door: Invaluable for Turnout, Improbable in 2020
description: Weve converted one of the countrys most intensive door-knocking operations into one of the countrys most intensive screen-pinging operations.

title: Corrections: May 8, 2020
description: An article on Thursday about the risks of gathering in cooling centers during the pandemic misstated the number of people sleeping without shelter in Phoenix. A survey in January counted almost 4,000 in all of Maricopa County, which includes Phoenix, not in the city of Phoenix alone.

title: G.O.P. Coronavirus Message: Economic Crisis Is a Green New Deal Preview
description: WASHINGTON  The coronavirus and the struggle to contain it has tanked the economy, shuttered thousands of businesses and thrown more than 30 million people out of work. As President Trump struggles for a political response, Republicans and their allies have seized on an answer: attacking climate change policies.

title: Mothering While Deaf in a Newly Quiet World
description: It took a pandemic for me to finally see my language everywhere. During any disaster, youll usually see a sign-language interpreter next to the government officials. But with this disaster being both nationwide and seemingly endless, so is the presence of sign-language interpreters. I watch as their hands create images that flow directly into my brain, as natural as breathing.

title: Valley Girl Review: A Jukebox Musical in the Key of Irony
description: The material world of Valley Girl, a fizzy and fun remake of the 1983 cult rom-com, sprawls across contrasting 80s neighborhoods. Julie (Jessica Rothe) and her posse live in the San Fernando Valley, where they shop and shriek in a luridly glowing mall. But over the hill, the grimier world of Hollywood is home to her soon-to-be boyfriend Randy (Josh Whitehouse), whose pierced and tatted pals prefer moshing at punk shows.

title: Summer Is Coming, but the Virus Wont Be Going
description: Everybody hopes for seasonality when it comes to the coronavirus pandemic, Peter Juni of the University of Toronto acknowledged. Maybe, just maybe, the summer will diminish the spread of Covid-19.

title: Mexican Government Is Hiding Huge Coronavirus Toll, Especially in the Capital
Britain, Antibodies, Bundesliga: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: U.S. Jobs Report Shows Clearest Data Yet on Economic Toll
description: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

title: Whats on TV Friday: The Eddy and the Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: THE EDDY Stream on Netflix. On the night we meet him, after the drinks have stopped flowing and the band has gone home, the jazz pianist at the center of this multilingual mini-series, Elliot Udo (Andr Holland), settles at a piano onstage at the Paris club he co-owns. He presses his fingers to the keys. At the bottom of the screen, a bracketed caption flashes. Sad chord, it reads. Plaintive melody. In other words: All is not well. The club is struggling. Its patrons are asking why Elliot doesnt perform anymore. Elliots business partner, Farid (Tahar Rahim), is apparently involved in illicit activity. And soon, Elliots teenage daughter, Julie (Amandla Stenberg), will arrive from the United States to live with him. So begins the story of The Eddy, a jazz-forward mini-series written by Jack Thorne and directed by filmmakers who, perhaps unsurprisingly, include Damien Chazelle (La La Land, Whiplash). The story is infused with original music by the songwriter Glen Ballard.

title: A Voracious Reader Takes Drastic Measures After Running Out of Books
Trumps M.O. Is The Less You Know, Says Stephen Colbert
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: The Old Knicks Made Basketball Games the Hippest Place in New York
description: An adage cracking wise on New Yorks half-century love affair with the only championship teams in the Knicks history goes like this: So many books, so few titles.

title: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Michael Flynn, Don Shula
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?

title: Yukio Okamoto, Diplomat Who Nurtured Japans U.S. Ties, Dies at 74
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: A Philosopher-Banker Whos Shaking Up a Nation
description: Steven Coutinho was sitting in his office in an imposing colonial mansion overlooking a palm-strewn tropical garden one January evening when he received an unexpected text message: Surinames enigmatic president wanted to see him in his palace the next day.

title: New in Paperback: The Old Drift and Cake
description: SPRING, by Ali Smith. (Anchor, 352 pp., $15.95.) A work-in-progress as raw as this mornings Twitter rant and as lasting and important as Ulysses is how our reviewer, Rebecca Makkai, described the seasonal quartet of which this novel is the third movement. Here, as three unrelated characters descend on the same Scottish town, Smith zeroes in on one of her main themes: how people are either, in Makkais words, thrust together or live separate lives that miss one another by inches.

title: In Stray, Stephanie Danler Asks How a Victim Becomes a Perpetrator
description: STRAYA MemoirBy Stephanie Danler

title: An Epic Storm Turns a Summer Holiday Into Potent Allegory
description: A CHILDRENS BIBLEBy Lydia Millet

title: The Persistence of May
description: When I was in first grade at my Catholic elementary school, my teacher told me there was a mother who would never leave me, and I could find her in the flowers. Of course she meant Mary, the purported mother of God. But I thought she meant my Sicilian grandmother, Mary Grace. Because when May came, there Gran was  in her garden in suburban Philadelphia, tending the freshly planted marigolds and zinnias. If good mothers live on in some inflorescent afterlife, Gran was on her way.

title: How to Grow a Victory Garden of Any Size
description: First the raised beds arrived, three narrow boxes lining the edge of my yard. Then came the soil in a big pungent pile, demanding to be shoveled. And last weekend, I brought home trays of delicate little plants that promise a summer of Swiss chard, snap peas, tomatoes and beets.

title: Enduring Lessons From My Mom
description: Debra Weiner is interviewing 100 newsmakers, thought leaders and other people whove made an outsize difference about the most valuable thing their parents taught them. Following are excerpts from a few of those stories, edited and condensed.

title: In the Fight to Treat Coronavirus, Your Lungs Are a Battlefield
description: Both the human lung and a critical care ventilator are complicated pieces of machinery. We opened them up to show you how the coronavirus has changed what we thought we knew.

title: Paid Leave Law Tries to Help Millions in Crisis. Many Havent Heard of It.
description: The paid leave program passed by Congress in March was supposed to help workers cope with the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic. It has struggled to do so. Many Americans are ineligible, and many more are unaware the benefit even exists, surveys show.

title: This Is Not Historys Catherine the Great
description: LONDON  Buttoning up the fly of his leather pants, Nicholas Hoult was confusing his condiments.

title: Laura Prepon Meditates on Motherhood and Clay
description: Laura Prepon had already planned on spending the spring indoors. Ms. Prepon, who gave birth to her second child with her husband, the actor Ben Foster, at the end of February, had scheduled a six-week maternity leave. She hadnt put a pandemic on the calendar.

title: My Last Encounter With Pandemic Parenting
Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, Children and Migraines
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: This Weekends Livestreaming Events: Tim McGraw and a Broadway Mothers Day
description: Here are a few of the best events happening Friday through Sunday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

title: She Just Wanted to Play Bass. That Life Is Gone.
description: Forty-three years ago, not long after she graduated from Princeton with a degree in art history, Amy Madden turned down an acceptance to Harvard Law School, leaving her mother horrified. If you were the sort of person governed by creative longing, if you defined ambition on your own terms, there was really just one place to be in 1977. Amy Madden went directly from college to New York, moving to the Lower East Side, where she found an apartment on Avenue B for $50 a month.

title: A Strangers Gift to an I.C.U. Nurse: A Free N.Y.C. Apartment
description: Around noon on Easter Sunday, Leona Hernandez, a registered nurse, pulled up in a van to a strangers home on the South Side of Minneapolis.

title: Nutritional Yeast Is for Hippies. Nooch Is for Everyone.
description: It took only 50 years, but nutritional yeast has finally gone mainstream.

title: Unjust Convictions Must Become a Justice Department Priority
description: In 2003, Greg Elking wrote a letter to his minister.

title: Sweatpants and No Caviar
description: With the New York party scene on hiatus, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

title: Doctors and Nurses Should Think More About Their Necks
description: Not long ago I asked a colleague to take my photo just before I was to see a patient who potentially had the novel coronavirus. Even though I had assured my 82-year-old mother every night that my hospital department has adequate supplies, she was worried and needed proof.

title: He Had Never Sold a Ventilator. N.Y. Gave Him an $86 Million Deal.
description: The offer to the Federal Emergency Management Agency sounded promising: A Silicon Valley engineer said that he could deliver thousands of ventilators from manufacturers across China to help hospitals treat coronavirus patients.

title: Congress Can Do Its Job Without Spreading the Coronavirus
description: Anyone who has experienced the unbearable closeness of voting in the House of Representatives knows its a health hazard, even under normal conditions. As soon as bells buzz across the Capitol, 435 House members, on a good day, (plus delegates) race to the floor. The fastest option  the members only elevators  each comfortably holds eight people. Ten, if you squeeze. During a vote, members pack in close enough to sense what their colleagues ate for lunch. These are extroverted pols who cant help but take advantage of a confined space to tell jokes and laugh loudly.

title: The World Is Taking Pity on Us
description: In 1847, members of the Choctaw Nation sent relief money across the Atlantic to a starving Ireland  something the Irish, who lost more than a million people in a famine made worse by British indifference, have never forgotten. The Irish are now giving financial aid to Native American tribes hit with a pandemic that has been made worse by American incompetence.

title: Trumps Bid to Stand Above the Law
description: On Tuesday, the U.S. Supreme Court is scheduled to hear one of the most consequential cases ever considered on executive privilege. Trump v. Vance concerns a subpoena issued by the Manhattan district attorney to President Trumps accountants demanding the release of tax returns and other financial documents to a grand jury.

title: With Red Tape Lifted, Dr. Zoom Will See You Now
description: In late March, Mary Jane Sturgis got a call from her primary-care physicians office, saying that her doctor was working from home during the Covid-19 crisis and suggesting an alternative for her scheduled checkup. Would Ms. Sturgis agree to a video appointment on Zoom?

title: This Is the Future of the Pandemic
description: By now we know  contrary to false predictions  that the novel coronavirus will be with us for a rather long time.

title: Full Steam Ahead for Trumps Convention? North Carolina Has Doubts
description: President Trump has made clear that he wants a traditional political convention in Charlotte, N.C., in late August, with thousands of sign-waving delegates from out of state filling an arena to acclaim his renomination.

title: I Cry Night and Day: How It Took One Woman 8 Weeks to Get Unemployment
description: Seven weeks after she filed for unemployment benefits, Nadine Josephs was running out of money. The birthdays of her two teenage children loomed, and she was spending her days pleading for forbearance on overdue bills.

title: Back in Session, State Legislatures Challenge Governors Authority
description: ATLANTA  State lawmakers in Mississippi voted overwhelmingly last week to strip away the governors authority to spend more than $1.2 billion in federal funds. In Wisconsin, lawyers for the Legislatures Republican leaders argued before the State Supreme Court their case for reining in the governors executive safer-at-home order.

title: A Techno Group Wary of Technology
description: As pioneers of synthesized pop music, the German group Kraftwerk has long been hailed as visionary. But the band, whose co-founder Florian Schneider died last month, has been visionary on a much grander scale than music.

title: The Anti-Lockdown Protesters Have a Twisted Conception of Liberty
description: Most Americans support the lockdowns and want the government to bring the coronavirus under control before opening up the economy. But most is not all, and a small minority is eager to end all the restrictions now, even as the virus spreads and Covid-19 caseloads continue to grow.

title: A Quarantine Hospital So Unwelcome that New Yorkers Burned it Down
description: President Trump tweeted in late April that because of the coronavirus pandemic, he sought to halt immigration in light of the attack from the Invisible Enemy. This followed earlier assertions that concerns over the viruss spread legitimized a crackdown at the southwestern border.

title: Why Get All Made Up With Nowhere to Go?
description: Amie Wohrer reached her limit about three weeks into the shutdown.

title: How an Edible Arrangements Delivery Worker Spends Her Sundays
description: Sandy Matthews makes deliveries for Edible Arrangements, the company known for its cut fruit bouquets, mylar balloons and chocolate-dipped strawberries. Since the coronavirus outbreak, she has gone from working part time to full time. I used to drop off five or six arrangements a day, mostly for birthdays or graduations; now its 20-plus, she said. A lot are being sent by worried, out-of-state parents who are afraid their adult children arent getting vitamins or wont have food, she continued. Others are for mourners who have lost people to the virus. Ms. Matthews, 54, who was a waitress for more than two decades, lives by herself in a one-bedroom apartment in University Heights, in the Bronx.

title: Small Farms in N.Y. Are Experiencing a Surprising Boom. Heres Why.
description: One Wednesday in early March, Abra Morawiec realized something seismic was happening at her farm stand. The month had been pretty quiet at the Feisty Acres table in the Union Square Greenmarket in Manhattan. But that day, at the very start of social distancing, she had sold out of everything by 2 p.m.

title: Knitting for the Apocalypse
description: Pastimes of yore have been all the rage during this pandemic  flower pressing, jigsaw puzzles, baking bread  and on that list, knitting continues to climb. In Spain, a hipster knitting companys sales are surging. In Britain, theres a run on supplies as the Prince of Wales rallies influencers to boost yarn crafts. Tutorials and essays espousing the healing powers of knitting have flooded the internet. In short: Weve hit peak crafting.

title: Yes, Thats Allyson Felix Running Down Your Block
description: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Spoiled Milk, Rotten Vegetables and a Very Broken Food System
description: WATERLOO, Ontario Belgians are being told that they need to increase their consumption of frites. Across Britain, farmers have dumped millions of pints of milk down the drain instead of churning it into butter. In Iran, millions of baby chickens  which may have one day been bound for barbecues  have been buried alive. In India, farmers are feeding strawberries to cattle rather than sending them to markets.

title: The Little Wedding on the Deck
description: Ashley Gruber always made a point of paying attention in church. This helped salvage her wedding.

title: Coronavirus Escape: To the Suburbs
description: For some New Yorkers, its time to get out of town for good.

title: Hidden Toll: Mexico Ignores Wave of Coronavirus Deaths in Capital
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican government is not reporting hundreds, possibly thousands, of deaths from the coronavirus in Mexico City, dismissing anxious officials who have tallied more than three times as many fatalities in the capital than the government publicly acknowledges, according to officials and confidential data.

title: How Dana White Unexpectedly Brought U.F.C. Back in a Pandemic
description: When Tony Ferguson and Justin Gaethje step into the octagon Saturday night in Jacksonville, Fla., their interim lightweight title bout will be the climax of U.F.C. 249, the biggest sporting event to take place in the United States in almost two months. It will also be a triumph for Dana White, the bellicose president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship. If it were up to White, he never would have stopped staging mixed martial arts fights, coronavirus pandemic be damned.

title: F.D.A. Clears First Home Saliva Test; Pences Press Secretary Has Virus
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: McDonalds Workers in Denmark Pity Us
description: President Trump thunders that Democrats are trying to drag America toward socialism, Vice President Mike Pence warns that Democrats aim to impose socialism on the American people, and even some Democrats warn against becoming, as one put it, [expletive] Denmark.

title: Social Shaming Will Not Save Us
description: An aphorism of online life goes: Every day, the internet picks a hero and a villain, and you hope that neither one is you.

title: Christianity Gets Weird
description: A few weeks ago, I dialed into the Eucharist for the first time, praying for spiritual communion as my priest consumed the host in front of the altar. The webcam was clear. The sound quality was top-notch. But the Mass was decidedly old-school.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: The Dirty Secret About Weeding
description: Athletes and coaches study game tapes of their opponents, looking for weaknesses and other clues on how to get the upper hand. Thats how gardeners should look at weeds, learning as much as they can about the plants and all their moves.

title: The Arrival of the Murder Hornet
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Coronavirus, Ahmaud Arbery, Michael Flynn: Your Friday Briefing
description: The world is entering a very risky period with the coronavirus  and many health experts and ordinary people are nervous.

title: Trump Says Hes Torn on China Deal as Advisers Signal Harmony on Trade
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump criticized China for failing to hold up its end of the trade deal on Friday and said he was very torn about the fate of the agreement signed in January, even as his closest economic advisers released a statement reassuring the world that the truce was intact.

title: The Government Is Ready to Reopen. Its Citizens Arent, Polls Show.
description: Two months after the coronavirus shuttered much of the United States economy, the outbreaks impact  on jobs, health care, foodaccess and much more is growing only more severe, according to a growing body of polling and social science data.

title: Brace for Devastating News on Jobs
description: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

title: Kenyans Held for Weeks in Quarantine Were Told to Pay to Get Out
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  When Valentine Ochogo arrived home in Kenya after being laid off from her job at a hot-air balloon business in Dubai, she was put in quarantine in a university dormitory with other travelers  one step in the governments aggressive, often-lauded campaign to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

title: 5-Year-Old Dies in New York City of Rare Illness Linked to Virus
description: A 5-year-old died in New York City on Thursday from what appeared to be a rare syndrome linked to the coronavirus that causes life-threatening inflammation in children, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said.

title: As India Reopens, Deadly Accidents Break Out
description: NEW DELHI  Sixteen migrant workers were crushed to death by a freight train in central India on Friday as they were traveling home, the latest casualties connected to Indias coronavirus lockdown and efforts to reopen the economy.

title: Authorities Investigate Death on Austin Runway Where Southwest Flight Landed
Do You Enjoy Going On a Walk  Especially Now?
description: Do you enjoy going on a walk? Or, would you rather use any other mode of transportation like a scooter, a skateboard or a bike? When you walk, do you take a leisurely stride or march at a brisk pace? Do you take in the sights, smells and sounds around you, or are you lost deep in thought?

title: Film Club: Concert for One: I.C.U. Doctor Brings Classical Music to Coronavirus Patients
description: Concert for One: I.C.U. Doctor Brings Classical Music to Coronavirus Patients is a five-minute film that touches on themes of sickness, isolation and hope. It profiles Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, who has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19  live classical music concerts.

title: Word + Quiz: unflappable
The Stories Maps Can Tell
description: A recent Times article suggests that you release your inner explorer by reliving, commemorating or envisioning a favorite place in the world through creating an illustrated map of it.

title: Hayley Williams Lays Down New Roots on Her First Solo Album
description: Second chances, they dont ever matter, people never change, Hayley Williams sang, decisively, at the wizened age of 18. Since Misery Business propelled her power-emo band Paramore to stardom, the ever-evolving singer and songwriter has proved that maxim wrong over and over again. Case in point: Though it remains a much-requested fan favorite, the band no longer performs the song live. As Williams wrote on her Tumblr five years ago, I havent related to it in a very long time.

title: How Bad Is Unemployment? Literally Off the Charts
description: The U.S. jobless rate for April is put at 14.7 percent, with 20.5 million jobs lost, figures that almost certainly understate the economic devastation.

title: The Reopening of California Has Begun
description: Good morning.

title: What Happens If You Are Sued by a Debt Collector?
description: Americans wrestled with debt-collection lawsuits long before the coronavirus hit, a new report finds. Now, a surge of the suits may swamp consumers who lost their jobs in the pandemic and cant afford to pay their bills.

title: The Pandemic Has Slowed the Divorce Process. Heres What to Expect.
description: When state and local governments announced shelter-in-place orders to slow the spread of the coronavirus, predictions that the lockdowns would force a reckoning in bad marriages and lead to a rise in the divorce rate abounded.

title: Desperate Sellers, Nervous Buyers: Real Estate Sales in a Pandemic
description: Late last month, about 60 agents from some of New Yorks top brokerages gathered in a virtual conference room for what was billed as the first open house of its kind for real estate agents. One by one, presenters shared pictures and videos of eight listings in Chelsea, with varying degrees of candor.

title: Lesson of the Day: Gaps in Amazons Response as Virus Spreads to More Than 50 Warehouses
description: Featured Article: Gaps in Amazons Response as Virus Spreads to More Than 50 Warehouses by Karen Weise and Kate Conger

title: How Coronavirus Is Taking a Toll on Mental Health
description: Francesca Donner, editor of In Her Words, on how the coronavirus is taking a toll on peoples mental health

title: Investigators Call Evidence in the Ahmaud Arbery Shooting Extremely Upsetting
description: This briefing has ended. Read about the troubled history of the Georgia police force that handled the Ahmaud Arbery case.

title: How Not to Apologize in Quarantine
description: No matter how hard we try to avoid it, were all doomed to hurt those we love. In quarantine, despite our best efforts, were all destined to annoy those we love.

title: Was a 90s Scorpions Song the Work of the C.I.A.? This Podcast Is on It
description: Anyone worth his or her cassette tape collection can whistle the beginning of Wind of Change, the 1990 hit by the West German heavy-metal band Scorpions. The song  with wistful lyrics such as The world is closing in/Did you ever think/That we could be so close, like brothers, emoted by the groups frontman Klaus Meine  was an anthem for the stretch of history that saw the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Soviet Unions collapse.  It also might be the handiwork of the C.I.A.

title: Happy Mothers Day to These Oddballs and Malcontents
description: With a pandemic putting beloved Mothers Day traditions on hold this year, movies about conventional moms  the kinds with cute kids, kindly husbands and gorgeously sun-soaked kitchens  can provide much-needed comfort and solace. Cheaper by the Dozen will do nicely.

title: Live(ish), From Someones Room, This  Is American Isolation
description: The first episode of this seasons American Idol opened in typically outsized fashion. We flashed back to last seasons finale, as Laine Hardy was crowned the winner, amid blinding lights and a roaring crowd in a massive theater.

title: Alone With Their Muses, Artists in Retreat Wonder if Its Too Much
description: EAST HAMPTON, N. Y. When Eric Haze was 10 years old, he and his sister posed for Elaine de Kooning in her downtown Manhattan studio. It was 1972 and it had been arranged through a colleague of his father. In between sittings, the artist, who painted John F. Kennedy, Berry Gordy and Pel, and was married on and off to Willem de Kooning, gave Mr. Haze brushes and told him to paint. She also taught him how to stretch canvasses.

title: U.S. Leads the Worlds Virus Fight? Thats News to the World
description: WASHINGTON  A new Democratic plan for confronting the coronavirus echoes what much of the rest of the West has been saying for months: that the United States has stepped back from the global response just as it is needed most.

title: Ariana Grande and Justin Biebers Slow Dance, and 10 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Its Going to Be a Bit of a Bumpy Ride: Financiers Weigh In on the Crisis
description: The economy is battered, yet the stock markets keep rising. Unemployment is soaring, but so far a real estate crisis seems to have been averted.

title: Why 1.4 Million Health Jobs Have Been Lost During a Huge Health Crisis
description: For more than half a century, in good economic times and bad, health care jobs in the United States just kept increasing. Economists and health analysts thought of them as nearly recession-proof: a buffer against the business cycle.

title: 5 New Comedy Specials to Remind You of the Old Normal
description: Laughter is the best medicine is a clich that has been skewered so many times its easy to forget the animating truth behind it. No, a joke will not save us, but it can provide solace, and not just by lightening the mood. In a time when many are isolated and suffering, its easy to get stuck in destructive mental patterns. The utility of jokes is that they are perfectly engineered to trick minds out of ruts, manipulate thoughts in one direction or another, a Rube Goldberg device delighting through distraction. The day will come when all the new comedy will have been made in a world after the pandemic, but we are not there yet. Most of the new specials, developed before the crisis, seem like they arrived from another world. For those tired of this one, it can be nice to visit. Here are a few recent examples.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. A long time ago, when I used to ride an electric motorbike through crowded traffic so I could get to a subway station where I shared a rickety elevator with a lot of people before getting on a train car with even more, so that I could travel into the heart of Times Square to go to work, making my way down 40th Street against a heaving tide of people coming from the Port Authority, I sometimes stopped at the deli across the street from the newspaper and ordered a bacon, egg and cheese sandwich.

title: Working for Social Change, High School Students Find a Social Life
description: For every generation categorized as lazy or uninformed, along comes a group of young people to Shut. That. Down.

title: Young BFFs, Looking for Likes in All the Wrong Places
description: All hail the best friend! That person we confide in and listen to without fear or judgment. The one with whom we share in-jokes. The one who holds our hand, metaphorically and sometimes literally, through the murky patches. As the clich goes, we dont always know where this person ends and we begin. During a time of insecurity, surging hormones and confusion about who we are (Im talking about adolescence, though it can go on forever), the best friend may be the most stabilizing force in our lives. Pinky swear.

title: Golfers Embrace CBD, Even as Its Gentility Is Questioned
description: Billy Horschel went six months without a top-eight finish last year before he found a remedy for his ailing golf game from a surprising source: the hemp plant. Horschel, a five-time PGA Tour winner, began using cannabidiol, or CBD, products shortly after he missed the cut at the British Open in July. He had four top-eight finishes in the next four months and was playing some of the most consistent golf of his career before the season was suspended in March because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Valry Giscard dEstaing, Ex-French President, Accused of Groping Journalist
description: PARIS  A German journalist has accused former President Valry Giscard dEstaing of France of groping her after a 2018 interview at his office in Paris, an episode that she said she had decided to make public now in a demonstration of the continuing influence of the #MeToo movement.

title: The Disastrous Employment Numbers Show Almost Every Job Is at Risk
description: The jobs numbers were the catastrophe everybody was expecting.

title: Locked Down on V-E Day, Europe Celebrates World War II Liberation
description: PARIS  There were no poignant handshakes with veterans. Military parades were canceled. Wreaths were laid, but with appropriate social distancing.

title: India Starts Bringing Home Hundreds of Thousands Stranded Amid Coronavirus
description: NEW DELHI  Sixty-four flights. Two naval ships. A dozen countries. And 15,000 stranded Indians.

title: In Court Document, Tara Reades Ex-Husband Said She Spoke of Harassment
description: Tara Reade complained to her ex-husband during the 1990s that she had been a victim of sexual harassment while working in Joseph R. Biden Jr.s Senate office, court records show, providing the first contemporaneous record supporting her claims that sexual misconduct occurred when she worked for Mr. Biden.

title: Stop drinking bad coffee. Make your own expensive fancy cup at home.
description: Its time to get serious about being your own barista.

title: F.D.A. Clears First Home Saliva Test for Coronavirus
description: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that it had granted emergency authorization for the first at-home saliva collection kit to test for the coronavirus.

title: The Appalling Damage of Dropping the Michael Flynn Case
description: Criminal law specialists and members of the law enforcement community are tough to really shock. But the Justice Departments announcement that it would drop criminal charges against Michael Flynn, President Trumps former national security adviser, has provoked, in addition to outrage, a sense of utter demoralization among them. Theyve never seen such a thing before. After all, Mr. Flynn twice pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I.

title: Trump Praises Barr and Revels in Dismissal of Charges Against Flynn
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump responded on Friday to the Justice Departments decision to drop criminal charges against his former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn by delivering his most extensive and aggrieved remarks on the Russia investigation since the arrival of the coronavirus.

title: Ian Whitcomb, Rocker Turned Pop Music Historian, Dies at 78
description: Ian Whitcomb, who had a rock n roll hit in 1965 with You Turn Me On before becoming a celebrated historian and performer of forms of popular music that peaked decades before rock, died on April 19 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 78.

title: Child in N.Y. Dies and Rare Syndrome Tied to Virus Is Suspected
description: A child died in a Manhattan hospital on Thursday from what appeared to be a rare syndrome linked to the coronavirus that causes life-threatening inflammation in critical organs and blood vessels of children, the hospital said.

title: Latinos Face Crisis Upon Crisis
description: MIAMI  With decades of effort and dedication, Arturo Morales built a life for himself in the United States. In a matter of days, the coronavirus nearly destroyed it all.

title: Russia Was Ready to Celebrate a Glorious Past. The Present Intervened.
description: MOSCOW  As the coronavirus began its silent but relentless march on Moscow in February, the names of the millions of Russian soldiers killed in the far deadlier horrors of World War II were already appearing, one by one, on state television, scrolling down the screen in a harrowing torrent.

title: You Dont Need Whiskey for an Old-Fashioned, or Vodka for a Cosmo
description: Comfort is often sought in the familiar: sitcom reruns, well-worn books, family recipes, even an old relationship. Just as something from our past can act as a balm when the future feels uncertain, so, too, can a classic cocktail.

title: Is Death Diving the Future of TV?
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Oh, Good, the Kids Are Fighting Again
description: The wails. The screeching. One more conference call interrupted.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend. Maybe you are getting creative to celebrate Mom (Happy Mothers Day to moms of all stripes). Maybe you are finally hopping on the sourdough bandwagon or just reading a good book. Whatever you are doing, take some time to read some great journalism.

title: Upstate Will Be First to Test New Yorks Arts Appetite
description: About an hours drive from New York City, ensconced in a thicket of greenery near the bank of the Hudson River, the Dia:Beacon art museum has been sitting empty for nearly two months. Mostly empty.

title: For Lemon Lovers
description: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Im back from maternity leave, though back in the current moment means Im quarantined at home with a laptop and an entire carafe of coffee. Thank you to Julia Moskin for filling in.

title: What Real Freedom Looks Like
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.

title: Behind the Cover: Voting
Taking on Covid-19, South Africa Goes After Cigarettes and Booze, Too
description: JOHANNESBURG  The dealer had a stash, but the young woman wasnt getting through the door without an introduction. Thats where her friend, already a trusted customer, came in. And even then there were complications.

title: Union Garment Workers Fear an Opportunity to Get Rid of Us
description: Myan Mode, a garment factory on the outskirts of Yangon, Myanmar, produces mens jackets, womens blazers and coats for Western fashion companies like Mango and Zara. Since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, it has seen a decrease in orders from international retailers.

title: Dropping the Charges Against Michael Flynn
description: To the Editor:

title: Found Unresponsive at Home: Grim Records Recount Lonely Deaths
description: MIAMI  A 71-year-old woman with nausea who was sent home from the emergency room, even though a doctor wanted to admit her. A 63-year-old nurse who was self-isolating while she waited for results from her coronavirus test. A 77-year-old man who was prescribed antibiotics by a doctor in another state for his fever and dry cough.

title: A Vibrant Celebration of Moroccan Design
description: As a few faint rain drops began to fall in the courtyard of Riad Mena, a seven-room guesthouse in the Marrakesh medina, the hotelier Philomena Schurer Merckoll looked skyward, assessing the likelihood of a downpour. This was in February, when a seasonal shower was the biggest threat to a social gathering, and at risk beneath the citrus trees were white linen sofas and red silk-embroidered floor cushions, laid out for cocktail hour before a dinner in honor of Marrakeshs design talent. But with artworks arriving and her guests expected, she shrugged at the massing clouds, determined the evening should go on. The furniture was taken inside and then reassembled an hour later once the shower had passed. Looking back now, from a radically altered world of shelter-in-place orders and social distancing, guests fondly recall the evening as one of the last when they were able to mingle freely with friends old and new. Its wonderful to remember that dinner now, said Schurer Merckoll late last month. It feels so special because it gives me hope for more positive times to come.

title: The Angry Children Are Our Future
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

title: The First Signs of Travels Return?
description: Covid-19 has upended daily life in much of the world for so long that the idea of traveling to another country or state seems like the stuff of dreams. But in the last week or so, as the idea of opening up to travelers has gained traction, some countries are taking concrete steps. Yesterday, Australia announced a three-stage plan to reopen the economy, which includes a focus on tourism. And some countries are forming regional alliances designed to minimize the risk of the virus, including an Australia-New Zealand travel bubble, and, in Europe, a travel corridor shared by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

title: After Fanfare for Baseball, Soccer Is Also Back in South Korea
description: Jeonbuk 1, Suwon Bluewings 0.

title: A Question of Theme
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Make the Most of Potatoes
description: Cheap, nourishing, eminently available and fuss-free, the humble potato is just the thing for these days and weeks of stay-at-home, nearly nonstop cooking.

title: Love Letter: A Mother-Daughter Bond Enhanced by Stillness
description: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

title: With Four More Shots Please!, India Gets Its Own Sex and the City
description: When the HBO series Sex and the City first arrived on TV screens in 1998, sex had become the reigning political story, according to the writer Julie Salamon. The show was a product and a catalyst of a zeitgeist in which financially independent and imperfect women had carved out a space for themselves and their casual, raging sex lives.

title: This Rich Challah May Be as Good as a Hug From Mom
description: After several weeks of hospitalization (unrelated to Covid-19), my mother is back home, snug and settled in the same Brooklyn house where I grew up. To celebrate that, and Mothers Day, I baked her a challah.

title: Paul Shelden, Clarinetist and Classical Music Advocate, Dies at 79
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Talking to Children About Job Loss During the Pandemic
description: Even as some states are reopening, many parents face telling their children that things they were looking forward to are effectively still canceled for them  because they can no longer afford them.

title: Plan to Remove a Million-Pound Granite Sculpture Draws Fire
description: Explorers affiliated with the National Geographic Society have a long history of surmounting stone in places like Mount Everest. But the 130-year-old organization has decided that more than a million pounds of artfully placed granite are in the way of plans to expand its headquarters in Washington.

title: White-Collar Companies Race to Be Last to Return to the Office
description: Even as President Trump has said we have to get our country open again, much of corporate America is in no rush to return employees to their campuses and skyscrapers. The companies are racing not to be the first back, but the last.

title: With Hollywood Productions on Hold, Documentary Filmmakers Keep Going
description: Jehane Noujaim and Karim Amer know about putting themselves at risk for their work. While they were shooting thousands of hours of footage for The Square, the 2013 documentary directed by Ms. Noujaim and produced by Mr. Amer on the popular uprising in Cairo, they were often in the middle of the action in Tahrir Square, where the military shot protesters and dispersed crowds with tear gas. Some of their footage was confiscated, and Ms. Noujaim was arrested and held for 36 hours.

title: Arrests in the Killing of Ahmaud Arbery
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget Pancakes. Pay Mothers.
description: After just six days of sheltering in place, I found myself thinking about all the women Id taken for granted.

title: 7 Tips for Watching Birds During the Spring Lockdown
description: We find comfort in nature. The psychological benefits are well documented: Spending time with grass and trees and birds, even through a window, makes us feel happier and more relaxed. Its inspiring and reassuring to remember that birds are migrating north right now, as they have for millenniums. The earth turns, and birds follow the rhythms of daily and yearly cycles.

title: Federal Watchdog Says Coronavirus Whistle-Blower Should Be Reinstated as It Investigates
description: WASHINGTON  A federal investigative office has found reasonable grounds to believe that the Trump administration was retaliating against a whistle-blower, Dr. Rick Bright, when he was ousted from a government research agency combating the coronavirus  and said he should be reinstated for 45 days while it investigates, his lawyers said Friday.

title: Inside a House in Queens, a Dark Side of the Immigrant Story
description: MY MOTHERS HOUSEBy Francesca Momplaisir

title: No Return to the Old Dispensation
description: In T.S. Eliots Journey of the Magi, the three wise kings, having witnessed the birth of Christ at the end of a long and difficult journey, return home to find themselves no longer at ease here, in the old dispensation.

title: On Ahmaud Arberys Birthday, Thousands Say #IRunWithMaud
description: On Friday, Ahmaud Arbery would have turned 26.

title: For Canada, Finding a Vaccine Will Only Be Part of the Equation
description: As many provinces ease up on some coronavirus restrictions  notably in Quebec, which has decided to reopen some schools  the discussion about vaccines has been increasing.

title: Myles Coker, 69, Dies; Freed From a Life Term in Prison
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: With Push From Trump, Senate Moves to Install Contentious Filmmaker at U.S. Media Agency
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republican leaders, under pressure from President Trump to install an ally who would dictate more favorable news coverage of his administration, are moving to swiftly confirm a conservative filmmaker to lead the independent agency in charge of state-funded media outlets.

title: Chess Thrives Online Despite Pandemic
description: It was 8 a.m. Tuesday in St. Louis when the American chess grandmaster Fabiano Caruana, ranked second best in the world, moved his pawn to E4.

title: When Murder Hornets Are Better News
description: When should The Daily not be about the pandemic? Weve been wrestling with that question. The coronavirus is, perhaps, the biggest story weve covered since the show was launched in 2017. It has disrupted and upended every corner of our lives. And there is no end in sight.

title: What Is the Best Book a Teacher Ever Recommended to You?
description: Those of us who are readers often owe a lot to our teachers. To mark the end of Teacher Appreciation Week, we thought wed take a moment to reflect on the most influential books we picked up thanks to a teacher who slipped a book into our hands, assigned a particular novel or reached out with a thoughtful recommendation.

title: Protests, Calls for Justice in Georgia Over Ahmaud Arbery Killing
description: A crowd of protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Georgia to demand a thorough investigation into the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after a father and son were arrested, and charged with murder.

title: Denis Goldberg, South African Freedom Fighter, Is Dead at 87
description: Denis Goldberg, one of two surviving political activists convicted in the so-called Rivonia Trial, which put Nelson Mandela and seven others in prison for many years and proved a turning-point in South Africas long struggle against apartheid, died on April 29 in Cape Town. He was 87.

title: Ohio State Pays $41 Million to Settle Claims From Doctors Abuse
description: Ohio State University said Friday it would pay $41 million to resolve some of the lawsuits stemming from several hundred sexual assault claims made against a doctor for the schools athletic department. The payouts to 162 people represent close to half the former athletes and other students who have filed lawsuits against the university because of assaults committed by Richard H. Strauss during his nearly 20 years as a team doctor.

title: California to Mail All Voters Ballots for November Election
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Friday ordered ballots to be sent to the states 20.6 million voters for the November election, becoming the first state to alter its voting plans for the general election in response to the public health concerns wrought by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Haphazard Rollout of Coronavirus Drug Frustrates Doctors
description: When the Food and Drug Administration granted an emergency approval last week for an antiviral drug, remdesivir, to treat hospitalized coronavirus patients, many doctors were overjoyed. The drug is the first shown to be even mildly effective against the virus.

title: Daisy Lucidi, a Radio Voice With a Telenovela Following, Dies at 90
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: 10 Eclectic Homes to Get Lost In
description: Months into collective efforts to flatten the curve, those of us lucky enough to be working remotely may be feeling overly familiar with our own homes, rooms once traveled through quite casually on our way to somewhere else and that must now function as our entire world. Inevitably, they fall short, and we start to imagine ourselves  worry-free  in different, better versions. Zoom calls and Instagram Live clips taunt us with small slivers of alternatives  intimacy has, in so many ways, been curtailed, and yet were getting glimpses into spaces weve never seen before. Perhaps you, too, have been distracted by the poster, stack of books or unusually colored wall behind the person on the other end of the platform and wondered about what is just out of view and what it might reveal about its owners true essence.

title: Millie Small, My Boy Lollipop Singer, Is Dead at 73
description: Millie Small, the Jamaican singer whose 1964 hit, My Boy Lollipop, introduced the upbeat rhythms of ska to international audiences, died on Tuesday in London. She was 73.

title: 6ix9ine Returns With New Song and Defiant Livestream: I Ratted
description: On Friday afternoon, the rapper and Instagram star 6ix9ine released a new song, Gooba  the first new music he has put out since a federal judge in April allowed him to finish the remaining months of his two-year sentence for racketeering and other charges in home confinement.

title: Satish Gujral, Versatile Indian Artist, Is Dead at 94
description: Satish Gujral, one of Indias best-known artists, was always game to try something new.

title: Jobs Report, Ahmaud Arbery, Mothers Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Be Your Own Spin Class
description: Rooms full of dozens of bikes packed together, music blaring, instructors shouting a mix of directions and motivational messages, and participants whooping as if they are at a sold-out concert at Madison Square Garden.

title: Soccer Arrives at a Fork in the Road
description: Enjoying this newsletter? Tell a friend to sign up at nytimes.com/rory and then youll have something new to talk about every Friday.

title: Ahmaud Arbery Shooting: A Timeline of the Case
description: Ahmaud Arbery loved to run. A former high school football standout, he had been jogging near his home on the outskirts of Brunswick, Ga., when he was shot and killed after being pursued by two white men with guns, according to the authorities.

title: Argentina Teeters on Default, Again, as Pandemic Guts Economy
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina is hurtling toward default on international loans in two weeks, a prospect that threatens to revive its reputation as a serial deadbeat and global financial pariah that could haunt the Latin American country long after the coronavirus pandemic is over.

title: Ben Benson, Who Put Singles in a Bar and Steak on the Tables, Dies at 89
description: People used to call Ben Bensons the most famous steakhouse nobodys ever heard of.

title: Tesla Tells Workers It Will Reopen California Factory Despite County Order
description: Tesla told employees it would restart its factory in Fremont, Calif., on Friday. But the electric car companys plans do not comply with a local government order that has not cleared large manufacturers to resume operations.

title: In Flynn Case, Barr Again Takes Aim at Mueller Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after admitting guilt to a federal judge in December 2017 for lying to the F.B.I., Michael T. Flynn issued a statement saying what he did was wrong, and through my faith in God, I am working to set things right.

title: Motoko Fujishiro Huthwaite, 92, Last of the Monuments Women, Dies
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: You Will Not Live to See Your Next Birthday
description: New Years Eve, 1943. Lajos Stillmann is celebrating his 22nd birthday with friends in a Budapest apartment. Someone suggests paying a visit to a nearby palm reader. Stillmann goes along, reluctantly. The palm reader takes a look at his hand, then tells him she would rather not say what shes seen.

title: Overlooked No More: June Almeida, Scientist Who Identified the First Coronavirus
description: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

title: N.B.A. Opens for Practice, but Few Show Up
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers and the Portland Trail Blazers were the only clubs to unlock their practice facilities Friday, reflecting the cautious approach many franchises and players adopted on the first day that roughly half of the N.B.A.s 30 teams had clearance to reopen after a shutdown of nearly two months.

title: After a Killing, Running While Black Stirs Even More Anxiety
description: Tell us about your experience running while black in the form at the end of this article.

title: A Bit of Relief: Rick Steves Travel Dreams
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Dropping of Flynn Case Heightens Fears of Justice Dept. Politicization
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump and his supporters on Friday praised Attorney General William P. Barrs decision to drop the prosecution of Michael T. Flynn, even as career law enforcement officials warned that the action set a disturbing precedent and Democrats accused the administration of further politicizing the Justice Department.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Its becoming clear that the coronavirus is not going to simply vanish after restrictions are lifted, epidemiologists say, despite the recent optimistic forecast from the White House.

title: Two White House Coronavirus Cases Raise Question of if Anyone Is Really Safe
description: WASHINGTON  In his eagerness to reopen the country, President Trump faces the challenge of convincing Americans that it would be safe to go back to the workplace. But the past few days have demonstrated that even his own workplace may not be safe from the coronavirus.

title: Roberts Rejects Request for Inquiry into D.C. Appeals Court Vacancy
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Friday turned down a request from the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to designate another court to conduct an ethics inquiry into the circumstances surrounding a retirement from what is widely viewed as the second-most important court in the nation.

title: Ahmaud Arbery Video Was Leaked by a Lawyer Who Consulted With Suspects
description: For weeks after Ahmaud Arbery was killed while running down a road in coastal southern Georgia, there were few public developments in the case of a 25-year-old unarmed black man who was shot while being pursued by two white men with weapons in February.

title: The Man Who Taught Australia How to Mix a Proper Drink
description: A couple of decades ago, I took the long trip from New York to Queensland to visit my family for Christmas. My birthday falls in early January, and I told my brother that Id like to go out for some cocktails to celebrate. He looked perplexed  there werent many cocktails to be found in Queensland back then.

title: What Colombia Did With American Spy Tools
description: Old habits die hard, so theres something sadly unsurprising in the news that a Colombian army unit used American surveillance equipment, provided to fight Marxist guerrillas and drug traffickers, to spy on journalists, political opponents and public figures. Its entirely possible that one important goal was to conceal that the fight was dirty and not going particularly well.

title: A Drug Cocktail Hastens Recovery in Some Coronavirus Patients
description: Patients with mild to moderate Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, appeared to improve more quickly if they were treated with a three-drug cocktail, compared with a group receiving just a two-drug combination, scientists reported on Friday.

title: Georgia Killing Puts Spotlight on a Police Forces Troubled History
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga.  When the Glynn County Police Department arrived at the scene of a fatal shooting in February in southeastern Georgia, officers encountered a former colleague with the victims blood on his hands.

title: No Charges for Parents of 5-Year-Old Who Took to the Highway in an S.U.V.
description: The parents of a 5-year-old boy will not face charges after their son was pulled over while driving on a Utah highway, hoping to make it to California to buy a Lamborghini, a prosecutor said Friday.

title: 2 Fugitives Arrested in Fatal Dispute Over Mask at Family Dollar Store
description: Two fugitives sought in connection with the fatal shooting of a security guard at a Family Dollar store in Michigan over a dispute about a customer not wearing a face mask have been arrested, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Disquisition
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Today we have another fun themeless grid from Erik Agard and a new sidekick, perhaps more evidence that his Crossword Collaboration efforts are paying off. Im biased, but I love Saturday and Sunday debuts. Lately Ive been thinking of how nice it would be to have one more day between Saturday and Sunday to create a three-day weekend, and to have a spot to put really hard daily puzzles. Maybe we could pull something off like this while everyones distracted.

title: Roy Horn, Who Dazzled Audiences as Half of Siegfried & Roy, Dies at 75
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Quotation of the Day: Churches Weigh the Risk of Reopening Their Doors
description: Weve somehow maintained a real intimacy and sweetness because we leaned into the values that always held us.

title: What Time is U.F.C. 249? Streaming and Full Details
description: The Ultimate Fighting Championship is back.

title: Corrections: May 9, 2020
description: An article on Friday about countries efforts to safely reopen their economies misstated the surname of the director of the Center for Health Security at Johns Hopkins University. He is Tom Inglesby, not Tom Inglesbury.

title: Coronavirus Forces Gulf States to Reckon With Their Scores of Migrant Workers
Andrs Iniesta Plots a Return to Barcelona, Where the Beauty Is Gone
description: From 6,500 miles away, Andrs Iniesta has been contemplating his return. He doesnt know when it will be, or under what circumstances, but he is sure he wants to go back to F.C. Barcelona.

title: One-Third of All U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Are Nursing Home Residents or Workers
description: In at least 14 states, more than half of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities for older adults, according to a New York Times database.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Spaceship Earth and Valley Girl
description: SPACESHIP EARTH (2020) Stream on Hulu. This documentary takes viewers inside Biosphere 2 (known as No. 2 because Biosphere 1 is the Earth), an experimental research facility that was built by a Texas oil tycoon to prove that humans could remain healthy while quarantining in a bubble. Built in Oracle, Ariz., with its own mini-rainforest, desert and ocean with a living coral reef, the idyllic bubble was meant to prepare scientists for space colonization. But in 1991, when the first eight scientists sealed themselves inside the terrarium-like habitat for the two-year experiment, things went awry. Directed by Matt Wolf (Teenage), this film looks at the odd and dark twists that took place in the utopian biosphere.

title: The Collateral Damage of the Coronavirus
description: They are ad executives, handymen, servers and wedding D.J.s. They worked in law firms and hotels and retail stores and concert halls. As the outbreak spread, the coronavirus sucked workers from every corner of the American economy.

title: Its Hard When You Cant Go Anywhere: Life Inside an Assisted Living Facility
description: We gave disposable cameras to six residents of Evergreen Gardens, a long-term-care residence in Colorado, so they could document their days during the coronavirus pandemic. These are their photographs.

title: The Book That Shaped Foreign Policy for a Generation Has More to Say
description: Lurching from crisis to crisis and assailed even by allies for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, the United States has rarely seemed more absent from the international stage, or more urgently in need of defining its role in world affairs. This may be a good time, therefore, to look back at a book from another era when fundamental questions about foreign policy were being asked  and answered.

title: Fight Over Viruss Death Toll Opens Grim New Front in Election Battle
description: The claim was tailor-made for President Trumps most steadfast backers: Federal guidelines are coaching doctors to mark Covid-19 as the cause of death even when it is not, inflating the pandemics death toll.

title: Theres Money Stuck in Your Dependent Care Account. Now What?
description: You did everything right. You read the email from human resources and signed up for a dependent care account. Your employer siphons pretax money from your paycheck, and youll get a little back upon request after paying each day care bill, or in a lump sum after covering summer camp costs.

title: Will Coronavirus Kill Astrology?
description: If ever there was one, Susan Miller would be a blue-chip astrologer. So, in January, when she appeared on CBS New York and predicted that 2020 would be a great year, and it will be a prosperous year, people listened.

title: As Job Losses Mount, Lawmakers Face a Make-or-Break Moment
description: WASHINGTON  As the nation confronts unemployment levels not seen since the Great Depression, Congress and the Trump administration face a pivotal choice: Continue spending trillions trying to shore up businesses and workers, or bet that state reopenings will jump-start the United States economy.

title: A Novelist Breaks the Code of Being a Woman in Japan
description: TOKYO  To explain the pressure felt by women in Japanese society, the novelist Mieko Kawakami recalls a playground prank from elementary school.

title: Singles Have to Think Outside the Screen
description: Before the coronavirus pandemic hit, Cedric DuBose of Houston was completing a nine-week online course called Love Alchemy. The workshop, intended to get him thinking about his relationship skills, was a prerequisite to hiring Amari Ice, a Washington-based matchmaker.

title: The Class Divide: Remote Learning at 2 Schools, Private and Public
description: For Rachel Warachs class, the 133rd morning of first grade, numbered on a poster board behind her, was similar to all of the previous mornings.

title: The Grapelord of Napa Faces a Threat Worse Than Plague
description: One balmy winter afternoon, Andy Beckstoffer, a grape grower who has done more than nearly anyone to shape the premium U.S. wine industry, was sitting in Mustards, a restaurant in Napa Valley that is a kind of clubhouse for the vintner class.
