description: At Hope Cemetery in Barre, Vt., a five-ton granite bench sits on a triangle of grass. It is a mere five feet high and three feet deep, which seems modest in scale relative to the calamity it commemorates.

title: A Study Said Covid Wasnt That Deadly. The Right Seized It.
description: Last month, a group of Stanford University researchers released a remarkable study: Covid-19 infections in Santa Clara County, Calif., might well be 85 times higher than official estimates. The fatality rate for coronavirus might be as low as 0.12 percent, the researchers concluded, which would make Covid-19 only as deadly as the seasonal flu.

title: How to Reopen America Safely
description: In late February, as data on the coronavirus pandemic continued to unfold, I started making calls to friends and family to prepare them. I told them to get ready to hunker down for three months. For many then, it was hard to believe that a virus we couldnt much see evidence of, less understand, would require us to shut down our economy.

title: The Sheer Number of School Districts Is Tilting the Playing Field
description: If we really want to balance school budgets in the wake of the coronavirus  and create more long-term equity in our public school system  we need to come to terms with the idea that we need far fewer than the 13,000 school districts that are currently in operation in the United States.

title: What I Want the Woman Behind the Counter to Know
description: I wanted some noodles.

title: Trump White House Changes Its Story on Michael Flynn
description: WASHINGTON  After announcing that the Justice Department was dropping the criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, Attorney General William P. Barr was presented with a crucial question: Was Mr. Flynn guilty of lying to the F.B.I. about the nature of phone calls he had with the Russian ambassador to the United States?

title: Thousands Are Headed to Alaskas Fishing Towns. So Is the Virus.
description: The people of Cordova, Alaska, had weathered the coronavirus pandemic with no cases and the comfort of isolation  a coastal town unreachable by road in a state with some of the fewest infections per capita in the country.

title: Thursdays Livestreaming Events: A 1985 Prince Concert, Elvis Costello, Sheryl Crow and More
description: Here are a few of the best events happening on Thursday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

title: Hotels vs. Airbnb: Has Covid-19 Disrupted the Disrupter?
description: Airbnb, born in 2008, famously disrupted the hotel industry. It stole market share, put pressure on hotel rates, inspired the creation of affordable brands and saw hotels across the spectrum create restaurants, bars and lobbies that channeled the local vibe. Airbnbs recent layoff of a quarter of its work force indicates the financial strain the company is under. Now the question is: Has Covid-19 disrupted the disrupter?

title: Bill Barrs Junk Justice
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

title: Praying Mantises: More Deadly Than We Knew
description: A praying mantis watches intently as a fly bobs by. In less than a blink, shes snatched it up. When the tape is played back in slow motion, we see the mantis pause and calibrate, almost like an experienced baseball catcher who has realized shes dealing with a knuckleball.

title: A Black Holes Boomerangs
description: Astronomers have deciphered the dynamics of yet another great trick that monster black holes can play.

title: As Unemployment Soars, Lawmakers Push to Cover Workers Wages
description: WASHINGTON  One of the most progressive lawmakers in the House and one of the most conservative in the Senate, staring down a pandemic-driven unemployment rate at its highest level since the Great Depression, have come to the same conclusion: Its time for the federal government to cover workers salaries.

title: Outside Egypt, Critics Speak Freely. Inside, Families Pay the Price.
description: CAIRO  When a popular Egyptian blogger shared gruesome video of a military officer severing the finger of an unidentified body and setting the body on fire, it was some of the most shocking footage to emerge from Sinai, where Egypts military has been battling Islamist militants in a hidden war.

title: Quarantining With a Ghost? Its Scary
description: It started with the front door.

title: Meat Plant Closures Mean Pigs Are Gassed or Shot Instead
description: One Minnesota hog farmer sealed the cracks in his barn and piped carbon dioxide through the ventilation system. Another farmer has considered gassing his animals after loading them into a truck. And a third shot his pigs in the head with a gun. It took him all day.

title: How Do You Maintain Dignity for the Dead in a Pandemic?
description: Nick Farenga stood amid the body bags in a refrigerated 18-wheel trailer at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center in Manhattan. This is him, a hospital worker said, pointing to a white body bag among the roughly 40 others lying on wooden platforms that resembled hastily constructed bunk beds. As a funeral director in the Bronx, Farenga has spent two months on the front lines of Covid-19, picking up dozens of bodies. Yet somehow, until that day in late April, he had escaped the pain of retrieving the body of someone he loved. Philip Foglia was Farengas former Little League coach. He and his brother, Sal, played baseball with Foglias sons; the families lived just blocks apart; their fathers were longtime friends.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: As Pandemic Wrecks Budgets, States Cut and Borrow to Balance Books
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Saga of Michael Flynn
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Coronavirus, Michael Flynn, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
description: When the coronavirus lockdowns began almost two months ago, the outdoors seemed like a scary place. It was where you could get infected by a neighbor, jogger, public bench, doorknob or any number of other things. The better move, as a popular hashtag put it, was to #StayHome.

title: The American Way of Life Is Shaping Up to Be a Battleground
description: Chris Christie, a Trump supporter and a former New Jersey governor, pleaded with Americans on May 5 to risk disease and death by returning to work. Everybody wants to save every life they can, he said, but weve got to let some of these folks get back to work. Otherwise were going to destroy the American way of life in these families.

title: Heres How Wuhan Plans to Test All 11 Million of Its People for Coronavirus
description: Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus pandemic began, has announced an ambitious plan to test all of its 11 million residents for the virus in the coming days, a campaign that will be closely watched by governments elsewhere.

title: On Politics: Stay at Home? States Cant Agree
description: Vice President Mike Pence wore a mask as he arrived at the White House on Wednesday.

title: Fourteen Review: An Intertwined Friendship Unravels
description: The bittersweet character drama Fourteen examines a friendship that seems like it should last forever. Despite their differences, Mara (Tallie Medel) and Jo (Norma Kuhling) have been close since childhood. Theyve been friends long enough to have secrets from each other, and theyre close enough to know those secrets dont really matter. The film around them is like their friendship  intellectual and loving, with a little too much left unsaid.

title: Graves Without a Name Review: An Impossible Quest in Cambodia
description: For years, people in the arts or in journalism have, in conversation, said of their vocation, I didnt choose it; it chose me. At times this is an at least half-glib attempt to rationalize the often nonremunerative nature of their endeavors. But the truism gains some heft if looked at from a different angle.

title: The Wolf House Review: A Different Kind of Quarantine
description: Did you ever wonder what it might be like to be one of the three pigs of childrens story and animated cartoon fame? Is this a bad time to ask that question? Bear with me.

title: The Wrong Missy Review: Bad Romance
description: In The Wrong Missy, the twerpy bank executive Tim (David Spade) has just met his dream girl  and his nightmare. Trouble is, both women are named Melissa, and though he intended to text Melissa, the former Miss Maryland (Molly Sims), an invite to his company retreat in Hawaii (along with a selfie of his unmentionables), hes accidentally made Melissa the motormouth (Lauren Lapkus) his plus-one, a feral lonely heart who forces a dog tranquilizer and a nonconsensual sex act on Tim before their plane has landed in paradise.

title: Indias Maximum City Engulfed by Coronavirus
description: The coronavirus problem that India had feared is becoming reality in Mumbai.

title: Can You Break the Pull of a ZIP Code? Most Cant
description: Our cities teachers on how childrens neighborhoods at birth shape their lives.

title: What Satya Nadella Thinks
description: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

title: Five of New Yorks 10 Regions Can Begin to Reopen on Friday
description: A five-county section of central New York that includes Syracuse has met the criteria necessary to begin reopening some businesses on Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Thursday.

title: Malaysia Drops Charges Against Wolf of Wall Street Producer in 1MDB Case
description: BANGKOK  A Malaysian court on Thursday dismissed money laundering charges against the Hollywood producer Riza Aziz, a stepson of the countrys disgraced former prime minister Najib Razak, under an agreement in which he will return assets worth more than $107 million.

title: Rolling Shock as Job Losses Mount Even With Reopenings
description: Scattershot reopenings of retail stores, nail salons and restaurants around the country have not halted the flood of layoffs, with the government reporting Thursday that nearly three million people filed unemployment claims last week, bringing the two-month tally to more than 36 million.

title: Amazon to the Rescue of the Fashion World!
description: Finally, Jeff Bezos is really in fashion.

title: Adopting a Pet in California During a Pandemic
description: Good morning.

title: Blood and Money Review: A Deer Hunt Turns Cat-and-Mouse
description: Jim Reed (Tom Berenger), the primary, barely moving part of the backcountry thriller Blood and Money, is not a well man. A retired U.S. Marine whose alcoholism has him coughing blood and wheezing every few steps, Jim subsists on cigarettes, peanut-butter sandwiches and an array of medications. Not your typical action hero, you might think, and youd be right; but that doesnt stop Berenger and his director, John Barr, from spending the next hour and a half trying to prove otherwise.

title: Alice Review: The Escort Experience
description: In the French dramedy Alice, an overextended young mother wakes up one morning to find that her husband has disappeared, having secretly spent her entire inheritance on luxury escorts. Stuck with a mortgage, a furious Alice (Emilie Piponnier) goes to the escort agency frequented by her husband  a bright pink parlor where campy madams titter about their elite clientele. After a chat with a free-spirited escort, Lisa (Chlo Boreham), Alice gives the gig a shot herself.

title: Castle in the Ground Review: Dazed and Used
description: For Henry (Alex Wolff), the 19-year-old unfortunate at the heart of Castle in the Ground, crushing pills for his dying mother (Neve Campbell) is only the first step in a wearyingly familiar journey. And as he gradually transforms from grieving son to endangered opioid addict, his descent is so depressingly predictable that, for the viewer, sticking with this miserablist dependency drama could be quite the challenge.

title: Rich Boss, Young Employee, Angry Wife: It Gets Twisted
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Kensington, Long Island City and Chelsea.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom in Millstone, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Lesson of the Day: A Heartbreak for Children: When the County Fair Is Canceled
description: Featured Article: A Heartbreak for Children: When the County Fair Is Canceled by Dionne Searcey

title: Appeals Court Allows Emoluments Suit Against Trump to Proceed
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court in Virginia on Thursday revived a lawsuit accusing President Trump of violating the Constitution by profiting from his Washington hotel, a decision that will most likely lead the Justice Department to appeal to the Supreme Court to keep the plaintiffs from gathering evidence in the case.

title: Should National Service Be Required for All Young Americans?
description: In Ghana, all young adults who graduate from an accredited university, college or trade school must complete one year of service in agriculture, health, education, local government or rural development.

title: Months After Louisville Police Kill Woman in Her Home, Governor Calls for Review
description: Two months after Louisville police officers fatally shot a woman as they raided her home, Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky said on Wednesday that local, state and federal prosecutors should review the police investigation into the shooting.

title: I Left My Husband Before the Pandemic. Can I Go Back to Him Now?
description: In February, I left my husband after being married for 18 years. We were teen parents who managed to keep it together, and our three amazing kids are almost grown. We were a heck of team, but we put each other through too much. Now, add the coronavirus! Sometimes, I just want to go home to the safety of my husband and have our kids under one roof again. I cant be sure how I would be doing if this virus hadnt come along. But if I go back, Im afraid I wont be able to leave him twice. What should I do?

title: The Shows Delayed, but Theyre Still Keeping Company
description: The revival of Company was in previews and 10 days from opening when Broadway shut down. And opening night was meant to be especially special, timed to the 90th birthday of the musicals composer Stephen Sondheim. Soon after, the shows director, Marianne Elliott, returned to her husband and producing partner, Nick Sidi, and their daughter in London, while one of its stars, Patti LuPone, headed to the Connecticut home she shares with her husband, Matthew Johnston, and their son.

title: A Cop Gets Away With Murder, Italian Style
description: A sleekly self-assured police chief pays an afternoon call on his slinky, kinky mistress. How are you going to kill me today? she purrs. Not only does he do so, but he also takes care to leave incriminating evidence everywhere around her place  daring his minions and superiors to find him guilty. (Is the killer an idiot or what, one investigator wonders.)

title: G.O.P. Defiance of Pennsylvanias Lockdown Has 2020 Implications
description: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

title: An African Literary Festival for the Age of Coronavirus
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For the novelist Maaza Mengiste, the coronavirus lockdowns and stay-at-home measures that have taken hold around the world have brought back the sense of exile she felt when she and her family fled Ethiopia in the 1970s.

title: W.T.O. Chief Quits Suddenly, Adding to Global Turmoil
description: FRANKFURT  The head of the organization charged with bringing a semblance of order to international trade relations resigned unexpectedly Thursday, adding another element of uncertainty to commerce in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic and escalating trade conflicts.

title: Jonathan Adewumi, Who Made Everyone Feel at Home, Dies at 57
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: My Kids Are Allergic to Video Chats
description: Since entering the world of pandemic parenting, Ive found most of my kids behaviors to be reasonably predictable. For example, I knew my strong-willed 8-year-old would not love having me as his teacher; that my attached-at-my-hip 4-year-old would be especially clingy; and that they would both be asking me seemingly nonstop for a snack or to watch a TV show. This has all checked out. But there has been one behavior that has left me puzzled: their disinterest (and often downright disdain) for communicating with their friends online.

title: The Drama Behind Mad Max: Fury Road Nearly Rivaled the Action Onscreen
description: Delays, fatigue, squabbles and harrowing stunts: Our reporter talked to the actors and director about the making of the action masterpiece.

title: For Farmers of Wine Grapes, the Pandemic Sows Doubts
description: Ann Kraemers vineyard, Shake Ridge Ranch, covers 46 acres of rocky hillsides near Sutter Creek, in the Sierra Foothills of California.

title: To Fight Waste and Hunger, Food Banks Start Cooking
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  The new kitchen was still under construction here at the Palm Beach County branch of Feeding South Florida, a food bank, when Chrissy Benoit walked through the warehouse in March. Fruits and vegetables had started arriving in unusually large amounts from nearby farms, which got her thinking about the cooking she would do when the kitchen was finished.

title: As Coronavirus Overruns Russia, Doctors Are Dying on the Front Lines
description: MOSCOW  Dr. Rimma Kamalova says her hospitals leadership ignored her warnings about an unexplained pneumonia outbreak back in March. She kept working.

title: The New Museum Is Offering Strange Stories for Trying Times
description: It is no surprise that the storytelling series Maurizio Cattelan initiated doesnt include Goodnight Moon or The Tale of Peter Rabbit. As an artist, Mr. Cattelan is known for skillfully subverting the expectations of his audience. Instead Bedtime Stories, a new digital offering from the New Museum, features cultural luminaries like David Byrne, Takashi Murakami and Elizabeth Peyton sharing selections from their favorite books, many of which are not standard nighttime fare for children or adults.

title: G.D.P. Doesnt Credit Social Distancing, but It Should
description: The United States is in a deep recession, but the official numbers are missing something big.

title: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
description: A stalwart of the traditional album cycle, Taylor Swift tends to juice her releases harder, and longer, than most artists. With the exception of her debut, she followed up each of her albums with a monthslong, intercontinental stadium tour. Lover, her seventh record, demanded an extra special touch: open, fields, sunsets, + SUMMER, Swift posted on Twitter. Shortly after delivering the album in August, she announced that she would once again be making the rounds with a string of European dates and so-called Lover Fests in the United States, all of which was to start in June.

title: Now Streaming: French Movies for Every Niche
description: While various European film industries were decimated over the decades, France still stands strong, cranking out dozens of movies a year in every genre imaginable.

title: Poor Americans Hit Hardest by Job Losses Amid Lockdowns, Fed Says
description: Households entered the coronavirus shutdown in precarious economic positions that have only worsened as workers are furloughed by the millions, and the challenges are especially acute for the poorest Americans, according to a Federal Reserve survey released Thursday.

title: The Art Collections Are Real; the Owners Are Not
description: Episode 2 of Mrs. America, the new TV show dramatizing the battle over the Equal Rights Amendment, features a glamorous party at the Guggenheim Museum. Its 1972, and Gloria Steinem is launching her new magazine, Ms. She mingles, dances and then talks shop with a fellow womens movement leader, Bella Abzug. As the two walk up the museums ramp, artworks on the walls peek out behind them.

title: Richard Burr Steps Back From Senate Panel as Phone Is Seized in Stock Sales Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Richard M. Burr of North Carolina temporarily stepped down on Thursday as chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, a day after F.B.I. agents seized his cellphone as part of an investigation into whether he sold hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stocks using nonpublic information about the coronavirus.

title: 33 Teen-Chosen Quarantine Reads: The Results of Our Special April Challenge
description: When The Times announced in early April that all high school students in the United States could get three months of free digital access, we created a Special April Challenge to encourage students to first, explore NYTimes.com, and then, tell us what they read, watched or listened to and why. Over 200 teenagers participated, and our judges have chosen favorites, below.

title: E.P.A. Opts Against Limits on Water Contaminant Tied to Fetal Damage
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration will not impose any limits on perchlorate, a toxic chemical compound that contaminates water and has been linked to fetal and infant brain damage, according to two Environmental Protection Agency staff members familiar with the decision.

title: Quartz to Lay Off 80 Employees
description: Quartz, a business news site with offices around the world, is laying off nearly half its staff in a substantial restructuring after the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut into its advertising revenue.

title: The Joys of Fixing Your Own Stuff
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Jerzy Glowczewski, Polish Pilot in a Spitfire, Dies at 97
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: National Service: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear, Trauma, Hope and Calm
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Viewing Party! Lets All Watch Whats Up, Doc?
description: Were feeling loopy and a little loony tunes under lockdown, and bet you are, too. We want to run around in the great outdoors, chase after a pizza-delivery guy and maybe throw a cream pie in someones face, all of which happens in the madcap comedy Whats Up, Doc?

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: I participated this week in a virtual Battle of the Books, hosted by my local bookstore and moderated by James Mustich, the author of 1,000 Books to Read Before You Die. The premise: Persuade the audience to vote for a book that Jim should have included on his list but didnt. The format: Five contestants get four minutes each to make the case for a book of their choosing, from how-to (a cookbook, a feng shui decorating book) to fiction (Jos Saramagos Blindness, Anton Myrers Once an Eagle) to  my pick  The Journals of John Cheever, which I consider his crowning achievement.

title: Whats Going On in This Graph? | Easing Lockdowns
description: Note: This is our final graph for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other graphs you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you dont miss any of our new graphs.

title: Canned Cocktails in Quarantine Make Mixing a One-Step Process
description: Jeff Wuslich, a founder of Cardinal Spirits in Bloomington, Ind., looked over a stack of more than 100 cases of canned cocktails at the distillery. There are three varieties: a Bramble Mule, made with vodka, raspberry juice, hibiscus and ginger; a Maui Mule, made with vodka, passion-fruit juice and ginger; and a vodka soda.

title: Amazons Showdown in France Tests Its Ability to Sidestep Labor
description: PARIS  Workers at Amazons six mammoth French warehouses won some concessions from the company in late March: After hundreds of employees threatened to walk out unless the company better protected them from the coronavirus, the internet giant strengthened social distancing measures, provided masks and hand sanitizer and took employee temperatures.

title: Trumps Criticism of Fauci
description: To the Editor:

title: On Second Viewing, First Impressions Dont Always Hold
description: I hadnt expected Simon Stephenss Sea Wall to come to the rescue. Then suddenly there it was, saving me. A play that ran on Broadway just last summer, it also exists as a quietly gorgeous little film that feels like a gift from the past arriving exactly on time.

title: How to Preserve and Store Your Hearty Greens
description: Whether youre returning from an overambitious trip to the supermarket or organizing an unruly haul from your C.S.A. or farmers market, storing your seasonal bounty can be a challenge. Sturdy greens like kale, collard greens, Swiss chard, mustard greens and others can take up a lot of valuable real estate. You can store them in a fraction of the space  and prolong their life  by simply chilling them raw or cooked, or blanching and freezing them. Heres how.

title: This Atlas of Art and Memory Is a Wonder of the Modern World
description: For most of us, its natural to look at many pictures at the same time. We do it every day via internet searches and digital pinup boards  even refrigerator doors have become ad hoc photo albums.

title: Italian Hostages Release Erupts Into Clashes Over Islam and Ransom
description: ROME  When word surfaced last weekend that a kidnapped 24-year-old Italian aid worker had been released after 18 months in captivity in Africa, Italians were overjoyed after weeks of relentlessly gloomy coronavirus-driven news.

title: Laurie Anderson and Michael Stipe on Music, Art and New Chapters
description: At 72, no one would fault Laurie Anderson, the avant-garde multimedia icon  an inventor, performance artist, musician, writer, filmmaker, painter and more  for being nostalgic. She is best known for her 1981 surprise hit song, O Superman, a visionary tirade against American imperialism, built on looped vocal effects that seemed to predict the next three decades or so of pop music. In recent years, Anderson has been moonlighting as an archivist, shaping the legacy of her husband and collaborator, Lou Reed, who died in 2013. (His archives, which include letters, photographs and recordings, are now housed at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts and are available to anyone with a library card.) But the experience of looking backward, immersed in anothers oeuvre, has only made Andersons own work more forward-looking.

title: Richard Gilder, Donor to Parks, Museum and History, Dies at 87
description: Richard Gilder, a billionaire investor and benefactor who was instrumental in revitalizing two neglected exemplars of American democracy  the study of American history and Central Park  died on Tuesday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 87.

title: Martin Lovett, Last Living Member of the Amadeus Quartet, Dies at 93
description: The Amadeus, a string quartet of extraordinary longevity, set the gold standard in chamber music for four decades after World War II. Their style was a burnish on the Viennese tradition of smooth, lush string playing; they shone above a foundation provided by the solid, undemonstrative voice of their cellist, Martin Lovett.

title: Will the Pandemic Make the West More Vulnerable to Wildfires?
description: The last thing we need right now is another risk to worry about. But across much of the American West, wildfires should be a big concern as summer approaches. This is especially true in Northern California, where the winter of 2019-20 was exceptionally dry and has set the stage for a potentially frightening wildfire season.

title: What Churches Really Think About Opening Up
description: I pastor a church in Sonoma County, Calif., under what has been one of the strictest shelter-in-place orders in the country. We havent met for in-person worship services since March 8. Weve spent the past two months with services, prayer times and Bible studies online. Gov. Gavin Newsom has announced that churches will not be meeting in large assemblies for some time. So with Gods help, prayer and encouragement from one another, were drawing upon deeper spiritual and relational resources as we seek to grow in patience, learn to wait and find new ways to minister to those in need.

title: I Wish I Could Do Something for You, My Doctor Said
description: The day before I got sick, I ran three miles, walked 10 more, then raced up the stairs to my fifth-floor apartment as always, slinging laundry with me as I went.

title: Goodbye to One of the Most Complex Black Women on TV
description: It was the gasp heard in millions of living rooms around the country.

title: Want to Try a Robert Bresson Film? Look to Clint Eastwood
description: Writing about the hard-edged American filmmaker Don Siegel (Dirty Harry), the critic Andrew Sarris once made an offhand observation about Siegels 1979 Escape From Alcatraz, starring Clint Eastwood. Siegel, he wrote, seemed to have been inspired by Robert Bressons A Man Escaped (1956).

title: How We Can Get the Next Phase of the Coronavirus Right
description: Heading into our pandemic summer, my biggest worry is that in the effort to get Americans to flatten the coronavirus curve, nobody prepared the country for what comes next.

title: A Caddies Most Important Measure of Distance? Now Its Six Feet
description: Missy Pederson is eager to get back to work caddying for the two-time major winner Brittany Lincicome on the L.P.G.A. Tour, which is scheduled to resume its season in July, five months after it was suspended because of the coronavirus crisis. Im chomping at the bit, Pederson said on Tuesday in a telephone interview from her home in Minnesota.

title: Yes, Kids Can Get Migraines. Here Are the Signs.
description: A couple of years ago, long before the novel coronavirus was a threat, my son started calling out to us soon after we tucked him in at night. Sometimes he would ask for an extra kiss, back rub or drink of water. All normal for a 5-year-old. But occasionally, he would report that his room looked funny. Things that are close look far, he would say. And things that are far look close.

title: Ralph W. McGehee, Agent Who Exposed the C.I.A., Dies at 92
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: What Students Are Saying About Post-Quarantine Plans, Leadership and Masks
description: For this weeks roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to tell us what they are looking forward to once quarantine ends, describe the qualities they admire in a leader, and detail how their communities are responding to new civic rules in the coronavirus era.

title: Travis McCready Concert Is Postponed, but Not Happily
description: The Arkansas authorities Thursday seized the liquor license of a concert hall planning what had been billed as the first major rock concert since the pandemic, forcing the promoters to delay the show, which was originally scheduled for Friday in Fort Smith.

title: As Virus Ravages Budgets, States Cut and Borrow for Balance
description: In February, Ohio was running a $200 million budget surplus. Then the coronavirus pandemic struck, wiping out the surplus  and then some. Tax revenue plummeted and public health expenses skyrocketed.

title: The Pandemic Helped Topple Two Retailers. So Did Private Equity.
description: J. Crew and Neiman Marcus were each facing a host of issues before the coronavirus pandemic forced them to close their stores and eventually file for bankruptcy, including trouble adjusting to the rise of e-commerce and a lack of connection with a new generation of shoppers.

title: Five: The Accidental Emperor
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

title: Disney Closes Frozen on Broadway, Citing Pandemic
description: Even Queen Elsas magic is no match for the coronavirus pandemic.

title: He Saw No Proof Closures Would Curb Virus. Now He Has De Blasios Trust.
description: As Mayor Bill de Blasio was resisting calls in March to cancel large gatherings and slow the spread of the coronavirus in New York City, he found behind-the-scenes support from a trusted voice: the head of his public hospital system, Dr. Mitchell Katz.

title: Review: Snowpiercer on a New Track
description: It took seven years, and some stops and starts, for the 2013 South Korean film Snowpiercer to get remade as an American television series. It was just long enough for the films director, Bong Joon Ho, to give the show a publicity boost by winning multiple Oscars this year for Parasite, his latest violent allegory about the haves and have-nots.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Theres a reason Indians call Mumbai Maximum City.

title: Furiosas Back: George Miller Discusses the Next Mad Max Movie
description: Its been five years since Mad Max: Fury Road came out in theaters, but if the director George Miller has his way, Furiosa will soon ride again.

title: New Loop, America
description: In our final episode from our living rooms, we visit the dystopia of Westworld and the utopia of Hollywood to see if we can glean anything about what might be in store on the other side of this pandemic  and about who we want to be.

title: Coronavirus May Pose a New Risk to Younger Patients: Strokes
McDonalds Details What Dining In Will Look Like
description: Clean the digital kiosks each time a customer orders. Place closed signs on certain tables to promote social-distancing. Scrub the bathrooms every half-hour.

title: Talking Can Generate Coronavirus Droplets That Linger Up to 14 Minutes
description: Coughs or sneezes may not be the only way people transmit infectious pathogens like the novel coronavirus to one another. Talking can also launch thousands of droplets so small they can remain suspended in the air for eight to 14 minutes, according to a new study.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: It Could Happen Anytime: Scientists Warn of Alaska Tsunami Threat
description: Climate change has increased the risk of a huge landslide in an Alaskan fjord that could cause a catastrophic tsunami, scientists said Thursday.

title: When Can Kids Go Back to Class?
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: Jobless Claims, Food Supply, Rovers: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Senate Approves Surveillance Bill With Sharper Privacy Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Thursday to reinstate a set of expired F.B.I. tools used to investigate terrorism and espionage that lapsed this spring, adopting modest new privacy protections for Americans swept up in national security cases.

title: Paralegal for U.S. Attorney Tipped Off Drug Cartel, Prosecutors Say
description: Just before they were raided by federal agents, drug dealers in San Antonio affiliated with a Mexican cartel moved their stockpiles of heroin, methamphetamine and cocaine.  A paralegal in the federal prosecutors office tipped them off, the authorities said.

title: The Virus Killed an Officer. His Town Lined the Streets to Mourn Him.
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J.  For three weeks, a small town in northern New Jersey kept vigil over Officer Charles Roberts.

title: Behind the Cover: Funeral Homes
T.S.M.C. Is Set to Build a U.S. Chip Facility, a Win for Trump
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company has agreed to build an advanced chip factory in the United States, in a response to the Trump administrations growing concerns about the security of the global electronics supply chain and its competitive tensions with China.

title: Lives Were Lost as Warnings Went Unheeded, Whistle-Blower Tells House
description: WASHINGTON  The whistle-blower who was ousted as the head of a federal medical research agency charged on Thursday that top Trump administration officials failed to heed his early warnings to stock up on masks and other supplies to combat the coronavirus, and that Americans died as a result.

title: Ordinary People Are Leading the Leaders
description: We have entered the endurance phase of this pandemic. We are slowly mastering this disease, but we have not yet done so. And so we wait  and endure.

title: Covid-19 Reality Has a Liberal Bias
description: On Tuesday, the U.S. governments top experts warned that Covid-19 was by no means under control, and that premature easing of social distancing could have disastrous consequences. As far as I can tell, their view is shared by almost all epidemiologists.

title: Biden on Assault Allegation: I Wouldnt Vote for Me if I Believed Tara Reade
description: Capping a day in which he appeared with two Democratic women in the running to be his vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday night that he did not remember Tara Reade, the woman who has accused him of sexual assault, and said that Americans probably shouldnt vote for me if they believe the accusation, which he has strenuously denied.

title: Screams in a Park, a Body With a Tattoo and MS-13 Is Now Accused
description: The 911 callers said they heard screams coming from the woods near a park in Queens.

title: Outsider Tapped in Flynn Case Regarded as Straight Arrow
description: The New York mob boss John J. Gotti rose in court one day in 1991 as he was nearing trial and jabbed his finger at the baby-faced Brooklyn prosecutor handling his case.

title: Navy Reports Describe Encounters With Unexplained Flying Objects
description: Navy fighter pilots reported close encounters with unidentified aerial vehicles, including several dangerously close, in eight incidents between June 27, 2013, and Feb. 13, 2019, according to documents recently released by the Navy.

title: We Need Tuition-Free College. For Adults.
description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan recently announced a plan to make essential pandemic workers in her state eligible for free college. The program will be directed at staff members at hospitals and nursing homes, grocery store clerks, sanitation workers, police officers, delivery people and others working on the front lines to help people in Michigan survive this crisis.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Bid for Virus Protections in Texas Prison
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court denied a request on Thursday from two inmates in a Texas geriatric prison to reinstate a trial judges order instructing officials to take steps to protect them from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: In 3 Key States That Elected Trump, Bitter Divisions on Reopening
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  In Wisconsin, residents woke up to a state of confusion on Thursday after the conservative majority on the State Supreme Court sided with the Republican majority in the Legislature on Wednesday night, overturning a statewide stay-at-home order by Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat.

title: U.S. Prison Population Remained Stable as Pandemic Grew
description: The United States prison population remained stable in the early months of the year, decreasing by just 1.6 percent from January through March even as prisons emerged as incubators for the spread of Covid-19, according to a report released on Thursday.

title: District of Columbia Is Investigating Trump Nominee to Lead Media Agency
description: WASHINGTON  The attorney general for the District of Columbia is investigating whether a conservative filmmaker nominated by President Trump to lead the independent agency in charge of state-funded news outlets illegally enriched himself with funds from a nonprofit organization he runs, according to a top Democratic senator.

title: Trumps Ad Team Blitzes Biden, Spending Millions to Define Him Early in the Race
description: The first wave of long-promised negative ads from the Trump campaign began this week in caustic form, flooding Facebook pages and television screens in swing states with harsh messages that make unfounded inferences about Joseph R. Biden Jr.s mental state and paint the presumptive Democratic nominee as too friendly to the Chinese government.

title: Your Questions: Voting by Mail, Tara Reade, Congressional Travel
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Changing Subject Amid a Pandemic, Trump Turns to an Old Ploy: Blame Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has embarked on an aggressive new drive to rewrite the narrative of the Russia investigation by making dark and unsubstantiated accusations that former President Barack Obama masterminded a sinister plot to bring him down.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Dr. Rick Bright, a top government scientist, went before Congress on Thursday and connected some of the dots of the U.S. response to the coronavirus pandemic. They did not add up to a pretty picture.

title: Trump to Name Brooke Rollins as Domestic Policy Adviser
description: President Trump is naming Brooke Rollins, a conservative lawyer and long-serving White House official, as acting domestic policy adviser, according to two senior administration officials.

title: Giants Deandre Baker and Seahawks Quinton Dunbar Accused of Robbery
description: Arrest warrants were issued Thursday for two N.F.L. players who were accused of armed robbery at a cookout they attended near Miami the night before.

title: Tailgaters Headgear
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Christopher Adams is hard on himself. He says he isnt, but anyone who can offer us a puzzle this entertaining and then go down the rabbit hole of all the ways this could have been better in his constructor notes needs to know that his puzzles really are very good.

title: Corrections: May 15, 2020
description: An article on Wednesday about the potential impacts that Manhattan would face if companies decide to let their employees work from home permanently misspelled the name of the owner of Aux Epices restaurant. She is Mei Chau, not Mei Cahu.

title: Quotation of the Day: After Elmhurst Buckled, State Forced Rare Teamwork Among Hospitals
description: You knew you werent alone in the fight, and that people were listening. That was great for the soul.

title: You Have to Let Go to Move On
description: My dating profile picture, a blurry, distant figure in a desert landscape, suggested a great deal about my ambivalence: I wanted, and I didnt want. At 47, divorced for nearly two decades and with my daughters grown, I cherished my solitude, but sometimes when I heard the mice rustling in the attic, I thought of the newspaper story I had read about a man not far from where I lived who had been found dead in his flat, partly eaten by rats.

title: U.S. and China Trade Coronavirus Accusations, Sparking Fears of a New Cold War
description: On May 1, a visibly relieved Matt Hancock announced that the British government had exceeded its target of 100,000 coronavirus tests a day. As health secretary, Mr. Hancock had set the goal after enduring intense criticism for the countrys lagging coronavirus testing program.

title: Severe Tropical Storm Vongfong Takes Aim at Philippine Heartland
description: MANILA  Tens of thousands of people fled to evacuation centers on Friday as the first typhoon to hit the Philippines this season barreled toward the main island of Luzon, dumping torrential rains and raising fears that the coronavirus could spread in crowded shelters.

title: J.C. Penney Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

title: C.D.C. Issues Reopening Checklists for Schools and Businesses
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday released six flow charts meant to help schools, restaurants, transit systems and other businesses decide when to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic, the agencys first release of such guidance after a more comprehensive draft was rejected by the White House.

title: Coronavirus, U.S. Jobless Claims, Amazon: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Friday: Barber Shop Chronicles and Seberg
description: BARBER SHOP CHRONICLES Stream on Nationaltheatre.org.uk. Barbershops are portrayed as communal spaces where patrons hang out and talk about politics, relationships and masculinity  and maybe also get their hair cut  in Inua Ellamss Barber Shop Chronicles, a play that was a hit in London in 2017. The story bridges six barbershops in six cities, focusing on conversations in each shop over the course of a day. The fleet-footed script is based on recordings of conversations Ellams made in barbershops in Africa and London. The men were just laughing whilst talking about really crazy issues, Ellams said in an interview with The New York Times last year. I had one rule: If a topic comes up three times in three different countries, then it has to go into the play. This production, recorded during the shows run at the National Theater in London, is streaming until late next week as part of a series of free programming being offered during the pandemic.

title: Australia Is Returning to Normal. What Does That Mean?
description: Recently, as coronavirus restrictions began lifting, I met up with my good friend Sofia for a long walk along Sydneys coastline. The weather had turned, finally, from a perennial summer to something chillier, but the ocean was full of the usual smattering of surfers and brave swimmers.

title: Is Lockdown Turning You Into J.D. Salinger?
Word + Quiz: ablation
Drawing
description: Do you like to draw, sketch or doodle? What do you tend to depict when you do? Do you find it meditative? Tell us in the comments.

title: Movie Theaters Are on the Brink. Can Wine and Cheese Save Them?
description: When the Spanish-Revival-style Roxy opened on Broadway in 1927, the 5,900-seat movie theater boasted an enormous pipe organ with three keyboards and its own 110-member symphony orchestra. A mechanical orchestra pit rose and receded before screenings. The theater employed a male chorus, a ballet company and a chorus line called the Roxyettes.

title: Scoob! Review: Once More Into the Mystery Machine
description: At the beginning of Scoob!, the latest Scooby-Doo reboot, directed by Tony Cervone, Velma (voiced by Gina Rodriguez) announces that its time for the gang to take on bigger cases, scarier villains and creepier mysteries. It sounds less like an opportunity than a threat.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Finds a Silver Lining in Whistle-Blowers Testimony
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Coronavirus Seemingly Tamed, Chinese Economy Starts to Recover
description: BEIJING  China has turned its factories back on after bringing the coronavirus outbreak largely under control within its borders. The question now is who will buy the goods those factories make.

title: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Walt Disney, Little Richard
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?

title: Lesson of the Day: Praying Mantises: More Deadly Than We Knew
description: Featured Article: Praying Mantises: More Deadly Than We Knew by Cara Giaimo

title: Eurovisions Canceled, but Not for These Fans
description: LONDON  Last week, Renske ten Veen, a 21-year-old Dutch college student and Eurovision obsessive, took matters into her own hands.

title: House Passes $3 Trillion Relief Bill Seen as Democrats Opening Bid
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: New in Paperback: Walking on the Ceiling and Good Husbandry
description: WALKING ON THE CEILING,  by Aysegul Savas. (Riverhead, 224 pp., $16.) The mysterious Turkish woman who narrates this beguiling debut novel set in Paris and Istanbul likes to walk through her past and, in her imagination, on the ceiling (since she sees no shadows there), wrote our reviewer, Alison McCulloch, to whom the book resembled a stroll: a life captured in short discrete word photographs that form a sweet, sad meditative ramble.

title: Visiting the Museum in My Mind
description: A consideration of artworks that ask the question: What world will we find on the other side of this?

title: Have You Given Yourself a Tattoo Yet?
description: Shaved heads, dyed hair, billowing beards: Many are using their newly found free time to alter their appearances.

title: The Richest Neighborhoods Emptied Out Most as Coronavirus Hit New York City
description: Estimating how many residents left New York City, neighborhood by neighborhood.

title: Dissecting Kissinger, and Other Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape, Torture, Murder, Beheadings  All in a Days Work for Marilyn Stasio
description: The Danish crime writer Jussi Adler-Olsen doesnt fool around. If he wants to creep you out, he knows exactly how to do it. Take this passage from his latest Department Q novel, VICTIM 2117 (Dutton, 480 pp., $28), in which the villain torments a man named Assad by sending him a message about his abducted wife, Marwa. It said that he made sure Marwa lost our third child, Assad discloses, and that he raped Marwa and my daughters every day, and that every time they gave birth, he immediately killed the child. Has a certain sadistic ring to it, doesnt it? Thats how we know we are indeed reading Adler-Olsen, whose style might best be described as literary brutalism.

title: These Debuts Arrived at a Tough Time. They Deserve Your Attention.
description: MEMBERS ONLYBy Sameer Pandya351 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Gyms, Elevators and Coronavirus
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Anna Wintour Is Not the Star of Andr Leon Talleys Memoir. He Is.
description: THE CHIFFON TRENCHESA MemoirBy Andr Leon Talley

title: Killing People in Fiction Was Fun: Mysteries That Have Stood the Test of Time
description: I am, as we all are, stuck at home these days. Back in mid-March I assumed I would spend much of my time in lockdown reading  still and always my favorite activity, ideal for an indefinite period of mandatory solitude imposed by, say, a pandemic. This has not been the case. Ive read fewer books over the past few weeks than I have over any comparable stretch that I can remember. Focus has evaporated. The cognitive load of living through the coronavirus has gone straight for my literary jugular.

title: Finding Solace During This Great Global Pause
description: Is it OK to admit that Im grateful for the isolation of the past few months? Because I am. Im relishing this liminal space, this Great Global Pause.

title: The Postal Service Is the Most American Thing Weve Got
description: It would be difficult to think of a time when we have depended more on the United States Postal Service. With tens of millions of Americans quarantined in their homes, the steady delivery of checks, letters, food and medical supplies is a lifeline.

title: Watching the Pandemic Steal Intimate Moments From Teenagers
description: On a day when my 17-year-old son cant seem to summon the strength to wake up, I worry hes coming down with the coronavirus or that hes slipped into a deep depression. But he tells me that his partner, who is 19 and uses they/them pronouns, is moving into the nursing home where they work. He is listless from the losses of his deli job and the end of his senior year, angry that his partner is in such a compromising situation. Consistently exposed to Covid-19, his partners been forced to make the unfathomable choice of isolating in quarantine or exposing their household.

title: Congress Doesnt Need to Meet in Person
description: This month, in a long overdue change, the Senate finally started holding hybrid hearings, allowing both senators and health experts to appear via videoconferencing as well as in the Senate chamber. This occurred months after other public and private organizations all over the world had already made the transition to remote work. Just last week, the House majority leader introduced rule changes, passed on Friday, allowing the House to follow suit by permitting both remote hearings and remote voting.

title: She Escaped Sex Work for College. Now the Virus Threatens Her New Life.
description: Last fall, toward the end of her first semester in college, Destiny Moura turned in a paper for an English composition class in which she described her introduction, at the age of 14, to the life. The life referred to the exploitation of girls by pimps, traffickers, manipulators.

title: Miss Your Friends? Try Being a Teenager in Love
description: Gabby Rodriguez and Kai Laidhold ask to see each other every day. The answer from their parents is always the same: No.

title: Everybody Was Sick: Inside an ICE Detention Center
description: Last month, Makalay Tarawally propped her 2-month-old in front of her phone so that his father could meet him for the first time, virtually. As a blood technician for a Covid-19 hospital unit, Ms. Tarawally knew how careful she needed to be.

title: DeVos Funnels Coronavirus Relief Funds to Favored Private and Religious Schools
description: WASHINGTON  Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is using the $2 trillion coronavirus stabilization law to throw a lifeline to education sectors she has long championed, directing millions of federal dollars intended primarily for public schools and colleges to private and religious schools.

title: These Large Carnivorous Lizards Are Right Where They Belong
description: You cant accuse a monitor lizard of being a picky eater.

title: Economists Want to Put Stimulus on Autopilot. Congress Has Other Ideas.
description: When there is an economic crisis, you want a government response that is scaled accordingly. But you dont know in advance just how long a crisis will last or how severe it will be.

title: This Summer, Consider Camping in Your Own Backyard
description: Our kids are going to have the weirdest memories of this time, and, ideally, some of them will be beautiful. Or at least comedic. This is where backyard camping comes in. Think smores, stars, the air mattress deflating with a cartoony hiss. Picture your childrens faces, fire-lit and, for just another minute, little. It could happen in farmland, suburbia or the Bronx  and it could be lovely. (And if you dont have access to the outdoors, consider adapting these tips for the middle of your tiny apartments living room.)

title: I Live in Sweden. Im Not Panicking.
description: STOCKHOLM  Its noon here, and from the window of my home office I can see my two daughters playing in the yard at their preschool across the street. I reach for my phone to text my best friend, a nurse who lives in Westport, Conn., to share some family trivia I just discovered. She has been hunkered down in her home with her husband and their two young daughters since March. Shes beginning to wonder what they will lose first  their jobs or their minds.

title: Young Adults Take Refuge in Parents Empty Nests
description: Andrea Yoch loves her adult sons, but would also love to not live with them.

title: How a Nurse Who Gives Last Rites Spends His Sundays
description: No one is meant to see so much death that quickly, said Yaakov Shereshevsky, an I.C.U. nurse at N.Y.U. Langone Health, where the coronavirus outbreak has taken a heavy toll. For a while, he said, eight floors  34 beds on each floor  were devoted to Covid-19 patients, and they were at capacity. At one point, we had 20- and 30-year-olds dying, he said. It was a horrible, brutal, helpless feeling. It felt like there was no light. Now its getting better.

title: Just Because You Can Afford to Leave the City Doesnt Mean You Should
description: The image of cities as caldrons of contagion is a very old one. In the 19th century, rapid urbanization was accompanied by literal squalor and waves of often lethal communicable disease. Life expectancy declined during the Industrial Revolution as cities populations surged.

title: Domestic Violence Calls Mount as Restrictions Linger: No One Can Leave
description: CHICAGO  The woman dialed the hotline from her car. Her partner was laid off from his job after the coronavirus outbreak hit the United States, she told the counselor, who listened from a basement call center in Chicago. He had become more tense and violent than ever. Please help.

title: A 92-Year-Old Piano Teacher Wont Let Students Miss Bach in the Pandemic
description: For more than 50 years, Cornelia Vertenstein, 92, has taught piano lessons from her home in Denver. Every week, through all those years, a parade of children came to her door, books in hand.

title: What Black America Knows About Quarantine
description: On Feb. 23, a 25-year-old black man named Ahmaud Arbery left his home in Brunswick, Ga., to go for a Sunday afternoon run. As he entered a nearby subdivision, he was followed and later shot dead by a father and son while their neighbor recorded the incident on his phone.

title: Trump, Biden and the Myth of But 2016
description: WASHINGTON  At first glance, there seems little in common between red-hat-wearing admirers of President Trump and Democratic activists still nursing PTSD from Hillary Clintons loss. Yet these political opposites share an overriding conviction, one they are apt to invoke any time the presidents re-election prospects are questioned:

title: Obamagate Is a Fake Scandal. Rick Bright Described a Real One.
description: Recently people on the right have started pushing a ludicrous pseudo-scandal theyre calling Obamagate. It holds that investigations by Barack Obamas administration into Russias attack on the 2016 U.S. presidential election were a form of illicit sabotage of Donald Trump and his team. The story doesnt really make sense, which is why, when asked about Obamagate, President Trump couldnt describe it. But at the heart of the conspiracy theory is unmasking, the routine practice by which national security officials find out the names of Americans who appear on intelligence intercepts of foreign actors. Trumpists have tried to turn this into a sinister and portentous term.

title: With Go-Slow Approach, Republicans Risk Political Blowback on Pandemic Aid
description: WASHINGTON  More than eight weeks and almost $2.8 trillion federal dollars into an urgent response to the coronavirus pandemic, congressional Republicans and the Trump administration have made it clear that they are in no rush to engage with Democrats on another round of costly relief measures.

title: Hospitals Knew How to Make Money. Then Coronavirus Happened.
description: When the top-ranked Mayo Clinic stopped all nonemergency medical care in late March, it began to lose millions of dollars a day.

title: Beach Towns Ask: Will There Be Summer?
description: In summer resort towns across the United States, livelihoods for the year are built in the 15 weeks between Memorial Day and Labor Day. It is during those 15 weeks that tourists from around the country and the world arrive to bask on the beach and gather for festivals and weddings. And it is during those three months that tour operators, hoteliers, innkeepers, restaurant employees and others earn the bulk of their income.

title: What to Buy to Create Your Own Backyard Campground
description: Being stuck at home doesnt mean you cant have an adventure, especially if youre fortunate enough to have some outdoor space. Unlike the appeal of a long-distance hiking trip  which relies, of course, on seeing new landscapes  the magic of backyard camping, especially with children, is creating a fantasy in an otherwise familiar environment. It is a theater that we invent for ourselves. And like all good theater, no matter how minimal, the illusion is sustained in the details.

title: Bringing Normal People to Sexy, Soundtracked Life
description: Fans of Sally Rooneys novel Normal People are devoted types. They tend to hold the books central mismatched-but-also-kind-of-perfect-together couple, Marianne and Connell, close to their hearts. So adapting the book for TV came with risks. It was a big leap of faith, Rooney told The Hollywood Reporter earlier this year about casting the show, that we were going to find people who would just get it, and would know exactly how to communicate that friction between the inner life and the outer world. Daisy Edgar-Jones and Paul Mescal have received widespread acclaim for their performances in the 12-part series on Hulu. Some of the praise for the show came from James Poniewozik, The Timess chief television critic, who called it a gorgeous, melancholy series starring leads who have so much chemistry you may need lab goggles. Poniewozik recently joined The Timess three book critics  Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai  for a discussion I moderated about the show, the novel, the art of adaptation and more.  John Williams, Daily Books Editor

title: Were Just Horrified: Why a Springsteen Sideman Took On Nursing Homes
description: When the coronavirus outbreak was only manifesting itself in horrifying headlines from Italy and China, Nils Lofgren, the guitarist for Bruce Springsteens E Street Band, and his wife, Amy, moved her mother into Brookdale Senior Living, a well-regarded long term care facility in Florham Park, N.J.

title: Livestreams to Watch: A Star-Studded Graduation Event, and Katy Perry Performs
description: Here are a few of the best events happening Friday through Wednesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

title: 9 Top (and Stubborn) Design Trends
description: Being confined to my home for the last two months has led me to think deeply about subway tile. It neatly covers my kitchen backsplash, and very possibly yours, but do its origins really lie in the subways? Why would that environment be anyones inspiration? And why is it so crazily popular now?

title: Americas Cities Could House Everyone if They Chose To
description: Tonight, more than half a million Americans will sleep in public places because they lack private spaces. They will huddle in crowded New York City shelters, or pitch tents under highways in Washington, D.C., or curl up in the doorways of San Francisco office towers, or dig holes in the high desert of northern Los Angeles County.

title: Lobby Heroes of the Lockdown
description: When Genc Rrahmani was growing up in Kosovo, he would fantasize about his future life in New York City. I was thinking that the U.S. has a lot of money, Genc said recently. That I would work hard and start a business, and have a beautiful future with a beautiful family.

title: Trump Is Following in Herbert Hoovers Footsteps
description: Additional economic assistance is the only thing that can keep the U.S. economy from falling into a second Great Depression, and with interest rates near zero, the government has all the fiscal capacity it needs to borrow the trillions necessary to relieve the pain. But Congress, or rather congressional Republicans, wont budge. After backing the $2 trillion CARES Act in March, they believe theyve done enough for now.

title: Examining the Meaning of Mrs.
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: What Home Means to the Homeless
description: What makes a home? Is it the materials we use to make the structure or the things we put in it? Is it the people who occupy the space or the memories we accumulate there? The question has vastly different meanings for people who have experienced homelessness, one of the most shameful manifestations of inequality in America.

title: Graduation Ceremonies in Quarantine
description: The day the governor of Rhode Island announced that schools would remain closed for the rest of the school year, Dan Freedman rallied his high school classmates to gather for an impromptu car parade on campus.

title: Sweden Stayed Open. A Deadly Month Shows the Risks.
description: While Sweden has avoided the worst outbreaks in Italy, Spain and Britain, it has also seen an extraordinary increase in deaths, mortality data shows.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: The 100-Year-Old Who Raised $40 Million for U.K. Health Workers
description: MARSTON MORETAINE, England  Hannah Ingram-Moore always knew her dad was a good story.

title: Reopening, Warily
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: How (and Why) to Use Native Plants
description: In recent years, the demand for pollinator plants has surged. But most of us dont have room for a meadow.

title: A Very Small Family Gathering Will Do This Time
description: Michael Cicoria is not the type to automatically pull out chairs and hold doors. But he will admit that when it comes to chivalry, he has his moments.

title: Coronavirus, Jobs, Richard Burr: Your Friday Briefing
description: Almost every country across Europe and North America has put in place some kind of lockdown. But not every country has experienced the sharp increase in unemployment that the United States has.

title: Trumps Ratings on the Virus Are Sagging. Why Isnt Biden Surging?
description: Its been a little over a month since Joseph R. Biden Jr. became the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, and what a month its been.

title: Private Equity Didnt Help
description: Good morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

title: Some Northeast Beaches Set to Open Next Week, but Not in N.Y.C.
description: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Saturdays live coverage.]

title: A Jazz Pianist Flips Bach Upside-Down
description: In March, the jazz pianist and composer Dan Tepfer found himself confined to his apartment in Brooklyn with all his bookings canceled for the foreseeable future, like musicians everywhere. So he decided to work seriously on an idea he had long been toying with.

title: How Is Your Family Dividing Responsibilities During the Quarantine?
description: How has the coronavirus affected family life and dynamics in your home? Have roles dramatically changed during social-distancing restrictions?

title: Film Club: Are Ice Cream Trucks Essential? In These N.Y.C. Neighborhoods, They Are
description: Note: This is our final Film Club for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other short films you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you dont miss any of our new films.

title: When Shoppers Venture Out, What Will Be Left?
description: The coronavirus pandemic dealt another crushing blow to retailers in April. Now the question is what the sector will look like as the economy reopens  and how much permanent damage has been inflicted.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend. Is the world around you reopening? Its strange to hear a constant hum of traffic out my window, to see people carrying takeaway coffee cups, to see kids at the park. It shouldnt be strange, people doing what they do, but right now it is. I am trying to be patient with myself as life uncoils itself back out into the world. I hope you are, too, and that whatever youre doing, you take some time to read some amazing journalism.

title: The Blacklist Draws Up a Novel End to Its Season
description: In mid-March, when the coronavirus pandemic shut New York City down, television production came to a sudden halt, sabotaging whole seasons for some shows and postponing season finales for others. But NBCs The Blacklist, which follows James Spaders Raymond Red Reddington as he helps the F.B.I. bring down the worlds most nefarious criminals, soldiered on.

title: One Side Effect of the Virus: Free Credit Reports Each Week
description: The economic turmoil caused by the coronavirus has prompted a helpful  if temporary  change in the window that Americans have into their credit files.

title: Why So Many Filipino Californians Are on the Front Lines
description: Good morning.

title: Why Sofas? These Books Explain the Joys and Mysteries of the Home
description: Have you ever wondered how forks ended up with four tines, where to store off-season clothes when you live in a small space, or why theres green felt on pool tables? These books have answers.

title: Oprah to Class of 2020: What Will Your Essential Service Be?
description: Hugging friends? Nope. Class photos? Afraid not. Instead, in place of the usual pomp and circumstance, Oprah Winfrey on Friday asked Americas graduates  the pandemic class, she called them  to consider what their essential service in this world would be.

title: U.S. Delivers Another Blow to Huawei With New Tech Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration issued a new rule Friday that will bar Huawei and its suppliers from using American technology and software, a significant escalation in the White Houses battle with the Chinese telecom giant and one that is likely to inflame tensions with Beijing.

title: Six Swipes for a Better Nights Sleep
description: Our daily patterns are all off, so our circadian rhythms are too. These tips will help.

title: Within a Week, They Fell in Love
description: Clare Goslant was in search of an affordable place to live in Washington, when she took time off between her junior and senior years at Harvard for an internship with the World Wildlife Fund.

title: In Jerusalem, Ramadan Restrictions Last Seen During the Crusades Return
description: JERUSALEM  The last time Muslim worshipers were kept out of the Aqsa Mosque compound throughout the entire month of Ramadan was when crusaders controlled Jerusalem in the Middle Ages.

title: Women Face Dilemma in a War Zone: Risk the Blasts or Sexual Assault
description: NEELUM VALLEY, Kashmir  There is another lockdown underway, forced by falling artillery shells rather than invading viruses. This one also requires frightening choices between bad options.

title: Paintings that Demolish the Myths of What a Home Should Be
description: Were someone to ask me for an image that clearly represents nostalgia  the definition drawn from Greek of the feeling of ache or pain associated with homecoming  I might point them to the work of the artist Naomi Safran-Hon who makes paintings of (among other things) lost and abandoned homes.

title: The Mrs. Files
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Trump Vows Vaccine by End of Year, and Mobilizes Military to Help
description: President Trump doubled down on Friday on his promise to have a coronavirus vaccine available by the end of this year, betting that he can rally the pharmaceutical industry and the government to have one available to nearly all Americans at a speed never before accomplished.

title: What Does Wife Mean for Queer Women?
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Is Marriage a Prize?
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Ray Eames, Out of Her Husbands Shadow
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Ms. Monroe
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Top Conn. Health Aide Disappears From Virus Briefings, Then Is Fired
description: Several weeks ago, Connecticuts public health commissioner suddenly stopped appearing with Gov. Ned Lamont at his daily briefings on the states response to the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Lady Jordan
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: Mrs.
description: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific Mrs. means to women and their identity.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamiltons back in The Times this week with a lovely essay about community meals that may send you down a summertime memory hole: to small-town fish fries and chicken dinners, spaghetti nights at the firehouse, men grilling venison, jerk pork, brats. Was it the era or the region where she grew up, she asks, that had those suppers commence with a Dixie cup of tomato juice, set down on your plate? She thought of it as a bracing appetizer, a kind of Communion before dinner.

title: What Is Beauty Now?
description: Hannah McCann, a lecturer at the University of Melbourne who specializes in beauty culture

title: Container
description: The agony and anxiety of living in a migrant camp.

title: Steve Earles Week: Pining for New York and Singing With His Son
description: Steve Earle misses New York.

title: We Are Kids Who Remember Only War
description: On a cold afternoon in mid-February, I huddled into a borrowed office on the Greek island of Lesbos with about 12 other volunteers for a workshop with a child psychologist. She had come to teach us about trauma and the human brain. We all worked at the nearby Moria refugee camp. I had been there about three weeks.

title: A Drug Company Wagers the U.S. Wont Dare Charge It With Crimes
description: In the coming days, the Justice Department will make an important decision: whether to file criminal charges against one of the worlds largest pharmaceutical companies for allegedly colluding with rivals to inflate the prices of widely used drugs.

title: How to Observe Planet Earth, Through Comics and Kafka
description: An assignment for all of us to help capture an extraordinary time.

title: Strong Earthquake Hits Western Nevada
description: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck a remote area in western Nevada early on Friday, damaging a major highway and shaking homes as far as Utah and California.

title: Bob Watson, Baseballs First Black General Manager, Dies at 74
description: Bob Watson, the hard-hitting first baseman and outfielder who became the first African-American general manager in major league baseball, with the 1994 Houston Astros, then helped take the 1996 Yankees to the franchises first World Series championship in 18 years as their newly hired general manager, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 74.

title: How Wall Street Is Hampering Some Small Businesses Seeking Aid
description: When Michael Sullivan borrowed $22 million from a specialist Wall Street lender in 2018 to buy and renovate two Florida hotels, he had no idea how costly that decision would prove to be.

title: Nick Kotz, Crusading Journalist and Author, Dies at 87
description: Nick Kotz, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author who exposed health hazards in the nations slaughterhouses, the gamut of hunger in America and the politics behind the Pentagons B-1 bomber, died on April 26 in Broad Run, Va. He was 87.

title: Aventuras Stripped-Down Livestream, and 10 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Your Food Is in the Mail
description: It started with hoarding. As the coronavirus began to spread across the United States, shoppers stocked up on toilet paper and canned food. Then, as restaurants closed and simply venturing out became a health hazard, people began cooking more meals at home.

title: A Lot of Bad News Out There: Parenting in a Pandemic
description: BANGKOK  I didnt want to be that parent, the one who talks about how when I was a child I had to walk uphill both ways, in the snow, just to get to school.

title: Antonio Gonzlez Pacheco, Accused Policeman in Francos Spain, Dies at 73
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: From Respect to Sick and Twisted: How Coronavirus Hit U.S.-China Ties
description: Evil. Lunacy. Shameless. Sick and twisted. China has hit back at American criticism over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic with an outpouring of vitriol as acrid as anything seen in decades.

title: How to Keep Kids Moving (Personal Bounce House Not Required)
description: It feels like a lifetime ago, but it was only March 17 when my daughter learned how to ride her bike without training wheels. It was also my birthday, so it felt like a gift  one with terrific timing, as our home state, Texas, had declared a state of emergency just four days earlier in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Those early days of the new normal were defined by frequent family bike rides, exploring our neighborhood in the welcoming air of an Austin spring.

title: The Biggest Weekend of Live Sports on TV in a Long Time
description: If it were 2019 or 1998 or 1986 or just about any year since the dawn of cable TV, you would look at the sports schedule for this weekend and say, Wow, theres almost nothing on.

title: The Hidden Language of Masks
