description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Friday that a broad new security measure proposed by China would amount to a death knell for Hong Kongs political freedoms, as Trump administration officials warned of punishments  possibly including revoking the territorys special economic and trading status.

title: Malaria Drug Taken by Trump Is Tied to Increased Risk of Heart Problems and Death in New Study
description: The malaria drugs hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine did not help coronavirus patients and may have done harm, according to a new study based on the records of nearly 15,000 patients who received the drugs and 81,000 who did not.

title: So Much Flavor
description: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. One of the glories of life in New York before Covid-19 was the vast variety of flavors you could take in over the course of a week without even entering your own kitchen. Tomatillos and Thai basil, Sichuan peppercorns and smoked salmon: It was a luxury to be able to eat them all, day to day, meal to meal.

title: You Cant Beat a Savory Babka
description: If you feel the desire for a multiday bread-baking project, but chocolate babkas are too sweet, and crusty sourdoughs, too needy, Ive got a loaf for you. Its a savory, ricotta-filled babka thats absorbing and meditative, but not at all fussy. Simply tearing the warm, garlic-scented bread with your hands will make procuring the yeast and flour well worth the search. And slices make for the best grilled cheese sandwiches, ever.

title: Rock-Bottom Interest Rates May Be Here to Stay
description: Federal Reserve officials were running a huge experiment with Americas job market before coronavirus lockdowns gripped the American economy, one that could inform how officials think about unemployment  and the path for interest rates  in the pandemics aftermath.

title: Detroit Police Arrest Man in Connection With Nursing Home Assault
description: The Detroit police on Thursday arrested a 20-year-old man in connection with a viral video that showed an assault on a patient at a nursing home, the authorities said.

title: Judge Is Ordered to Explain Handling of Flynn Case as F.B.I. Announces Review
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court panel has ordered a trial judge to explain why he is hesitating to grant the Justice Departments request that he dismiss the criminal case against President Trumps former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn.

title: Bidens Online Campaign Is Still Loading
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has an opportunity and a challenge: He is the presumptive nominee for president taking on an incumbent weighed down by a public-health disaster and a resulting deep recession.

title: Why All the Shouting About Google?
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: He Says Trumps Cost Him $2 Million, but Hotelier Now Cheers Federal Assist
description: When President Trump was campaigning in 2016, his company announced a new line of bespoke hotels that would be built with partners across the country. But two years into his presidency, the Trump Organization shelved the brand and dropped the only partner, a Mississippi family business that one member says lost about $2 million in the collaboration.

title: How to Share Food Safely During the Pandemic
description: Maybe your big sister just had a baby, and you want to take her a home-cooked meal. Or youd love to swap some sourdough starter for your neighbors famous beef stew. Or maybe you baked a birthday cake for your immunocompromised neighbor.

title: A Philip Glass Score Was Lost. 50 Years Later, Here It Is.
description: In the early 1970s, Philip Glass was already writing masterpieces and performing them with his ensemble in lofts, galleries and museums. But he wasnt quite making a living as a composer yet.

title: 9 Splashy Masks to Try On
description: Retail as a whole has declined rapidly over the last two months, but one segment of the struggling industry has defied the trend: face masks. In early April, the Centers for Disease Control began encouraging Americans to wear face masks outside their homes. By then, a crop of do-it-yourself solutions had already emerged, intended to abate shortages of medical-grade personal protective equipment among those on the front lines of the fight against the coronavirus. More than a month later, its apparent that social distancing  and thus, mask-wearing  will continue to be necessary throughout the summer. (Of course, in some parts of the world, face masks are already worn daily.)

title: 8 Cannes Film Festival Prizewinners We Love (and 3 We Dont)
description: At the end of every Cannes Film Festival, juries of cinematic eminences deliver verdicts on the films in competition. The name of the top prize has changed over time  from Palme dOr to Grand Prix and back again  but the winners include a roster of modern classics.

title: Is Crying a Sign of Weakness? Tell That to Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: Love Letter: Must Love Dogs
description: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

title: SpaceX Gets Go-Ahead for NASA Astronaut Launch Next Week
description: [When to watch SpaceXs next NASA launch of astronauts.]

title: This One-Bowl Cake Is Worthy of Its Own Celebration
description: This holiday weekend may be a lot more subdued than my usual Memorial Day revelries (lake house, potato cannon, punch), but there will still be cake. Lots of it, smothered in strawberries and cream.

title: A Bright, Comforting One-Pot Stew With West African Roots
description: When I returned from Nigeria at the end of February, it was at the tail end of the Harmattan, a season when the winds from the north deposit the finest sand from the Sahara onto Lagoss every surface. The city was hot and dry, and the markets were bursting with life.

title: Trump Suggests Virus Death Count Is Inflated. Most Experts Doubt It
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, eager to reopen the economy, has begun questioning the official coronavirus death toll, suggesting the numbers, which have hobbled his approval ratings and harmed his re-election prospects, are inflated.

title: Walter Dallas, Heartbeat of Philadelphia Theater, Dies at 73
description: Walter Dallas, a powerful force in African-American theater, chiefly as a director but also as a playwright, musician and teacher, died on May 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 73.

title: Britain Orders a 14-Day Quarantine on Arriving Travelers
description: LONDON  Britain on Friday moved ahead with a 14-day mandatory quarantine on arriving travelers, and heavy fines for those who break the rules, outlining strict new travel restrictions as other European nations are thinking about easing theirs.

title: Plant-Based Meats Catch On in the Pandemic
description: The news for the American meat industry over the last month has not been good. Slaughterhouses closed as the coronavirus sickened and killed workers. Even after President Trump declared meat processing plants critical infrastructure, hundreds of Wendys restaurants ran out of hamburgers. As meat-processing plants have shut down, farmers have had to kill hundreds of thousands of pigs.

title: The Best Films of 2020 (So Far), and Theyre All Streaming
description: Theaters closed in March because of the pandemic, and studios delayed the release of several much-anticipated films till the fall or even 2021. So youd think there might not be much to recommend so far this year. But our chief critics, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, are having none of that: they are championing several movies that hit theaters before the shutdown or were released online afterward. If youre looking for new movies that will challenge you, here are their picks.

title: How to Make a Frozen Margarita
description: Youll need some blanco tequila, lime juice, triple sec, simple syrup, ice and a blender. A summer weekend refreshment is a few easy steps away.

title: My 14-Year-Old Isnt Socially Distancing. What Should I Do?
description: Our Adolescence columnist, the psychologist Lisa Damour, responds to a readers question. The question has been edited and is being published with the consent of the person who submitted it.

title: With Museums Closed, Coffee-Table Books Bring the Art to You
description: GERHARD RICHTERPainting After All By Sheena Wagstaff and Benjamin H. D. BuchlohIllustrated. 269 pp. Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University. $50.

title: Coronavirus Vaccine Shows Promising Early Results in China
description: A vaccine developed in China appears to be safe and may protect people from the new coronavirus, researchers reported on Friday.

title: Reduced Demand for Electricity Leads to Power Giveaways
description: The coronavirus pandemic has played havoc with energy markets. Last month, the price of benchmark American crude oil fell below zero as the economy shut down and demand plunged.

title: Argentina Tries to Escape Default as It Misses Bond Payment
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina missed a bond payment on Friday and inched closer to another crushing default, which would plunge it into a new period of economic isolation and deepen a recession that has been exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
description: Last Fridays episode about Jasmine Lombrage, a restaurant owner in Baton Rouge, La., struggling with the decision of whether to reopen, struck a chord with many of you. There was an outpouring of feedback.

title: Moving Forward
description: At a time of year long associated with graduation and with students moving on to new adventures, members of the first class of New York Times fellows also prepare for their next steps. Here they reflect on the journeys that brought them together and on some of the lessons they've learned.

title: Phil May, British Rocker of Unbridled Energy, Is Dead at 75
description: Phil May, the lead singer of the Pretty Things, a 1960s British rock band whose members played faster, louder and with more unbridled energy than their contemporaries, died on May 15 in Norfolk, England. He was 75.

title: Germanys Lessons for China and America
description: The nation-state alone does not have a future, Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said this week. It was a direct challenge to President Trumps America First, the slogan whose poison keeps on giving. His United States has become the most unserious of nations.

title: Immigration Reform, Past and Present
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

title: Surfaces Are Not the Main Way Coronavirus Spreads, C.D.C. Says
description: Guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention making the rounds this month on the internet are clarifying what we know about the transmission of the coronavirus.

title: After 3 Children Die, a Race to Investigate a Baffling Virus Syndrome
description: Blood will be collected from dozens of children in New York to determine whether they share any genetic variations that might make them susceptible to a mysterious syndrome linked to the coronavirus.

title: What Role Should Employers Play in Testing Workers?
description: As the country reopens, employers are looking into how to safely bring back their workers. One recurring question: Should they be tested for the new coronavirus?

title: As Virus Spreads in Russias Caucasus, Rumors Swirl Over Strongmans Health
description: MOSCOW  The strongman leader of Chechnya, a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, is hospitalized with possible symptoms of the coronavirus, state-run news agencies say. A spokesman suggests he is just keeping a low profile because he is thinking.

title: Trump Takes Aim at a Watergate Reform: The Independent Inspector General
description: WASHINGTON  Congress had a clear idea of the role it expected inspectors general to play when it created them in 1978 after the Watergate scandals. They were to be dispersed in the agencies and departments of the federal government not as compliant team members but in-house referees, charged with rooting out corruption, waste, malfeasance and illegality.

title: Churches, China, Memorial Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Marcel Ospel, Architect of the Swiss Bank UBS, Is Dead at 70
description: Marcel Ospel, who fashioned the Swiss bank UBS into a global banking power but then saw it come close to unraveling during the financial crisis of 2008, died on April 26 at his home in Wollerau, Switzerland, near Zurich. He was 70.

title: Being More Like Athletic Bilbao
description: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, please pass it on to a friend (or four) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

title: Investigators Say Man Who Filmed Arberys Killing Was More Than a Witness
description: DECATUR, Ga.  From the beginning, William Bryan has portrayed himself as a concerned citizen, one drawn by commotion when he pulled out his phone and filmed the fatal encounter between two of his white neighbors and Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was running in their neighborhood.

title: Whats Lost and Gained When We Put In 9-to-5 From Home?
description: On Thursday, Tobi Ltke, the founder and chief executive of Ottawa-based Shopify, announced on Twitter that most of his companys 5,000 employees had permanently become stay-at-home workers.

title: C.D.C. Test Counting Error Leaves Epidemiologists Really Baffled
description: WASHINGTON  As it tracks the coronaviruss spread, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is combining tests that detect active infection with those that detect recovery from Covid-19  a system that muddies the picture of the pandemic but raises the percentage of Americans tested as President Trump boasts about testing.

title: Coronavirus Poems to the Editor: Death Too Wears a Mask
description: In the Time of Plague

title: Mass Firing on Zoom Is Latest Sign of Weight Watchers Unrest
description: On the afternoon of May 14, Joanne Patten sat down at her computer in her home in Houston and logged in to a Zoom call with her employer, WW International, the company formerly known as Weight Watchers.

title: John Driscoll, Scholar, Art Dealer and Collector, Dies at 70
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: With Unemployment Expected to Reach 20%, Senators Take a Vacation
description: After three weeks in session, the United States Senate emptied out again on Friday, as lawmakers fled Washington for the Memorial Day recess. They left without even pretending to tackle the next round of coronavirus relief.

title: Trumps Press Secretary Displays One of His Checks in a Little Too Much Detail
description: WASHINGTON  Its a feel-good story that President Trumps press secretaries have relished over the years: the quarterly announcement of which government agency Mr. Trump has selected to be the lucky recipient of his salary, an easy way to show the president sticking to his 2016 campaign pledge to forgo his $400,000 salary and donate it.

title: Firing a Salvo in Culture Wars, Trump Pushes for Churches to Reopen
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump may not consider church essential to his personal life, but it may be to his political future. And so he waded into the culture wars on Friday by demanding that states allow places of worship to reopen right away and threatening to overrule any that defy him.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The U.S. is about to kick off its first major holiday weekend since the pandemic began  and its going to be unlike any other, with most of the traditional activities off limits or significantly restricted.

title: Patrick Ewing Says He Has Covid-19
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks great who is now coaching the Georgetown University mens basketball team, announced on Friday evening that he had Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.

title: Virus Lockdown Forces Iran Into Its First Virtual Quds Day
description: For the past four decades, on the last Friday of Ramadan, supporters of Irans government have marched to denounce Israel. They burn Israels flag. They mock effigies of the leaders of Israel and of its patron, the United States. They chant pledges to liberate Jerusalem, or Quds, as the city is known in Arabic.

title: White House Worries About Kelly Loefflers Senate Prospects in Georgia
description: President Trumps advisers are increasingly concerned about Senator Kelly Loefflers campaign in Georgia, a newly competitive state where the presidents own poll numbers have tightened against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to people briefed on the discussions.

title: Uncertain Results in Study of Convalescent Serum for Covid-19
description: A small study of patients who were severely ill from the coronavirus hints that treatment with antibodies from recovered patients may modestly help recovery and survival, scientists reported on Friday.

title: Michael Flynn and the Presumption of Guilt
description: Of all the low moments in the 2016 Republican presidential convention  there were many  Michael Flynns speech ranks high.

title: Prosecutors to Drop Charges Against Boyfriend of Breonna Taylor
description: Prosecutors on Friday said they were dropping charges against the boyfriend of Breonna Taylor, a black woman who was fatally shot by three white police officers in Louisville, Ky., in March.

title: Airlines Given Tentative OK to Halt Service at Dozens of U.S. Cities
description: The Transportation Department said late Friday that it would tentatively allow 15 airlines to stop flights to about 60 mostly small and midsize cities, though none of the destinations stand to lose service entirely.

title: Completely
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This pair of constructors, Wyna Liu and Erik Agard, are proving to be a dynamic Saturday duo with their second Saturday grid this spring. This one is measurably harder, in my eyes at least, and required a revisit after a nights sleep to finish (I am always amazed when that works, its like taking the crayon out of your frontal lobe).

title: Hertz, Car Rental Pioneer, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Hertz, which started with a fleet of a dozen Ford Model Ts a century ago and became one of the worlds largest car rental companies, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday after falling victim to its mountain of debt.

title: Corrections: May 23, 2020
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a grant given to the drug company AstraZeneca misstated the partial results announced by the biotech company Moderna from a first-phase trial of a vaccine it is developing. The vaccine candidate produced an immune response in the first 45 study participants, the company said, not just in 8.

title: Quotation of the Day: This Years Official Start to Summer Comes With Alarm and Face Masks
description: Everybodys tired of being quarantined. They are stunned that they couldnt watch their children graduate from high school. They are afraid that the whole world is going to get canceled.

title: Pandemic Swells in South America, as the U.S. Nears 100,000 Deaths
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the global coronavirus pandemic.

title: Akim Alius Account of Racism Pushes Hockey to Search Its Soul
description: Akim Aliu, a former National Hockey League player, gave a harrowing account this week in The Players Tribune about his experiences with racism in the sport. Alius unusually frank post  in which he challenged the culture of the sport and named his tormentor  intensified a debate within the hockey community about efforts to diversify.

title: Jacinda Ardern Sold a Drastic Lockdown With Straight Talk and Mom Jokes
description: Halfway into a Facebook Live video last week, updating the world on New Zealands plan to reopen restaurants, schools and even movie theaters, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern noticed a concern cropping up among the commenters: They thought she looked tired.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Premature and The Painter and the Thief
description: PREMATURE (2020) Stream on Hulu. Two people meet, form an undeniable connection and fall in love. But the timing just isnt right. Its a familiar story, yet there are more layers to this romantic drama by the filmmaker Rashaad Ernesto Green. Seventeen-year-old Ayanna (Zora Howard), an aspiring poet, is enjoying summer at home in Harlem with her friends before going off to college. Enter Isaiah, (Joshua Boone), an older music producer who instantly catches her eye. They bond over their artistic ambitions and embark on a dreamy summer romance, but reality strikes when discussions about the future crop up. Jeannette Catsoulis named Premature a Critics Pick, and in her review for The New York Times wrote that the poetry of the writing and the vibrancy of the filmmaking lift the movie above its narrative clichs.

title: A Comics-Obsessed Cinderella Down on the Farm
description: After skimming only a few pages of Lucy Knisleys STEPPING STONES (Random House Graphic, 224 pp., $20.99; ages 8 to 12), even the least jaded of readers might guess the storys arc: A mother moves her daughter, a true city kid, to the country, where the child will be surprised to find, over time, that she thrives on the pleasures of hard work, fresh milk and the natural world.

title: Going Places: An Anonymous Gossip Cartoonist With Buzz
description: I remember 12 as a particularly stressful age. My family had recently moved to England, and for a time I was the center of attention, asked to repeat things in my funny accent and regale everyone with what was happening in American television. I simultaneously loved it and desperately wanted it to stop  one wrong move and they could all turn on me. It was a relief when they got used to my pronunciation of aluminum and I could quit performing.

title: The New Training Facilities: Backyard Gym, Hallway Track
description: Perhaps its a new adage: If you build a backyard gym, the quarantined athletes will come.

title: The Coronavirus Patient Had a Question: Dont You Lead a Soccer Team?
description: He swapped his blazer and tie for the uncomfortable fit of personal protective equipment and left the boardroom for the emergency room at Lisbons military hospital.

title: European Defense and Strategic Autonomy Are Also Coronavirus Victims
description: BRUSSELS  The coronavirus has upended the best-laid plans and priorities of many, including the European Union. But one of the biggest casualties may be European efforts to build a more credible and independent European military.

title: Going Outside This Weekend? Dont Freak Out
description: After being holed up indoors for an extended period of time, perhaps youre feeling the itch to peer outside: to explore the world beyond the radius of your home, grocery and takeout spot. But is it recommended? Will others adhere to social distancing? What fresh horrors await?

title: Is the Wedding Off? (For Now?) Heres What to Do Next.
description: Organizing a wedding under normal circumstances can be stressful  now throw in a global pandemic and its near maddening. As couples look to safely solidify their union, some are planning intimate ceremonies at home, while others are pushing back their original wedding dates to the following year. Here are a few tips from wedding experts to help you tackle some of the issues that may arise while trying to get your celebration back on track.

title: Should You Renew Your Lease if Youve Lost Your Job?
description: Q: I have been furloughed from my job, and the lease on my Brooklyn apartment is up in June. My landlord sent me a renewal, but I am worried about committing to a year lease when I am living on savings and unemployment insurance. I asked if I could stay on as a month-to-month tenant, or sign at a lower rent, but Ive gotten no response. What can I do?

title: This Neighborhood Stifled Gangs and Guns. Then a New Killer Moved In.
description: Not long ago, the main public health threat facing people living in and around the Baisley Park Houses complex in South Jamaica, Queens, was one that had taken too many young lives: gangs armed with guns.

title: Investigators Say One Man Shot Ahmaud Arbery. Why Are Three Charged With Murder?
description: ATLANTA  Three shots were fired in the confrontation that killed Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was chased by white men as he ran through their southeastern Georgia neighborhood. The authorities said Travis McMichael, who with his father and a neighbor pursued Mr. Arbery, pulled the trigger.

title: The Drones Were Ready for This Moment
description: New Yorkers strolling along the East River early last month glanced up to see an unsettling sight: a mysterious drone claiming to represent something called the Anti-Covid-19 Volunteer Drone Task Force barking orders to pedestrians below to maintain social distancing.

title: Bidens Breakfast Club Controversy Shows What His Rivals Already Knew
description: A few months after former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. entered the 2020 race for president, the executive producer of the popular nationally syndicated radio show The Breakfast Club said that he and the hosts were in discussions with the Biden campaign about an appearance.

title: Why Is the SAT Falling Out of Favor?
description: SACRAMENTO  The University of Californias decision this past week to stop requiring the SAT and ACT tests for admissions renewed a debate that could be a prompt on a college application: Are the tests that were first deployed to diversify the Ivy League beyond rich prep schoolers a worthwhile yardstick, or are they, as one U.C. regent put it, a proxy for privilege?

title: China Deploys Propaganda Machine to Defend Move Against Hong Kong
description: Chinas propaganda machine went into full gear as the government sought to defend new laws aimed at limiting dissent and protest in Hong Kong.

title: What a Weeks Disasters Tell Us About Climate and the Pandemic
description: The hits came this week in rapid succession: A cyclone slammed into the Indian megacity of Kolkata, pounding rains breached two dams in the Midwestern United States, and on Thursday came warning that the Atlantic hurricane season could be severe.

title: Long Limbs Helped Propel T. Rex Up the Dinosaur Food Chain
description: Surviving in the Cretaceous wasnt a sprint, it was a marathon. And Tyrannosaurus rex was built to amble for hours, new research reveals. That attribute might have helped propel the carnivore to the top of the food chain, researchers suggest.

title: Will the Coronavirus Kill Whats Left of Americans Faith in Washington?
description: Patricia Millner, a nurse in Hershey, Pa., was born the year Dwight D. Eisenhower was re-elected. The economy was booming, and trust was high: When national pollsters began asking the question two years later, about three-quarters of Americans said they trusted the federal government to do the right thing.

title: As Sports Begin Reopening, Athletes Weigh the Health Risks
description: Kathleen Baker, 23, a gold medal-winning Olympic swimmer, began wearing masks on airplanes long before the coronavirus outbreak began to avoid contracting illnesses that are especially hard for her to shake off because she has Crohns disease, which causes inflammation in the digestive system.

title: A Feud in Wolf-Kink Erotica Raises a Deep Legal Question
description: Addison Cain was living in Kyoto, volunteering at a shrine and studying indigenous Japanese religion. She was supposed to be working on a scholarly book about her research, but started writing intensely erotic Batman fan fiction instead.

title: I Am Just Hong Kong: A Citys Fate in Chinas Hands
description: Hong Kong was born at the crossroad of empires, a hybrid of British and Chinese parentage. It may fade there, too.

title: The Artisans Behind Italian Fashion Tremble at Their Future
description: Until recently, some of the most intricately embroidered fabrics in the world, like those found in garments designed by Giorgio Armani, Valentino, Etro and Prada, have come out of a duplex apartment complex in Milan, the home of a small business called Pino Grasso Ricami.

title: Pakistan Plane Crash Leaves Grim Task: Identifying Victims From DNA
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The bodies were pulled one by one from the ruins of damaged buildings and the smoldering wreckage of the Pakistan International Airlines plane that had crashed a day earlier into a crowded neighborhood of Karachi: 97 of them by Saturday.

title: N.Y. Reports Fewer Than 100 Virus Deaths for First Time Since March
description: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sundays live coverage.]

title: Can a Coach Save You From Divorce?
description: In a newsletter last year, I (cheekily) suggested that one way to get partners to do their fair share of emotional labor is to become physically incapacitated for several months, like I was when I was pregnant with my younger daughter. This week, Jancee Dunn offers a more viable solution to a mental load imbalance: Hire a coach.

title: Together, Alone: The Car as Shelter in the Pandemic
description: The role of the automobile has been reinvented in the coronavirus era. Once just a way of getting from one place to another, the car has been turned into a mini-shelter on wheels, safe from contamination, a cocoon that allows its occupants to be inside and outside at the same time.

title: Outrage Grows Over Boris Johnson Aides 260-Mile Trip During Lockdown
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced a torrent of calls on Saturday to dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, after reports that Mr. Cummings had visited relatives in northern England while he was ill with the coronavirus  a violation of Britains lockdown rules.

title: This Bloody Mary Is Just as Good Without Alcohol
description: The weeks most popular dishes include Gabrielle Hamiltons recipe for Bloody Mary mix (above), Yewande Komolafes baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice, and Dawn Perrys berry buttermilk cake. Find more recipes in the collection below.

title: How Upbeat Vaccine News Fueled a Stock Surge, and an Uproar
description: [Read more on Modernas Covid-19 vaccine.]

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  This is a classic Team Cox-Rathvon acrostic where a topic makes itself evident in the clues as well as in the grid, as you tease the whole thing apart  familiar territory, but still satisfying. The passage is from an 1899 book (with a gorgeous gilded Art Nouveau cover) by Mabel Wagnalls, called Stars of the Opera, that lionizes everyone, including the lead sopranos and the occupants of the orchestra pit. I love it when professionals who operate in the background receive proper attention, and I find that the statements made about the operas orchestra apply to great support staff everywhere.

title: Are Cars Protecting Los Angeles?
description: LOS ANGELES  I was born in New York and spent my formative years there, so waiting makes me crazy. Im a jaywalker and I push elevator buttons more than once. I find the shortest line to anything. I walk fast and can drive like a competitor in a video game race. I attribute these qualities to years spent trying to survive in New Yorks hustle culture, and not to innate personal flaws.

title: Contact Tracing Is Harder Than It Sounds
description: How likely are you to answer an unknown number popping up on your caller ID? And if you were to pick up, how likely is it that you would disclose personal information about yourself and your family, friends and colleagues to the stranger on the other end of the line?

title: What if We All Vacationed at Home Again?
description: LONDON  For us, it was supposed to be France  a big house in a soporific Breton village, with 16 members of my partners family. Her bon vivant father, who recently completed chemotherapy, had paid for the rental to celebrate with two weeks surrounded by grandkids and half-empty bottles of Beaujolais. Everyone had been looking forward to it all year. It is only in the past two weeks, after France announced an 18 billion euro (about $20 billion) Marshall Plan to place its vital tourist sector on life support, that I finally conceded that the trip isnt going to happen.

title: In Mexico, Roma Lit a Fire for Workers Rights
description: This  essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Timess philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, Why does art matter? The entire series can be found here.

title: U.N. Documents Abductions and Torture Of Iraqi Protesters
description: BAGHDAD  Hundreds of people were killed and thousands wounded in the antigovernment protests in Iraq last fall and winter that halted political life and immobilized cities from Baghdad to Basra.

title: Simple Stretches to Combat All That Sitting
description: Whether you are hunched over a laptop in a makeshift work space or slouched on the couch binge-watching TV, you know  and can feel  that sitting for long periods can sabotage your health. From head to toe, these simple exercises can provide relief, restore muscle function and improve posture.

title: N.B.A. in Talks to Resume Season at Walt Disney World Resort
description: The N.B.A. is in the early stages of discussions with the Walt Disney Company to restart its suspended season in late July at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida, a league spokesman said Saturday.

title: John Macurdy, Stalwart Bass in Roles Large and Small, Dies at 91
description: John Macurdy, an American bass who belonged to a select group of solo singers who have tallied more than 1,000 performances at the Metropolitan Opera, died on May 7 in Stamford, Conn. He was 91.

title: Hawaii Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results from the Hawaii presidential primary election.

title: Covid Dreams, Trump Nightmares
description: WASHINGTON  My corona dreams are so crazy and vibrant, with star turns by politicians, celebrities, zombies and my late mother, that sometimes as I wake, I groggily think the virus that devoured the globe has to be a dystopian vision.

title: Crumbs for the Hungry but Windfalls for the Rich
description: While President Trump and his allies in Congress seek to tighten access to food stamps, they are showing compassion for one group: zillionaires. Their economic rescue package quietly allocated $135 billion  yes, thats billion with a b  for the likes of wealthy real estate developers.

title: Why Does the U.S. Military Celebrate White Supremacy?
description: The white supremacist who murdered nine black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., five years ago dispensed with the fiction that the Confederate battle flag was an innocuous symbol of Southern pride. A murderers manifesto describing the killings as the start of a race war  combined with photos of the killer brandishing a pistol and a rebel flag  made it impossible to ignore the connection between Confederate ideology and a blood-drenched tradition of racial terrorism that dates back to the mid-19th century in the American South.

title: The End of the New World Order
description: Its a mistake to believe most conspiracy theories, but its also a mistake to assume that they bear no relation to reality. Some are just insane emanations or deliberate misinformation. But others exaggerate and misread important trends rather than denying them, or offer implausible explanations for mysteries that nonetheless linger unexplained.

title: Its My 100th Birthday. Its Been Quite a Century.
description: Theres nothing like reaching the age of 100 to make a person want to get a grip on life, to start looking for that elusive way forward, especially when it comes during a pandemic propelled by a devilish virus that is everywhere and nowhere.

title: How Cubans Lost Faith in Revolution
description: GUANABACOA, Cuba  There was nothing Caridad Limonta would not do for her dear mother, even if it meant fulfilling her strange wish to be buried with two pairs of socks.

title: A Hidden Origin Story of the CBD Craze
description: Long before CBD had become a trendy wellness elixir found in juice and moisturizer and ice cream and dog treats; before corporate chains like Walgreens and Sephora had decided to sell it; and way before Kim Kardashian West had thrown a CBD-themed baby shower, a ragtag crew of activists, doctors, writers and marijuana farmers met up on an early winter evening in 2011. They sat in a circle at a house in the hills a few hours north of San Francisco  where wine country becomes weed country  to discuss the therapeutic potential of CBD, and how to get people to take it seriously.

title: Federal Scientists Finally Publish Remdesivir Data
description: Nearly a month after federal scientists claimed that an experimental drug had helped patients severely ill with the coronavirus, the research has been published.

title: Fire at San Franciscos Pier 45 Destroys a Quarter of Its Warehouses
description: About 150 firefighters battled a four-alarm blaze that destroyed a quarter of the structures on Pier 45 in San Francisco early on Saturday morning, the authorities said.

title: Rattled by a Pandemic, People Turn to Leaders  Any Leaders
description: As world leaders grapple with when and how to safely reopen their countries, many are also facing a political problem: how to maintain support as they oversee tanking economies, stifling restrictions and staggering death tolls.

title: Less Is More as an Art Museum Reopens
description: HOUSTON  They waited patiently in line in 80-degree heat, standing on large blue stickers placed six feet apart, to enter the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston  the first major American art museum to reopen since the country went into lockdown in March.

title: How to Make an Envelope From Newspaper
description: You may not be able to embrace your friends and family for a while, but letter writing is a great (and screenless) way of letting them know you care from afar. And why not give your penpals a real treat by dressing up your letter in all the news thats fit to print? Youll need some folding skills and a roll of either clear or decorative tape.

title: Is It Time to Stop Clapping for Health Care Workers? An Organizer Thinks So
description: On Thursday nights, Britons bang pots and pans and let out hearty cheers of support for doctors and nurses who care for coronavirus patients and for other essential workers amid the pandemic.

title: The Mystery of McGuffin Manor
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays grid is a surprise and a delight, the type that makes me want to grab any poor solver I see on the street and explain every loving dimension. Andrew Chaikin, who also goes by Kid Beyond, is a San Francisco-based musician and game inventor, a constructor of pleasurable mind-benders for us and elsewhere (please read his notes and check out Puzzle Bouquet as well; hes also philanthropic).

title: Black Coronavirus Patients Land in Hospitals More Often, Study Finds
description: As the coronavirus spread across the United States, sweeping through low-income, densely populated communities, black and Hispanic patients have been dying at higher rates than white patients.

title: The Project Behind a Front Page Full of Names
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Rafael Leonardo Black, Solitary and Self-Trained Artist, Dies at 71
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: In Joe Flacco, Jets Get a Credible Backup for Sam Darnold
description: The Jets are hoping that their most prominent addition this off-season  a former most valuable player of the Super Bowl  never takes a snap for them. Such is the plight of a backup quarterback, and that is the new role for the veteran Joe Flacco, who agreed to a one-year deal on Friday as he recovers from neck surgery.

title: Elizabeth Warren to Hold Big-Dollar Fund-Raiser for Joe Biden
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Elizabeth Warren, whose full-throated opposition to high-dollar fund-raising events was a central tenet of her presidential campaign, has agreed to host such a gathering of donors for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the presumptive Democratic nominee, who is considering her to be his running mate.

title: Trump Bans Travel From Brazil, Citing Pandemic
description: This briefing has ended. Follow live updates on the coronavirus here.

title: Afghan Sides Agree to Rare Cease-Fire During Eid al-Fitr
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban and the Afghan government announced a cease-fire for the three days of the Islamic festival Eid al-Fitr, which starts on Sunday in Afghanistan, offering the war-torn nation a rare respite from violence that has been intensifying.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: Lance and Underestimate the Girl
description: 30 FOR 30: LANCE 9 p.m. on ESPN. Nearly eight years after an investigation by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency found that Lance Armstrong had been using performance-enhancing drugs throughout his career  making him a pariah essentially overnight  the disgraced athlete has resurfaced to reflect on his misdeeds. This two-part documentary by the director Marina Zenovich (Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind), airing as part of ESPNs 30 for 30 series, gives him ample opportunity to do so. (Although if youve already made up your mind on Armstrong, the former superstar cyclist, this movie might not change it.) The film packs plenty of back story, chronicling his early days as a cyclist, his battle with testicular cancer and the demise of his reputation after he admitted to doping in 2013. Zenovich doesnt shy away from tough questions, and by interviewing Armstrongs family, friends, rivals and others, she manages to create an objective portrait of a shunned star. The second half of the film airs May 31.

title: Corrections: May 24, 2020
description: An article on Page 5 about the choreographer Bill T. Jones misstated the name of his company. It is the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company, not the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company.

title: Quotation of the Day: In the Fight to Be Just Hong Kong, a Daunting New Salvo
description: At the end of the day, we have to accept that we answer to one country. And that country is more and more powerful.

title: Kim Jong-un Moves to Increase North Koreas Nuclear Strength
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After another weekslong absence from public view, North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, has convened the countrys top military-governing body, outlining new policies for further increasing its nuclear capabilities and promoting top weapons officials, the Norths state-run media said on Sunday.

title: I Was a Little Nervous as I Finished and Dropped Back Onto the Sidewalk
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hong Kong Police Fire Tear Gas as Protesters Resist Chinas Grip
description: HONG KONG  Thousands of protesters swarmed some of Hong Kongs busiest neighborhoods on Sunday, singing, chanting and erecting roadblocks of torn-up bricks and debris, as the police repeatedly fired tear gas, pepper spray and a water cannon during the citys largest street mobilization in months.

title: Remembering the 100,000 Lives Lost to Coronavirus in America
description: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.

title: Trump Sows Doubt on Voting. It Keeps Some People Up at Night.
description: WASHINGTON  In October, President Trump declares a state of emergency in major cities in battleground states, like Milwaukee and Detroit, banning polling places from opening.

title: Too Many Memorial Days
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: What Happens if a Hurricane Hits During the Pandemic?
description: MIAMI  Its deep into the summer and a massive hurricane looms off the Florida coast, threatening enormous destruction and widespread power blackouts. In normal times, in such a scenario, the orders would come down for millions of coastal residents: Evacuate.

title: Pay Cuts Become a Tool for Some Companies to Avoid Layoffs
description: It was late and Martin A. Kits van Heyningen feared he was letting the team down at the company he co-founded, KVH Industries. Rather than lay off workers in response to the coronavirus pandemic, he had decided to cut salaries, and when he emailed a video explaining his decision at 3 a.m. last month, he was prepared for a barrage of complaints.

title: Summer in Lockdown: 5 Families Mull a Spoiled Season
description: Dolly and Amaya Diaz were hoping to spend July and August in the sun, playing softball. Nael Genao was planning a big trip out of the country. Amy Tsais five children were supposed to be in math programs or day camp, finally leaving her time and space to catch up on work.

title: For Some Italians, the Future of Work Looks Like the Past
description: CORCOLLE, Italy  On a small farm outside Rome, workers crouched in the corridors of a cornfield and tended to stalks for the coming harvest. The ones from Morocco, Romania and Nigeria knew exactly what to do. It was the new Italian hires who needed help.

title: After 17 Years Underground, Cicadas Stage a 2020 Southern Invasion
description: They break through the ground, like the undead emerging from graves.

title: Memorial Day, Testing, Hong Kong: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Week in Business: The End of the Office as We Know It
description: Holiday weekends seem a little strange when Saturdays feel the same as Tuesdays and you cant really go anywhere, but have a good Memorial Day all the same! Heres what you need to know in business and tech for the short week ahead.

title: Netanyahu Corruption Trial Begins, Taking Israel Into Uncharted Territory
description: JERUSALEM  Three electoral challenges by a popular former army chief could not unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. A clear majority of Israeli lawmakers could not set aside their differences long enough to oust him.

title: Why Chinas Move to Rein In Hong Kong Is Just the Start
description: Chinas move to strip away another layer of Hong Kongs autonomy was not a rash impulse. It was a deliberate act, months in the making. It took into account the risks of international umbrage and reached the reasonable assumption that there would not be a significant geopolitical price to pay.

title: New York Prepares for Two More Regions to Open
description: With the Mid-Hudson and Long Island regions poised to start reopening this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced new public transit safety measures on Sunday in an effort to ensure public health as those areas emerge from lockdown.

title: They Survived the Worst Battles of World War II. And Died of the Virus.
description: HOLYOKE, Mass.  In 1945, James Leach Miller returned from the war and said nothing.

title: Push to Reopen Houses of Worship in Europe and Mideast Brings Perils and Tensions
description: BERLIN  As nations weigh the calculus of reopening parts of society after locking down because of the coronavirus, Germany has plunged ahead after bringing its outbreak under control, reopening houses of worship and allowing the faithful to gather again in larger numbers.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Its funny, the things that bring happiness in these weird, unsettled times. I thrill to routine: the morning bike ride to see the sun rise; the hurried lunch alongside my children in the kitchen; Kai Ryssdal on the radio in the evenings, as I chop and steam, slice and fry. Weekends unmoor me. Anything could happen. Nothing might. So I shower a pork butt with salt and sugar and let it cure on Saturday, and Sunday it spends in the oven: my weekly bo ssam (above), David Chang and Peter Meehans gift to the world. At least Ive got that.

title: Youre Getting Used to Masks. Will You Wear a Face Shield?
description: The debate over whether Americans should wear face masks to control coronavirus transmission has been settled. Governments and businesses now require or at least recommend them in many public settings. But as parts of the country reopen, some doctors want you to consider another layer of personal protective equipment in your daily life: clear plastic face shields.

title: The Unexpected Joys of Lockdown
description: Arithmetic, wrote Carl Sandburg in a famous poem, is where numbers fly like pigeons in and out of your head.

title: The Most Patriotic Thing You Can Do Right Now
description: Thank you, Americans.

title: My Futile Struggle for Stillness
description: ZIPOLITE, Mexico  When in mid-March Quedate En Casa, or stay at home, became the coronavirus rallying cry for the Spanish-speaking world, I had just arrived from El Salvador to the village of Zipolite on the coast of southeastern Oaxaca State in Mexico.

title: The Fall of Autumn: Live Performance Producers Are Giving Up on 2020
description: In the world of performing arts, the coronavirus pandemic has already sunk summer. Now it is felling fall.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: 100,000: The Names Behind a Grim Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: New Vaccine Team Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: June Willenz, Champion of Women in the Military, Dies at 95
description: June A. Willenz, a longtime human rights activist and champion of women in the military, died on May 3 in Bethesda, Md. She was 95.

title: College Students Colonize the Divided Romania of Mad Forest
description: Revolution has come to Bucharest, and a society has exploded into shards. A multitude of writhing, flailing, falling bodies fills the screen during the climax of the second act of Ashley Tatas fervently inventive new streaming version of Caryl Churchills Mad Forest, a coproduction of Theater for a New Audience and the Fisher Center at Bard College.

title: Sal Capozucca, Rock Drummer with a Real Estate Gig, Dies at 65
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: World TeamTennis Plans to Play Its Entire Season in West Virginia
description: World TeamTennis, the coed professional tennis league that has operated in summers after Wimbledon since the 1970s, has chosen a site in West Virginia to conduct its entire 2020 season, according to several people familiar with the leagues plans.

title: Trump Promotes Posts From Racist and Sexist Twitter Feed
description: WASHINGTON  On a weekend when the nation was bracing for the approaching toll of 100,000 lives lost to the coronavirus and honoring the many more people who have died in wars, President Trump amplified a series of demeaning personal attacks from a supporter with a history of racist and sexist online commentary.

title: Gallery Sues Landlord, Claiming Covid-19 Shutdown Voids Lease
description: In early March, the Venus Over Manhattan gallery on the Upper East Side mounted an exhibition of paintings, drawings and wall reliefs by the artist Roy De Forest, the biggest presentation of his work in New York City since 1975.

title: There Are No Flag-Draped Coffins
description: I had loaned my body to America. Thats what the Navy doctor said, as he poked and prodded me in his office during my separation physical. After eight years in the Marines and two wars, I was in remarkably good shape, so I didnt expect to receive any disability from the Department of Veterans Affairs. However, my doctor wasnt entirely convinced. When he asked whether I suffered chronic pain from the grenade shrapnel in my back, I said no. When he asked whether I suffered blackouts or short-term memory loss after a handful of head-ringing encounters with improvised explosive devices, I again said no. Still, he recommended me for disability. The reason: hearing loss. I had passed my audiogram but, according to the doctor, that didnt matter. Someday, Id likely need hearing aids, he said, and the government had to budget for that. You loaned society your body, he said. Its our obligation to return it to you with interest.

title: Pixar Short Film Out Features Studios First Gay Main Character
description: The man nervously practices in front of his dog how he is going to tell his parents he is gay.

title: Mory Kante, Million-Selling African Singer and Bandleader, Dies at 70
description: Mory Kante, a Guinean singer, kora player and bandleader who built a worldwide audience for music rooted in West Africa, died on Friday in Conakry, Guinea. He was 70.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Thousands of demonstrators streamed into some of Hong Kongs busiest neighborhoods on Sunday in the citys largest street mobilization in months. The police responded with tear gas, pepper spray and water cannons.

title: Michael Halkias, Who Promised Wish Fulfillment at Banquet Hall, Dies at 82
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Boris Johnson Backs Top Aide Accused of Flouting Lockdown Rules
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Boris Johnson, defying a storm of criticism, said on Sunday that he would not dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, for breaching Britains lockdown rules by driving across the country to visit relatives, even when he was falling ill with the coronavirus.

title: Hana Kimura, Japanese Wrestler and Star of Netflix Series, Dies at 22
description: Hana Kimura, a Japanese professional wrestler who starred in the Netflix reality series Terrace House: Tokyo, has died. She was 22.

title: The Virus Has Wrecked Some Families. It Has Brought Others Closer.
description: The coronavirus has smothered New York Citys economy and sealed off its museums and concert halls like crime scenes. Many people have filled the void with something that has always been there, close at hand but often crowded out of reach: their families.

title: Surinames President Shrugs Off Murder Sentence in Re-election Bid
description: Surinames president looked straight at the judge as she read his sentence for crimes committed during the 1982 political purge that cemented his grip on the small South American nation.

title: What Just Happened?
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  First, I wish you all a contemplative and peaceful Memorial Day. Its not the same during the pandemic, I know, but I hope that in lieu of the picnics and vacations, we can turn our attention to the men and women who have given their lives while serving in the United States military.

title: As Trump Pushes for Reopenings, Congregations Choose Safety Over Haste
description: ATLANTA  For the first time in weeks, Jason Dees looked out as he preached on Sunday and saw faces, instead of just a camera lens. The group of Christ Covenant Church worshipers was considerably smaller than before the coronavirus pandemic  40 people this week, wearing masks as they sang and prayed, a small fraction of the congregations 500 members but they were there.

title: Camp Is Canceled. Three More Months of Family Time. Help.
description: Summer is upon us, and many summer camps across the Northeast  and other parts of the country  have been canceled. We all know what this means: three more months of family togetherness! 270 more meals! 540 if you have teenagers! All without the nominal structure of online school! Whos excited?

title: Florida Law Restricting Felon Voting Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
description: MIAMI  A Florida law requiring people with serious criminal convictions to pay court fines and fees before they can register to vote is unconstitutional, a federal judge ruled on Sunday, declaring that such a requirement would amount to a poll tax and discriminate against felons who cannot afford to pay.

title: Trump Tweets and Golfs, but Makes No Mention of Viruss Toll
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trumps motorcade pulled into his golf club in Virginia on an overcast Sunday, a small group of protesters waited outside the entrance. One held up a sign.

title: C.D.C. Warns of Aggressive Rats Searching for Food During Shutdowns
description: Humans are not the only ones who miss dining out.

title: The New Model Media Star Is Famous Only to You
description: Back in March, I was trying to persuade my dad to stop taking the subway to work in Manhattan and join me upstate. So I paid $75 to Leonard Marshall, a retired New York Giants defensive lineman we both loved in the 1980s, to send the message.

title: Biden Can Beat Trump  if He Doesnt Blow It
description: As the United States death toll raced toward 100,000, Donald Trump went golfing.

title: He Died at War. The Pandemic Gave Me Time to Grieve.
description: When I met Diego D. Pongo at the gym, neither of us was looking for a relationship. I was preparing to deploy to Iraq for just over six months, and he was more focused on being a good parent to his young daughter than on dating. He was a Marine Raider with U.S. Marine Special Operations Command out of Camp Lejeune in North Carolina. I offered him a ride back to his work, though it was only a two-minute walk from the gym. He agreed, and gave me his number as he got out of my car. I put it in my phone as Handsome Diego. On one of our first dates, we took a long walk through the marshes surrounding North Topsail Beach, on the North Carolina coast. While the tide was out, we walked out to a small island a couple hundred feet from the shore. I wondered if I had foolishly fallen too hard for him right before a deployment. We had agreed that this wouldnt become anything serious. Neither of us noticed the rising tide that would soon leave us stranded. He held my shoes and clothes over his head and led the way as we waded through the cold water, cutting our feet on slivers of shells while we scrambled back to the beach.

title: U.S. Bans Flights From Brazil, Where Pandemic Is Raging
description: [Read more on Brazils Coronavirus cases and deaths.]

title: Tiger vs. Phil (and Tom vs. Peyton) Turn Rivalry Into Laughs
description: The charity golf match pitting Tiger Woods and Peyton Manning against Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady on Sunday figured to be good TV. It had big names, longstanding rivalries spanning two sports, an intriguing combination of talents and the prospect of the unforeseen.

title: Billions Season 5, Episode 4: Hometown Hero
description: Wendy Rhoades stares at the man opposite her. And stares. And stares. And stares some more.

title: New Zealand Earthquake Interrupts Jacinda Arderns TV Interview
description: A sizable earthquake struck New Zealand on Monday, shaking Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern during a live television interview, but failing to cause major damage or disrupt Ms. Arderns calm demeanor.

title: James Bonds Car Comes to Life With Oil-Slick Sprayer, but No Ejector Seat
description: James Bond is lonely. Its just 007 and his gadget-laden 1965 Aston Martin DB5 these days. He hasnt had any company since his last passenger was ejected. His car phone cant call anyone; for one thing, its inventor didnt remember to include a dial. His radar-mapping system is frozen on some place in rural Sussex, and just emits beeps like a sonar signal from a submarine movie.

title: As the U.S. Honors Memorial Day, Trump Threatens to Move Republican Convention
description: This briefing has ended. Read live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.

title: Hong Kong, Dominic Cummings, New Zealand: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: He Thought He Was Getting Football Physicals. He Was Being Abused.
description: For more than 40 years, Chuck Christian did not call himself a victim because he did not think he was one.

title: Whats on TV Monday: Uncut Gems and Grant
description: UNCUT GEMS (2019) Stream on Netflix; rent on Amazon, Vudu and YouTube. The combination of Adam Sandlers performance in an atypical role and the Safdie brothers energetic and adventurous style made waves when this crime thriller arrived in theaters last year. Sandler plays Howard Ratner, a jeweler and gambler who hopes that a black opal he has acquired from Ethiopia will be the key to his salvation. His plan, however, is quickly thrown into disarray by the basketball player Kevin Garnett, playing himself, who wants to borrow the gemstone for good luck. As he tries to extricate himself from one jam after another, Ratner must also contend with his estranged wife, Dinah (Idina Menzel), his mercurial mistress, Julia (Julia Fox), and his loan shark brother-in-law Arno (Eric Bogosian).

title: Corrections: May 25, 2020
description: The full-page presentation on Sunday that listed the names of people whose lives were lost to the coronavirus pandemic included several errors. The list erroneously included Jordan Driver Haynes. Mr. Haynes did not die of virus-related causes; his memorial service was delayed because of the outbreak. The following names were also erroneously included because of a misreading of local obituaries: John A. Rocco, Fannie Mae Person, Richard Wayne Cannon, Dorothea Elaine Young-Lane, Stephen Wald Levine, Robert L. Scarpino Jr., Elmer J. David and Jagdish C. Agarwal. The listing also omitted the surname of a professor at Gloucester County College. He was Henry Burk Sullivan, not Burk. It also omitted the surname of a master jeweler from Alpine, N.J. He was Fritz Wilhelm Reisgies, not Wilhelm. It misspelled the surname of a woman from Brookville, N.Y., who died on April 13. She was Joan M. Heaney, not Heany. The list also misstated Randall Clayton Frenchs age. He was 39, not 29.

title: The Cost of Rushing Back to Sports: A Stars Life
description: Nobody made much of it when Joe Hall skated off the ice.

title: A 96-Year-Old Veteran Was Near Death. Then He Met His Social Worker.
description: The outlook for the patient assigned to Capt. Eric Dungan on May 1 was bleak: George Crouch, 96, seemed to have given up on life.

title: This Cars Yearly Tune-Up Costs as Much as a Civic
description: Ive never piloted the Concorde; but in early March, just before the coronavirus-fueled lockdown, I drove what may be the closest road equivalent to a luxury aircraft: the Bugatti Chiron.

title: The Coronavirus Is Deadliest Where Democrats Live
description: [Follow our live coronavirus pandemic updates.]

title: As Passengers Disappeared, Airlines Filled Planes With Cargo
description: Most passenger planes today fly virtually empty, but when Virgin Atlantic flight VS251 landed at Heathrow Airport near London on a cloudy afternoon late last month, most of its 258 seats were occupied.

title: African-Americans Are Highly Visible in the Military, but Almost Invisible at the Top
description: WASHINGTON  A photograph of President Trump and his top four-star generals and admirals, tweeted in October by Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper, was meant as a thank-you to the commander in chief. But it angered a lot of others, and not just those who erupted on Twitter.

title: Hannah Gadsby on Comedy Trolls, Anti-Vaxxers and Burying Her Dog
description: People who want to hate me  theres nothing I can do about it.

title: The Crisis at My Husbands Nursing Home
description: For the last three and a half years, my husband has lived at the Isabella Geriatric Center, a two-tower high-rise nursing home in the heart of Washington Heights. In a period of six weeks, as many as 98 people living there died from Covid-19.

title: Is the Age of the Road Trip Over Forever?
description: LOS ANGELES  In the age when it was coolest to be an American, we took to the roads, the seas and the air. We saw the country and the world.

title: Joe Rogan Is the New Mainstream Media
description: When I saw the news that the king of all podcasting, Joe Rogan, had inked a deal with Spotify for his widely popular show I texted to congratulate him on getting crazy rich. How rich?

title: Hoping for a Covid Vaccine and Recalling the One for Smallpox
description: As many people check the news compulsively for even the smallest positive word on vaccine development, we are at an anniversary moment in vaccine history. We are between the anniversary of the day  May 14, 1796  that Edward Jenner inoculated 8-year-old James Phipps with cowpox virus, and the day  July 1, 1796  that he tested his new process by inoculating the same child with smallpox virus, to find out whether he was protected.

title: Join Us for a Look at a Century of Progress for Women
description: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern). You can find the full calendar here.

title: Its Not Obesity. Its Slavery.
description: About five years ago, I was invited to sit in on a meeting about health in the African-American community. Several important figures in the fields of public health and economics were present. A freshly minted Ph.D., I felt strangely like an interloper. I was also the only black person in the room.

title: Business Casual? Its Robes and Slippers All Day Now
description: When Dr. Denise McDermott, 49, isnt seeing patients for telehealth appointments, theres a good chance shes wearing a robe. In fact, as soon as she and her 11-year-old son finish the video portion of their work and school days, they both make the switch. Its become our joke during the pandemic: Were the robe family, said Dr. McDermott, a psychiatrist in Manhattan Beach, Calif.

title: Donald Trump, Joe Biden and the Vote of the Irish
description: In 2016, my vantage point on the donnybrook between Donald and Hillary was an Irish bar in Queens, where I was a bartender a few nights a week. It was a cash-only joint that sometimes stayed open until 7 a.m. and sold discounted cigarettes driven up from Virginia, the sort of place where you could make $800 under the table but you also might get a bottle or a chair thrown at you. This was where I watched the presidential debates and noticed something interesting. Half the patrons were Irish immigrants who considered Mr. Trump a real eejit, but the other half, the Irish Americans, thought he was just grand.

title: All Alone in a Three-Bedroom Apartment
description: Bonnie Blue Edwards had long fantasized about taking over her three-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where she has spent 10 years living with roommates. But when both of her roommates moved out in March  one departure was planned, the other wasnt  it was far from a dream scenario.

title: Chairing a Gala While Stuck in Mustique
description: With the New York gala scene on hiatus, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

title: In Memphis, Journalism Can Still Bring Justice
description: NASHVILLE  Wendi C. Thomas launched MLK50 in 2017 as a one-year project to make the 50th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a time to consider the current state of economic justice in the city where he was murdered while advocating for a living wage.

title: To Fight Covid-19, Dont Neglect Immunity and Inflammation
description: While most people focus, as they should, on social distancing, face coverings, hand washing and even self-isolation to protect against the deadly coronavirus now ravaging the country, too few are paying serious attention to two other factors critically important to the risk of developing a Covid-19 infection and its potential severity.

title: Couples Who Eat Together May Not Stay Together
description: Since the pandemic lockdown began, Marianne Andrews, Jonathan Miller and their two teenagers have been eating dinner together every night, and sometimes lunch.

title: Wealthiest Hospitals Got Billions in Bailout for Struggling Health Providers
description: A multibillion-dollar institution in the Seattle area invests in hedge funds, runs a pair of venture capital funds and works with elite private equity firms like the Carlyle Group.

title: Help! One Company Refused to Refund Travelers More Than $100,000
description: My trip to Egypt with Overseas Adventure Travel was scheduled to depart in late March. O.A.T. canceled the tour because of Covid-19, which was a relief. The company notified me of the cancellation and offered either a credit for rebooking or a full refund that would have included airfare. The next week, I learned via email that I had been rebooked on the same trip next year. Unbeknown to me, the stated policy had changed: O.A.T. was no longer offering refunds. I told them that I had a medical condition and did not know when  or if  I would be able to travel, and asked whether they were just going to keep my $17,500 if I couldnt travel by the end of 2021. Answer: Yes.

title: How to Save Sleepaway Camps
description: Imagine this: Just over the horizon, deep purple and orange skies, the sun setting behind emerald-green mountains. You and your partner are sitting close together, listening to the campfire musicians, while your children roast smores in the distance. Youre not even paying that much attention to them now  thats what the summer camp counselors are for. Instead youre sharing a laugh, about how terrible you were at rock climbing earlier that day. Those are exactly the kinds of restorative moments a family retreat at summer camp can provide.

title: Which Party Would Benefit Most From Voting by Mail? Its Complicated
description: WASHINGTON  Not so many months ago, casting a ballot by mail was a topic reserved for conferences of election administrators, a matter of voting mechanics blander than a water cracker. In Republican Arizona and Democratic Oregon as well as many other states, vast numbers of citizens not only voted by mail, but also loved it.

title: Its the Year 2120. MasterClass Is the Only School Left.
description: In mid-March, as much of the world withdrew into their homes, the celebrity-powered e-learning platform MasterClass began to notice that people who encountered its advertisements were often watching them in full.

title: Naming the Disappeared, Raising the Dead
description: This essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Timess philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, Why does art matter? The entire series can be found here.

title: Pass the Popcorn and Shhh! The Wedding Is About to Start
description: On what was supposed to be their wedding night, Lindsey Leaverton and Bri Houk sat in their car on the top floor of a parking garage in North Austin and ate pizza, watched the sunset and finished off a Yeti full of champagne. I put on a private concert for Bri and we danced under the stars, Ms. Leaverton said.

title: By Air and Sea, Mercenaries Landed in Libya. Then the Plan Went South.
description: CAIRO  Two former British marines piloted their boats, a pair of military-grade inflatables, across the Mediterranean from Malta. Six helicopters were flown in from Botswana using falsified papers. The rest of the team soldiers of fortune from South Africa, Britain, Australia and the United States  arrived from a staging area in Jordan.

title: Amy Schumer Misses Stand-Up. (I Should Have Said My Dad, but Thats Not the Truth.)
description: It didnt take long for Amy Schumer to shut down her old life. The first day I heard the term Wuhan market, that was it, she said in a recent interview. I was one of those people who was like: Pack your bags.

title: New Yorkers Embark on a Summer of Uncertainty
description: Memorial Day weekend in New York City usually marks the beginning of a vibrant summer to come.

title: The 7 Things You Need for an Ergonomic Workstation
description: After years of slumping at a desk, Ive begun to suffer the aches that come from having a poor work-space setup. The stiff chair, the desk thats too tall and the cramped laptop keyboard have all become literal pains in the neck (and shoulders and back and elsewhere). If your home-office setup is less than ideal, it may be time to upgrade the space ergonomically, especially now that most nonessential businesses plan to keep employees working from home indefinitely.

title: Quotation of the Day: Virus at Its Deadliest in the Strongholds of Democrats
description: I guess other people expect us to set our futures on fire to keep their fear warm. I think thats incredibly selfish  if youre that fearful, then just stay home.

title: Spains Courts, Already Strained, Face Crisis as Lockdown Lifts
description: MADRID  A flood of new court cases, some with little precedent, is expected to deluge a Spanish judicial system already gasping for breath, bogged down by delays and lagging in technology.

title: How Will We Remember the Pandemic? Museums Are Already Deciding
description: LOS ANGELES  Six-year-old Franklin Wong captured the simple frustration of being a student in this citys Unified School District in mid-March, after his classes were canceled. He wrote in big blocky letters: I did not go anywhere, and added an unhappy face in green and red crayon for his remote-learning assignment.

title: New Yorkers Mark a Subdued Memorial Day
description: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Tuesdays live coverage.]

title: Putin Speaks, Officials Shrug, and Doctors Are Caught in the Middle
description: MOSCOW  Assailed by critics as an absentee leader at the start of the coronavirus crisis in Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin re-emerged with a splash on state television last month to show that he cared and was taking charge.

title: What You Get for $1.25 Million in California
description: A one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco, a renovated midcentury house in Redondo Beach and a 1940 farmhouse in Sebastopol.

title: $1.25 Million Homes in California
description: The Redstone, a 24-unit condominium in the Russian Hill neighborhood, was designed by Henry Clay Smith, an early 20th-century architect known for his skill at building large structures on San Franciscos hilly terrain.

title: How a Pianist Salvaged His Lost Carnegie Hall Debut
description: Its a story that has become tragically common since the coronavirus pandemic brought live performances to a halt: The composer and pianist Timo Andres spent months preparing for his Carnegie Hall recital debut this spring. Then the concert was canceled.

title: Coronavirus Threatens Chinas Devotion to Chopsticks and Sharing Food
description: At Chilli Kitchen in Beijing, spicy and mouth-numbing Sichuan dishes are laid out family style. Using red chopsticks, diners dive into steaming bowls of pork wontons bathed in fragrant chili oil and sesame seeds, and rummage through platters filled with dried red chili peppers to unearth juicy bits of roasted fish.

title: The Paradox of Memorial Day
description: Good morning. One hundred and one years ago, the American ambassador to France, Hugh Wallace, invited President Woodrow Wilson to speak at a Memorial Day ceremony near Paris, to honor American doughboys killed during World War I. The president had been in France for months attending to the peace process and was in ill health, a victim of the flu epidemic that had begun to roil the world the previous year. Still, he rallied:

title: Trump Threatens to Pull Republican National Convention From North Carolina
description: President Trump on Monday threatened to yank the Republican National Convention from Charlotte, N.C., where it is scheduled to be held in August, accusing the states Democratic governor of being in a shutdown mood that could prevent a fully attended event.

title: Virgin Orbit Launch Attempt Ends Without Trip to Space
description: Strap a rocket to the underside of a plane. Fly it up several miles. Drop it. The engine ignites, and the rocket and its payload zoom to space.

title: On a Scottish Isle, Nursing Home Deaths Expose a Covid-19 Scandal
description: On the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, residents thought they had sealed themselves off from the coronavirus. They shuttered hotels. Officials warned of police checks. Traffic emptied on the only bridge from the mainland.

title: Fear of Covid-19 Leads Other Patients to Decline Critical Treatment
description: It was the call Lance Hansen, gravely ill with liver disease, had been waiting weeks for, and it came just before midnight in late April. A liver was available for him. He got up to get dressed for the three-hour drive to San Francisco for the transplant surgery.

title: When Mrs. Became an Uncomfortable Fit
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Bookstores Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Biden, Wearing Mask, Appears in Public at a Veterans Memorial
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has been campaigning from his home for more than two months during the coronavirus crisis, on Monday made his first public appearance since mid-March, visiting a veterans memorial in Delaware.

title: For Kenny Chesney and Others, Promotion in a Pandemic Is a Quandary
description: Kenny Chesney was supposed to take the stage last month in his signature straw hat and weathered boots at the AT&T Stadium in Dallas. The event was designed to help kick off an album, Here And Now, on which he had worked for about three years.

title: ISIS Prisoners Threaten U.S. Mission in Northeastern Syria
description: WASHINGTON  A year after American-backed forces seized the last remnant of territory under Islamic State rule in Syria, some 10,000 captured ISIS fighters in Kurdish-run wartime prisons pose a significant risk to the United States mission in the countrys northeast, military commanders say.

title: Future Lands a Seventh No. 1 Album
description: Hip-hop dominates the Billboard album chart once again, as Future reaches No. 1 with High Off Life, the seventh time in the last three months a rap album has held the top spot.

title: He Placed in a Virtual Race. But His Racing Was Too Virtual.
description: Daniel Abt might be a successful driver on the Formula E circuit, the racecar series normally using electric cars, but he had not been so good at the virtual races that are substituting for the real thing during the coronavirus pandemic. In the first four races, he had failed to score a point.

title: Lufthansa to Receive $10 Billion Bailout
description: Lufthansa will receive a bailout worth 9 billion euros, or $9.8 billion, to help the airline survive an existential emergency caused by the pandemic and a virtual shutdown of passenger air traffic, the German government said Monday.

title: Gucci Says Fashion Shows Should Never Be the Same
