description: Some of President Trumps most stalwart media defenders broke ranks with him on Wednesday, aghast at his baseless smears against the MSNBC host Joe Scarborough, whom Mr. Trump has all but accused of killing a former staff member two decades ago despite a total lack of evidence.

title: DeVos Demands Public Schools Share Pandemic Aid With Private Institutions
description: WASHINGTON  Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, defiant amid criticism that she is using the coronavirus to pursue a long-sought agenda, said she would force public school districts to spend a large portion of federal rescue funding on private school students, regardless of income.

title: Judge Who Asked Woman if She Closed Her Legs to Prevent Assault Is Removed
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge who asked a woman if she had closed her legs to try to prevent a sexual assault has been ordered removed from the bench by the states highest court, which concluded his behavior made it inconceivable that he could ever handle cases of domestic violence or sexual assault.

title: Renault and Nissan Unveil Plan to Patch Tattered Alliance
description: TOKYO  Nissan and Renault, the quarrelsome main partners in the worlds largest automaking alliance, announced a plan on Wednesday to try to reset their troubled relationship as they seek to survive the coronaviruss devastating impact on the car industry.

title: Do You Have Video of George Floyds Arrest?
description: [Read more about George Floyd and Derek Chauvin once working together.]

title: Now on Netflix: Portraits of Grief With Unplanned Relevance
description: Heart-thumping crushes, rivalries, unsupervised parties, a volcanic cocktail of hormones  weve all been there, and so has a whole subgenre of popular television series. The teen high school comedy-drama, rife with hallway gaffes and under-bleacher kisses, is comfort food for those of us willing to revisit the carnival of frights that is adolescence  or imagine a totally different, fully stylized teenage experience (say, one of impossibly attractive 20-somethings acting out soap opera-worthy plotlines between Algebra and gym).

title: Disney World Is Reopening, but You Wont Be Able to Hug Mickey
description: Walt Disney World, one of the largest tourist sites on the planet, has a plan to reopen in mid-July. But the necessary safety protocols  limiting the number of visitors, making face masks mandatory, deploying roaming squads to enforce social distancing, no longer allowing people to get up close and personal with Mickey Mouse  shows how difficult it will be to operate once-booming attractions as the country prepares for a broader reopening.

title: Sweaty Scrums? How Rugby May Adapt to Return to Play
description: Three big men lock arms. Three from the other team do the same. At the referees signal, they lunge toward each other, their faces inches apart.

title: The Bird Watcher, That Incident and His Feelings on the Womans Fate
description: His binoculars around his neck, Christian Cooper, an avid birder, was back in his happy place on Wednesday: Central Park during migration season. He was trying to focus on the olive-sided flycatchers and red-bellied woodpeckers  not on what had happened there two days earlier.

title: Oh No, Here Comes the Transportation Hellscape
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: How Studio Ghibli Went From Streaming Holdout to HBO Max Star
description: HBO Max kicked off Wednesday with an abundance of noisy hit Warner Bros. movies (like Wonder Woman and the entire Harry Potter franchise) and heralded television shows (Game of Thrones, Friends). Yet tucked inside the platforms 10,000 hours of programming is a jewel of a film catalog from the Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli, which has garnered both accolades and critical reverence in its 35-year history but whose work has remained elusive to the many streaming services that have come calling over the years.

title: Trumps False Tweets, and Twitters Response
description: To the Editor:

title: N. Carolina Speedway Packs Its Stands, Drawing Governors Rebuke
description: Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina has rebuked the operator of Ace Speedway in Elon, N.C., which last weekend conducted races at which fans packed the stands without face masks or social distancing, but he stopped short of blocking a race planned for Friday.

title: Coronavirus Isnt Keeping Florida Crowds From SpaceX Launch
description: NASA has urged spectators to stay away from the Kennedy Space Center for Wednesdays SpaceX launch to limit the spread of the coronavirus. But officials from cities and counties around the launch site, an area known as Floridas Space Coast, are expecting large crowds to gather to watch the countrys first astronaut launch in nine years.

title: Space Force Review: Steve Carell, in a Familiar Orbit on Netflix
description: Theres a statistical likelihood that your image of Steve Carell is based primarily on The Office, and on the films The 40-Year-Old Virgin and Anchorman before that. In the streaming age it wouldnt even be surprising if one of those venerable comedies was the last thing you watched him in. What are the odds that when you think of Carell you think of Welcome to Marwen or Battle of the Sexes or Last Flag Flying, recent movies whose box office ranged from poor to dismal?

title: Ravi Zacharias, Preacher Who Used Reason to Defend Faith, Dies at 74
description: Ravi Zacharias, an evangelist and author who became an important voice for Christians by making a rational argument for the existence of God and vigorously defending the faith against atheists, relativists, Buddhists and other challengers, died on May 19 at his home in Atlanta. He was 74.

title: 54 Ways Coronavirus Has Changed Our World
description: Looking at a pandemics ups and downs.

title: Lockdown Taught Me to Care for My Natural Hair
description: For the first time in as long as I can remember, I miss the salon. Which isnt to say that I miss the many minutes or sometimes hours spent waiting for the hairdresser to take you, even though you arrived for your appointment early; or the punishing heat of the dryer, which makes you hot behind the ears and sweaty at the nape of your neck; or the inevitable rough tug of the hairdresser and the urgent apology  Sorry!  as she combs through a stubborn tangle.

title: Dead Inside: The Morgue Trucks of New York City
description: It was nearly two months ago when the first white refrigerated trucks began to appear on the streets of New York City. They were meant as a temporary solution to help overwhelmed hospitals and morgues house the bodies of people who had succumbed to Covid-19. The pandemic has now left nearly 30,000 dead in New York  and about 205 of the vehicles, sent by the Federal Emergency Management Agency or purchased by the medical examiners office, are stationed across the city.

title: Boris Johnson Defends Toxic Aide Again. Why Protect a Political Burden?
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Boris Johnson went to the mat yet again on Wednesday for his embattled adviser, Dominic Cummings, signaling to lawmakers that he had no plans to dismiss Mr. Cummings for breaching the rules by driving 260 miles to his parents house during the countrys coronavirus lockdown.

title: A White Damsel Leveraged Racial Power and Failed
description: The symbolism is almost too much to bear. The antagonist stares down the barrel of the camera, removing her surgical face mask at the same moment she takes off her figurative mask and offers the audience a glimpse into what lies beneath. The woman, Amy Cooper, points her finger at the stranger behind the camera, Christian Cooper, to demand that he stop filming her. When he refuses, she threatens to call the police and then immediately acts on her threat.

title: Nursing Home Operator Genesis Details Coronavirus Aid
description: The nations biggest nursing home operator, Genesis HealthCare, has received more than $300 million in government grants and loans to help it grapple with the coronavirus pandemic that has killed about 1,500 of its residents.

title: Trumps Economic Advisers Are Wrong
description: Like dutiful soldiers, President Trumps top economic advisers have been ardently echoing their bosss optimism about the likelihood of a quick economic snapback, while downplaying the need for another rescue package.

title: What Would Happen if Twitter Banned Trump?
description: Every few months the same debate re-emerges: Should Twitter ban Donald Trump? Usually, its because of something particularly egregious, conspiratorial, untrue or geopolitically reckless that the president tweeted. Many of these tweets would result in a takedown or a temporary suspension if they came from a normal users account, but Twitter has made an exception for heads of state, citing a newsworthiness clause that allows the company to evade responsibility.

title: Hong Kong, Stimulus, Huawei: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has told Congress that Hong Kong no longer merits special treatment under U.S. laws, a move signaling that the Trump administration will most likely end the U.S. preferential trade relationship with the territory.

title: Activists and Celebrities Honor Larry Kramers Brash Advocacy
description: Activists, celebrities, community leaders and L.G.B.T. groups reacted to the death of the longtime H.I.V. and AIDS activist Larry Kramer on Wednesday, sharing memories of his fiery passion and advocacy in tributes on social media.

title: Childrens Lives at Stake
description: To the Editor:

title: Coronavirus Epidemics Began Later Than Believed, Study Concludes
description: The first confirmed coronavirus infections in Europe and the United States, discovered in January, did not ignite the epidemics that followed, according to a close analysis of hundreds of viral genomes.

title: Partying on Minecraft, in a Replica of a Brooklyn Club
description: On a recent Friday, thousands of partygoers gathered on the rooftop of a popular Brooklyn club to hear a performance by Alice Glass, the former front woman of the Canadian electronic band Crystal Castles.

title: A Deeply Flavorful Grain Salad, Full of Lemony Flavor
description: I cooked up a pound of dried chickpeas over the weekend, and Ive loved the freedom of being able to just toss a handful into almost everything weve been eating  or at least everything that could benefit from their savoriness.

title: At Cape Canaveral, Trumps Search for a Heroic Narrative Is Thwarted
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  For President Trump, it was a chance to rewrite the story line from tragedy to triumph. Even as the United States reached the grim milestone on Wednesday of 100,000 dead from the coronavirus pandemic, he would help mark the nations trailblazing return to human spaceflight from American soil.

title: How to Use Zoom Like a Theater or Film Professional
description: Since the pandemic forced theaters to close their doors in mid-March, there has been no shortage of noble attempts to recreate the magic of the stage on streaming platforms including Zoom, Instagram Live and YouTube (where the Broadway interview show Stars in the House streams two theater productions daily). Virtual theater productions, of course, are mediated through technology and thus not experienced as they would be from the front mezzanine, and yet theyre not fully polished or always prerecorded, either. Part of the thrill of theater is its immediacy and, along with it, the potential for something to fall to pieces. That aspect remains perfectly intact, and recent performances have been felled by late starts, spotty internet and A/V connections, missed cues and poor lighting. It can all feel like the local portions of the Jerry Lewis telethon, jokes the producer and writer Jonathan Tolins. As though these actors might be in their laundry rooms.

title: States Sue to Block Trump From Weakening Fuel Economy Rules
description: Led by California, nearly two dozen states sued the Trump administration on Wednesday over its reversal of fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks, arguing that the move is based on erroneous science, and endangers public health.

title: A 750 Billion Virus Recovery Plan Thrusts Europe Into a New Frontier
description: BRUSSELS  For decades, even when the 2008 financial crisis threatened to blow the bloc apart, the European Unions wealthier nations resisted the notion of collective debt. But the coronavirus has so fundamentally damaged the blocs economy that it is now forcing European leaders to consider the sort of unified and sweeping response once thought unworkable.

title: Larry Kramer, Prophet and Pussycat
description: On the same sweltering Dallas day that later found him screaming at a crowd of gay revelers, I saw Larry Kramer offer water to a horse.

title: Tropical Storm Bertha Could Cause Dangerous Flooding in the South
description: A tropical storm named Bertha could bring heavy rain, whipping winds and potentially life-threatening flash floods to parts of the Carolinas and Virginia on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.

title: How Do I Get HBO Max if I Already Have HBO?
description: AT&Ts new streaming platform HBO Max went live on Wednesday, but for many HBO subscribers, it was not entirely clear whether they had access to the service.

title: Modern Love Podcast: Saoirse Ronan Reads Grappling With the Language of Love
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Just Sitting in Limbo. For Many Professionals, Careers Are on Hold.
description: After five years at the wellness industry start-up she co-founded in San Francisco, Hasti Nazem decided it was time for her next adventure in Silicon Valley. Her last day was March 5.

title: Remembering Larry Kramer
description: Larry Kramer, who died Wednesday at 84, was, in so many words, a force. The rare activist to become a household name, he fought tirelessly for people with H.I.V. and AIDS, and against a largely indifferent government and public, first as a founding member of the Gay Mens Health Crisis, and then through the more protest-oriented AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power  or ACT UP  which he co-founded in 1987. Many tried to dismiss Kramer as overly brash, but his and his cohorts success in lessening stigma and spurring research and care is undeniable.

title: SpaceX Launch of NASA Astronauts Is Postponed Over Weather
description: [When to watch SpaceXs next NASA launch of astronauts.]

title: Steve Hann, Sidewalk Bookseller With a Brainy Following, Dies at 67
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Is Takeout and Delivery Food Safe?
description: As America begins to reopen for business, restaurants in several states have reopened for indoor dining. Others, like those in Connecticut and New Mexico, are serving outdoors only. Restaurants in New York City and Los Angeles allow no sit-down service at all.

title: SpaceX, Hong Kong, Larry Kramer: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Twitter Comes Under Attack From Trumps Supporters
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Not long after Twitter added a warning label to two of President Trumps tweets on Tuesday, his supporters swung into action.

title: House Passes Uighur Human Rights Bill, Prodding Trump to Punish China
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to pass a measure that would punish top Chinese officials for detaining more than one million Muslims in internment camps, sending President Trump a bill intended to force him to take a more aggressive stand on human rights abuses in China.

title: Oliver Williamson, 87, Dies; Nobel Laureate Studied Organizations
description: Oliver E. Williamson, an economist whose groundbreaking work on analyzing the structure of organizations was honored with the 2009 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, died on May 21 in Oakland, Calif. He was 87.

title: How Do You Lead a States Coronavirus Response? Ask Her
description: Dr. Ngozi Ezike, director of the Illinois Department of Health

title: Rosenstein to Testify on Russia Inquiry to Panel Led by Trump Ally
description: WASHINGTON  The former deputy attorney general Rod J. Rosenstein will testify before senators next week in a hearing that will give President Trumps allies a high-profile platform to escalate their attacks on the Russia investigation.

title: QuarantineChat Brings Back Spontaneity (and Distraction)
description: Like many people, my life in quarantine has included doses of grief, solitude and unpredictability. In early April, a friend recommended that I try QuarantineChat, an app that connects two people who dont know each other for a phone call. Youll love it, she said.

title: Barbara Sher, 84, Dies; Prescribed Self-Help With a Dose of Humor
description: Positive affirmations gave her a headache. She often said she didnt believe in self-improvement, but found she had a knack for helping people make their lives better.

title: As a Federal Coronavirus Expert Frets, the Capital Moves to Reopen
description: WASHINGTON  The leaders around the nations capital are pushing forward with plans to reopen the region, hoping they are close enough to their public health goals to move toward normalcy despite coronavirus infection rates that have alarmed federal officials.

title: Trump Will Have His Coronation
description: On the somber occasion of Memorial Day, President Trump delivered a message to Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina: Nice little convention you have planned. Shame if anything happened to it.

title: Julin Castro: Its a Totally Porous Safety Net
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Twitter Tsks, and Trump Fumes
description: To use his own ludicrous metaphor, President Trump could once shoot someone on Twitters Fifth Avenue and get away with it.

title: Gabriel Bacquier, 95, Dies; Set Standard for French Baritones
description: Gabriel Bacquier, a French baritone whose supple voice, immaculate diction and keen dramatic instincts made him a cherished presence in opera houses and on concert stages worldwide, died on May 13 at his home in Lestre, in Normandy, France. He was 95.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: This afternoon we received a grim note from Mitch Smith, one of the reporters who keep track of The Timess database of coronavirus-related deaths: We crossed 100,000 known deaths at about 3:40 E.T. with new data from Illinois.

title: Minneapolis Police, Long Accused of Racism, Face Wrath of Wounded City
description: [Follow our live coverage of the protests in Minneapolis over George Floyds death.]

title: Canadas Largest Newspaper Changes Hands Amid Vow to Keep Liberal Voice
description: OTTAWA  The new owners of The Toronto Star, Canadas largest newspaper by circulation, pledged on Wednesday to maintain its tradition of championing liberal causes in a news market dominated by conservative views.

title: On the Record Review: A Black Woman Says #MeToo
description: In her 1999 book, When Chickenheads Come Home to Roost: A Hip-Hop Feminist Breaks It Down, the cultural critic Joan Morgan describes eloquently the ways in which racism often makes it difficult for black women to call out sexism within their own communities. I needed a feminism that would allow us to continue loving ourselves and the brothers who hurt us without letting race loyalty buy us early tombstones, she wrote.

title: The Wonderful World of Trump Worsts
description: So hey, summers coming. Time for all Americans to get together and plan how to stay apart.

title: Will President Trump Stand With Hong Kong?
description: That Chinas Xi Jinping is taking more steps to bring Hong Kong under the central governments control should come as no surprise. President Xi has long made clear that he regards the enclaves freedoms as a Western thorn in his side. With the world fixated on the coronavirus pandemic, with relations with the United States at a low, and with 3,000 delegates gathered in Beijing for the annual propaganda-fest of the National Peoples Congress, he evidently concluded that this was the time to pounce, proposing a national security law that could allow Chinese authorities to crack down on civil liberties in Hong Kong.

title: U.S. to Penalize Work at Iranian Facilities in Latest Blow to Nuclear Accord
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department announced on Wednesday that it would begin imposing economic penalties on foreign businesses working at Iranian nuclear facilities, the latest effort by the Trump administration to dismantle an Obama-era accord with Tehran.

title: We Loved Each Other: Fauci Recalls Larry Kramer, Friend and Nemesis
description: How did I meet Larry? He called me a murderer and an incompetent idiot on the front page of the San Francisco Examiner magazine.

title: As Meatpacking Plants Look to Reopen, Some Families Are Wary
description: The plants have been hotbeds of viral spread. Will cleaning and safety measures be enough to protect workers from new outbreaks?

title: An American Jobs Crisis with Few Reporters to Cover It
description: In the rural West and around the country, newspapers are stuck at the intersection of a shrinking industry and crumbling local economies.

title: Amazons Big Breakdown
description: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees  by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.

title: When the Casinos Were Shuttered, the Money Dried Up in Las Vegas
description: By mid-May, 27.9 percent of Nevadas work force had filed for unemployment  not accounting for the undocumented population finding itself out of work.

title: Scenes From an Economic Collapse
description: The staggering spike in unemployment isnt just throwing individual families into poverty. Its gutting entire communities  in ways they might never recover from.

title: I Have a Dream
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Man, did this one ever take me down. Congratulations to the constructor, Tracy Bennett. You win. And its only Thursday.

title: How White Women Use Themselves as Instruments of Terror
description: At a time of so much death and suffering in this country and around the world from the Covid-19 pandemic, it can be easy, I suppose, to take any incidents that dont result in death as minor occurrences.

title: UConn Student Wanted in 2 Homicides, Peter Manfredonia, Is Caught in Maryland
description: A University of Connecticut student who had been wanted since Friday in the killing of two people was taken into custody on Wednesday night in Maryland after a multistate manhunt, the authorities said.

title: Basketball Hall of Fame Event Will Be Pushed to 2021, Colangelo Says
description: The Basketball Hall of Fame induction for an exceptionally illustrious class, including the late Kobe Bryant, will be postponed from August to next spring because of the coronavirus pandemic, Jerry Colangelo, the chairman of the Hall of Fames board of governors, said Wednesday.

title: The Asian Giant Hornet Resurfaces in the Pacific Northwest
description: SEATTLE  The Asian giant hornet has resurfaced in the Pacific Northwest, with two reported discoveries that indicate the invasive insect has already been circulating in a broader territory than previously known.

title: Quotation of the Day: Fury in Minneapolis Over Latest in a Long Line of Police Killings
description: It was painful to watch before I knew the person in the video was related to me. Now that I know this person is my flesh and blood, the pain is magnified a trillion times.

title: Corrections: May 28, 2020
description: The full-page presentation on Sunday that listed the names of people whose lives were lost to the coronavirus pandemic included several errors. The list erroneously included Helyn Dawson because of a misreading of a local obituary. The list also misstated Sandra Piotrowskis profession. She worked in the accounting departments of several manufacturing companies, not as a meat-cutter for Jewel supermarkets. The list misspelled the surname of a woman from Garrison, N.Y. She is Kerri Ann Kennedy-Tompkins, not Kennedy-Tomkins. The list misspelled the name of a woman from Philadelphia. She is Anibal Francisco de Brito; not Fracisco. It also misspelled the name of Jeffery Ronald Henry Muzljakovichs hometown. It is Centerbrook, Conn., not Centerbook. It also misstated several ages: Chad Capule was 49, not 50. Vincent G. Frainee was 68, not 89. Ruth Hunter was 96, not 94, Benjamin Di Giovanni was 90, not 91. Shidao Wang was 72, not 75.

title: Coronavirus Spread Speeds Up, Even as Nations Reopen
E.U. Aid, Dominic Cummings, U.S. Coronavirus Deaths: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Joan of Arc and Princess Mononoke
description: JOAN OF ARC (2020) Rent on Film at Lincoln Centers virtual cinema. In his 2018 historical drama, Jeannette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc, the French director Bruno Dumont infused Saint Joans formative years with a sonic landscape that featured prominent, raucous guitar shredding. For his follow-up, Joan of Arc, Dumont focuses on Joan of Arcs later years, this time using electronic pop music to help tell the story. The film casts one of the performers who played Joan in Dumonts earlier movie, Lise Leplat Prudhomme, opposite the French pop singer Christophe, who plays one of the priests who try Joan. Here and in the earlier picture its perhaps easy to apprehend Dumonts approach with a Whats this oddball up to now? smirk, Glenn Kenny wrote in his review for The New York Times. But if Dumont is joking at all, its a form of what used to be called kidding on the square.

title: G.E., Which Traces Its Roots to Thomas Edison, Sells Its Lighting Business
description: More than 140 years after Thomas Edison and his assistants conducted their first successful experiments with a carbon-filament lamp in a vacuum, the company he helped to found  General Electric  has sold its lighting business.

title: Trump Prepares Order to Limit Social Media Companies Protections
description: The Trump administration is preparing an executive order intended to curtail the legal protections that shield social media companies from liability for what gets posted on their platforms, two senior administration officials said early Thursday.

title: Word + Quiz: vagary
Restaurant Food
description: What restaurants have you missed the most during quarantine? What are your favorite dishes there? If you had the recipe, would you ever want try to recreate any of those dishes in your own kitchen? Why or why not?

title: Where Coronavirus Help on Facebook Is Inherently Political
description: The three young idealists met before this all started, when the most pressing issues they faced were climate change, environmental justice and ensuring clean water for Detroit residents. They were all organizers of a sort: eager to do the unglamorous work of convincing people that they could dream bigger, and demand more from their government.

title: Ai Weiwei Designs Masks With a Message
description: One mask depicts a middle finger, stuck defiantly upward, silk-screened in black ink on a blue background. Others feature sunflower seeds, a surveillance camera or creatures from ancient Chinese mythology. All these masks are works by the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei.

title: China Approves Plan to Rein In Hong Kong, Defying Worldwide Outcry
U.S. Jobless Claims Pass 40 Million: Live Business Updates
description: The multitrillion-dollar patchwork of federal and state relief programs has not kept bills from piling up or prevented long lines at food banks. But it has mitigated the damage. Now the expiration of those programs represents a cliff that many Americans and the economy are hurtling toward.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Floor Cookies
description: Myles writes: My partner works at a bakery. The other night she mentioned that she ate a floor cookie at work. Apparently, this is common at the bakery. When I took this matter to a group chat, I was met with a litany of items everyone had eaten off the floor that day, including wet noodles. Am I a germophobe, or am I surrounded by heathens?

title: In Coronavirus Advertising, Youre the Hero
description: In coronavirus-themed commercials, consumption is reframed as a public service performed by heroes, for heroes. Amanda Hess looks at how brands are selling shopping as a heroic act.

title: The World Is Still Far From Herd Immunity for Coronavirus
description: The latest studies show that even in the hardest-hit cities, most people remain vulnerable.

title: Two Renters Try Out the Amenities in Brooklyns Newer Buildings. Which of These Homes Would You Choose?
description: For their first home together, a young couple sought the best roof deck and gym they could find on a budget. Heres where they wound up.

title: The Novel That Made Jules Feiffer Ignore His Family on Vacation
description: The cartoonist, whose new picture book is Smart George, read Michael Chabons The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay on a trip to the Dominican Republic: For five days, I barely moved from the beach chair.

title: What Have You Learned About Yourself During This Lockdown?
description: When you think back to your first days in lockdown, what were some of your fears, worries and hopes? Are you the same person now that you were at the beginning of all this? What has changed about who you are and how you view the world?

title: Credibility and Converts: Revisiting Tara Reade and Jane Roe
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

title: Yes, It Is Possible to Change History. Write a Novel!
description: ALTERNATE ENDING From Philip Roths The Plot Against America to Monica Alis Untold Story, veteran novelists have long tinkered with real-life events. (Roth imagines Charles Lindbergh as president; Ali imagines an alternate life for Princess Diana ... in the American suburbs.) Curtis Sittenfeld is the latest to practice Jenga storytelling in her sixth novel, Rodham, which considers how the pieces of Hillary Rodham Clintons life might have fallen differently if she hadnt married Bill. Like its namesake, the book wins the popular vote, landing at No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list.

title: Poem: Pause
description: Poem to create a space. Poem to invite us in, out of ourselves, into a new place of being. Poem that helps us gather the hay bales, pull them together. Its a gift when a poem becomes its own little room so quickly. In David Wattss Pause, from Having and Keeping, we keenly feel the sense of slower time that many of us have experienced in isolation  indoors versus everywhere else, the sounds of weather, memories of the outer world pinging and humming. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

title: Making Home Safe for Kids This Summer
description: As stay-at-home orders drag on and summer approaches, parents and caregivers will need to be more aware than ever of accident risks in the home. More children spending more time staying at home and in the backyard means more needed supervision by parents who may be distracted by teleworking and caring for other family members, said Joe Martyak, director of communications for the Consumer Product Safety Commission. In this situation, kids exposure to risks goes up more than usual.

title: You Never Call Us. We Didnt Know You Cared.
description: My brother, sister and I wouldnt even answer the phone when our parents would call us. Years of damage from our fathers violence, years of disappointment at our mothers acquiescence, years of their tag-team invalidation of our hurt had left us estranged from them but inseparable as siblings.

title: Why Is the Fed Spending So Much Money on a Dying Industry?
description: The coronavirus pandemic has laid bare just how vulnerable the United States is to sudden, catastrophic shocks. Climate change poses the next big threat. Ignoring it, particularly to the benefit of fossil fuel interests, is a risk we cant afford.

title: Whats the Risk of Catching Coronavirus From a Surface?
description: Fears about catching the coronavirus from contaminated surfaces have prompted many of us to spend the past few months wiping down groceries, leaving packages unopened and stressing about touching elevator buttons.

title: The Perseverance of Andr Watts
description: Toward the end of 2019, the classical pianist Andr Watts was facing what seemed to be an insurmountable impediment. The last time he had encountered nerve damage in his left hand, back in 2004, an operation on a herniated disk led to rapid recovery. But this time the injury was not to the nerve sheath but to the nerve fiber, and after vertebra surgery, the prognosis was not good. Regeneration would take time; there was no guarantee that it would enable him to fully use his all-important left thumb. He canceled quite a few concerts, but would he have to relinquish his performance career altogether?

title: We Need a Voice for Public Health in the Presidents Cabinet
description: The coronavirus pandemic has exposed crucial shortcomings in our public health system. Plenty of experts said a pandemic was coming, but we ended up with a belated response that included a lack of coordination, inadequate funding and a failure to be strategic.

title: Youve Probably Heard Socialists Wont Vote for Biden
description: Its not easy being an American socialist these days  despite the fact that Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont built a movement of millions behind ideas we have long supported, were now being called out as potential spoilers in the November elections.

title: Libraries Must Change
description: As we face tragedy, devastating economic turmoil and dislocation, public libraries will play a key part in the recovery of our country, cities and lives. Libraries offer all people  regardless of background or circumstance  free access to the tools and knowledge they need to open doors of opportunity and be productive members of society. To remain true to their mission, all libraries must undergo radical change. To serve the public in the face of unprecedented challenges, libraries will need to transition their services to the virtual space and explore new avenues to serve the public and bring people together, even while we are apart.

title: Pamela Andersons Garden of Eden
description: Nothing can prepare you for FaceTiming Pamela Anderson. One second there is only you  staring, through a layer of iPhone glass, at your tired, trapped reflection, both of you hoping that is not how you actually look  and the next second there is Pamela Anderson, brightening the screen instantaneously and completely, the way a ray of sun stretching beyond a cloud can seem to bounce off the whole Pacific.

title: Trumps Horrifying Lies About Lori Klausutis May Cross a Legal Line
description: President Trump and his minions relentlessly grind out despicable acts  gratuitous insults to war heroes, over 18,000 (and counting) false or misleading statements, many decisions courts have ruled illegal. But Mr. Trumps wantonly cruel tweets about the tragic death in 2001 of Lori Klausutis are distinctive: They may constitute intentional torts for which a civil jury could award punitive damages against him.

title: 23 Poets Laureate Receive Fellowships for Projects Around the U.S.
description: The Academy of American Poets announced on Thursday the 23 recipients of its Poets Laureate Fellowships, who will use the $50,000 grants for civic projects throughout the United States, even as the coronavirus pandemic limits the in-person, community-based initiatives they typically develop.

title: Get Republicans to Vote Against Trump? This Group Will Spend $10 Million to Try
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, 50 of the countrys most senior Republican national security officials signed a letter declaring that Donald J. Trump would put the country at risk if he was elected president and that they would not vote for him.

title: Asserting Sovereignty, Indian Casinos Defy Californias Governor and Reopen
description: MORAGA, Calif.  It was a high-stakes gamble: a chance to win big at the slot machines but risk getting infected with the coronavirus. Braving a cold drizzle last week, hundreds placed their bet, lining up for hours in front of the Viejas Casino and Resort, a glass-and-stone Indian casino east of San Diego that was reopening despite pleas from Californias governor, Gavin Newsom.

title: When Art Is Medicine
description: MINNEAPOLIS  From our first contact with Europeans to the present, Indigenous people have careened from one public health crisis to another. Our healing process and our historical memory of these moments should not end with vaccinations. Traditions of song and dance help restore the balance that is drained by bodily sickness and deliver spiritual sustenance to those who have lost loved ones. Art, in other words, allows us to survive.

title: Senators Seek Answers on Coronavirus Protections at Guantnamo Bay
description: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

title: Should We Fear Post-Pandemic Inflation?
description: Its not just the usual inflation alarmists. Many people now see high inflation lurking around the corner, a world where, in the not-too-distant future, major economies will face upwardly spiraling prices.

title: U.S. to Expel Chinese Graduate Students With Ties to Chinas Military Schools
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration plans to cancel the visas of thousands of Chinese graduate students and researchers in the United States who have direct ties to universities affiliated with the Peoples Liberation Army, according to American officials with knowledge of the discussions.

title: The N.H.L. Is Coming Back, Pending a Few (Dozen) Questions
description: Now that the National Hockey League has announced this week its detailed road map for returning to action with a playoff tentatively set for mid-July, it can start focusing on all the steps needed to make its plan actually happen.

title: They Predicted The Crisis of 2020  in 1991. So How Does This End?
description: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

title: Camping in the West? Like Everything These Days, Its Complicated
description: In the West, cabin-feverish parents yearning to take their children into the woods, couples trying to escape quarantine pods and all campers who miss their beloved outdoors will this summer find a complicated camping landscape, one of new and conflicting laws, closings and reopenings, and strict requirements on social-distancing and hand-washing.

title: 10 Weeks Into New York Areas Lockdown, Who Is Still Getting Sick?
description: New York City has been locked down and shut off for more than two months.

title: What Does Art Have to Do With the Coronavirus?
description: This essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Timess philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, Why does art matter? The entire series can be found here.

title: Livestreams to Watch: A 10-Day Global Film Festival Begins and Concerts for All Tastes
description: Here are a few of the best events happening Thursday through Tuesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

title: Couple Bilked Medicaid for $13 Million to Pay for Lavish Lifestyle, U.S. Says
description: They shared photos on social media of their private jet, stacks of Tiffany & Company boxes and a crystal decanter of Louis XIII cognac, often accompanied by the hashtags #jetsetter, #millionaire, #billionaire and #entrepreneur.

title: Returning, and Awakening, to the Beauty of Rural Alabama
description: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, were turning to photojournalists to help transport you, virtually, to some of our planets most beautiful and intriguing places. In this weeks installment of The World Through a Lens, Scott Baker shares a collection of photographs from his hometown in Alabama.

title: Bidens Testing Strategy Sets Up a Clear Contrast With Trump on the Coronavirus
description: WASHINGTON  Joseph R. Biden Jr. has proposed harnessing the broad powers of the federal government to step up coronavirus testing, with a public-private board overseeing test manufacturing and distribution, federal safety regulators enforcing testing at work and at least 100,000 contact tracers tracking down people exposed to the virus.

title: The Mythic Performances That Are Keeping Me Company
description: Some 20 years ago, in a New York hotel suite on a late summer morning, I was raptly observing two fabled theater stars, Julie Harris and Christopher Plummer, in conversation. Both multiple Tony Award winners (five for her, two for him) whose stage appearances were regularly greeted with hosannas, they seemed to my eyes to be eternally haloed in their own natural spotlights.

title: How Automated Background Checks Freeze Out Renters
description: This article was reported and written in collaboration with The Markup, a nonprofit newsroom investigating technologys effects on society.

title: Its Not the Virus: Mexicos Broken Hospitals Become Killers, Too
description: The senseless deaths torment doctors and nurses the most: The man who died because an inexperienced nurse unplugged his ventilator. The patient who died from septic shock because no one monitored his vital signs. The people whose breathing tubes clogged after being abandoned in their hospital beds for hours on end.

title: Lights. Camera. Makeup. And a Carefully Placed 1,246-Page Book.
description: It is 46 years old, weighs nearly four pounds in paperback and is about as ill-suited for the internet age as they come: The book is not even available for digital readers.

title: 13 Books to Watch For in June
description: A train attack in Kolkata brings together the fates and fortunes of three characters: Jivan, a young Muslim who is blamed for the attack because of a social media post; PT Sir, a gym teacher who becomes involved with a right-wing political party; and Lovely, a transwoman studying acting. Majumdars debut explores power, justice and vulnerability in contemporary India.

title: Proud of Your Lockdown Baking? This Man Built a Giant Kookaburra
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Some have taken to baking to while away the hours during coronavirus lockdown; others embraced gardening. For Farvardin Daliri, it was the perfect opportunity to complete his magnum opus: a 15-foot-tall replica of a bird known as a laughing kookaburra.

title: Its Too Late: In Sprawling Indonesia, Coronavirus Surges
description: The 1,340 Maluku Islands are a long way from anywhere. So remote are these Indonesian isles that the countrys most famous novelist was imprisoned there in a gulag that was actually an archipelago.

title: Spectral Actors and Viewer Voting: German-Language Theater Adapts
description: MUNICH  As theaters here tentatively start to emerge from the coronavirus lockdown, now seems a good time to take stock of the artistic responses in the German-speaking world after two and a half months of drawn curtains and empty stages.

title: As Hot Spots Shift, Pandemic Enters a New Phase
description: This live briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Space Travel, Privatized
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Will the U.S. Soon Treat Hong Kong Like China? Much Is at Stake
description: Hong Kong risks becoming collateral damage in the growing rivalry between China and the United States.

title: Can You Get the Virus From a Surface?
description: As lockdowns lift, many more Americans are going to come in contact with surfaces that other people have touched: doorknobs, tabletops, shopping bags and more. And I know that many people find these situations confusing.

title: Street Fighting Men Review: Reviving Detroit From Within
description: The death and ostensible resurrection of the great American city of Detroit has been the subject of so many feature pieces of journalism over the last 10 years (at least) that an outsider might be inclined to believe those events are recurring in a sort of temporal loop. The actual experience of living there day in and day out is credibly conveyed in the director Andrew Jamess documentary Street Fighting Men.

title: Into Her Own Review: A Sculptors Monumental Achievements
description: This documentary portrait of the formidable sculptor Ursula von Rydingsvard is, by dint of its brevity, more tantalizing than satiating. But its still a welcome cinematic account of her work.

title: Stage: The Culinary Internship Review: Apprentices With Eclectic Appetites
description: Movies probably lack adequate sensory capacity to capture the cooking at Mugaritz, a celebrated restaurant in Errenteria, Spain, started by the chef Andoni Luis Aduriz. In Stage: The Culinary Internship, the menu is described as a sequence of provocations. Adurizs inventions have included live cannelloni (which looks like it could grow at the base of a tree) and mallow with sake perfume. A protg says he was challenged to concoct a dish that looks like it needs a condom. The movie ends with a server bringing penicillium-rotted apples to a table.

title: Pompeo Hits Out at China
description: The White House steps up pressure on China, Betsy DeVos redistributes the wealth (to the wealthy, her education opponents argue) and the mask wars intensify. Its Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet.

title: Protests Continue to Rage After Death of George Floyd
description: This briefing has ended.

title: Trump and Biden Will Fight the Election With Charts
description: Bad weather scrubbed the historic launch of a crewed SpaceX mission yesterday, so NASA will try again this weekend. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

title: N.Y. City Council Pushes Plan for Outdoor Dining
description: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Fridays live coverage.]

title: What I Learned as a New York Times Fellow
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Still Catching Up: Jobless Numbers May Not Tell Full Story
description: More than 40 million people  the equivalent of one out of every four American workers  have filed for unemployment benefits since the coronavirus pandemic grabbed hold in mid-March, the government reported on Thursday, an astounding tally that rivals the bleakest years of the Great Depression.

title: Dance Companies Take Baby Steps Back to Rehearsal
description: Eight dancers from the Ballet du Rhin were partway through a class at their studio in Mulhouse, eastern France, recently, when the companys artistic director decided to step things up.

title: Meet the Next Chancellor of U.C. Merced
description: Good morning.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: The Most Indoor Space for the Money
description: New Yorkers have been in coronavirus lockdown for more than two months, long enough to develop an intimate relationship with the shortcomings of their homes. Once places to spend mornings, evenings and nights, theyve become offices, gyms, classrooms and day-care centers with hyperactive kitchens. But even the best advice on efficient pantry storage can lead to the realization that more space is needed.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Bay Ridge, Sunnyside and the West Village.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a six-bedroom in Chatham, N.J., and five-bedroom in Northport, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: When Will the Major Sports Leagues Return?
description: The N.B.A., N.F.L. and Major League Baseball are all making plans to return soon. Heres a look at where each sport is in the process.

title: 2 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home
description: How can photography be a tool for self-care? Thats the question posed by the exhibition In Sickness and in Health, which was intended for Paris Photo in New York but moved online after the fair was postponed. The artists Heather Agyepong, Anna Fox and Jo Spence use the medium to process personal and societal histories that affect who they are and how they see themselves.

title: Finding Beauty in a New Routine
description: The day before the governor of California announced a statewide shelter-in-place order, Adrienne Bailon-Houghton, 36, a daytime talk -show host on The Real and a YouTuber, and her husband of almost four years, Israel Houghton, 48, a gospel singer, songwriter and producer, moved to a new house in Calabasas, Calif. They were quarantined without much furniture. Renovation and dcor projects were put on hold with contractors and designers because of the pandemic. And, they were both expected to be on camera for their work, especially Ms. Bailon-Houghton, who films up to three episodes a day for The Real.

title: A Reporters Journey Across a Resuscitating, and Oddly Changed, Europe
description: ROZVADOV BORDER CROSSING  Can you please, said the policeman at the Czech-German border, step out of the car?

title: Taking Lessons From a Bloody Masterpiece
description: Ive become obsessed with Thomas Eakinss The Gross Clinic. Let me show you why.

title: Lesson of the Day: Lionhearted Girl Bikes Dad Across India, Inspiring a Nation
description: Featured Article: Lionhearted Girl Bikes Dad Across India, Inspiring a Nation by Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj

title: George Floyd Protests Escalate in Minneapolis
description: Protests over the death of George Floyd, an African-American man who died in police custody, have intensified in Minneapolis. Some have turned violent, with the police firing tear gas and rubber bullets and people setting buildings on fire.

title: Beijing Hardens Resolve to Defy U.S., Even While Calling for Cooperation
description: BEIJING   Ignoring threats from Washington, China stripped another layer of autonomy from Hong Kong on Thursday, plowing ahead with a plan that would ban any form of dissent deemed subversive in the territory reclaimed from Britain more than two decades ago.

title: Simon & Schuster Names Jonathan Karp C.E.O.
description: Simon & Schuster, one of the countrys major publishing houses, named Jonathan Karp its new chief executive on Thursday, succeeding Carolyn Reidy, who died earlier this month.

title: Do I Have Permission to Corona-Shame My Friend?
description: I saw a post on my friends Instagram that infuriated me: a picture of seven boys in a row, their arms slung over each others shoulders, celebrating the 13th birthday of their friend (her son). Three boys wore face masks; four didnt. We live in a state that recommends social distancing and face masks in public. I am sorry if this gets in the way of traditional birthday parties. My daughter will be extremely disappointed not to celebrate her summer birthday with friends in person. But we know these gatherings are not OK. I find this disrespectful to everyone who follows the rules and to our front-line workers. Should I confront my friend? Am I an idiot to be this furious?

title: Papicha Review: Fashion Statement
description: Fashion and female friendship become tools of resistance in Papicha, Mounia Meddours partly autobiographical feature whose extreme tonal flips  from gaiety to trauma, tenderness to tragedy  only make it all the more touching.

title: Leslie Odom Jr. Raises a Glass to Billie Holiday and New York City
description: Leslie Odom Jr. met Josh Gad when they were drama students at Carnegie Mellon. And when Gad calls, usually about some weirdly wonderful little project, Odom tends to pick up the phone. I always know that its going to be a delightful experience, Odom said, because its no secret: Josh is a delightful dude.

title: The High Note Review: A Little Pitchy
description: Like a potted fern held aloft by a forest of well-positioned stakes, Dakota Johnson claims the center of The High Note on the strength and general excellence of the actors around her. Every one of them is a blessing, even those (condolences, Ice Cube) enduring trite roles and formulaic setups in a movie that cant decide if its a musical reworking of The Devil Wears Prada, an underdog romantic comedy or a feminist arrow to the heart of the entertainment industry.

title: Circumstantial Pleasures Review: The Lyrical Junkman Cometh
description: An air of menace suffuses Circumstantial Pleasures, the latest from the cinematic collagist Lewis Klahr. An archivist par excellence and excavator of the collective unconscious, Klahr creates striking, deeply personal assemblages using found images and objects, with jolts of sound and music. His materials vary but are inevitably frayed around the edges, bringing to mind the odds and ends gleaned from flea markets and junk drawers: old ticket stubs, bottle caps, blister packs, medical illustrations and comic books. With alchemical invention, he takes this cultural detritus to make work that hovers  tentatively, teasingly  on the very precipice of narrative.

title: House Pulls Surveillance Measure After Trump Tells Republicans to Vote No
description: House Democratic leaders on Thursday withdrew legislation that would revive expired F.B.I. tools to investigate terrorism and espionage and add privacy protections for Americans subjected to wiretapping for national security purposes, after a fragile bipartisan compromise collapsed following an abrupt repudiation by President Trump.

title: Nikil Saval, the N+1 Candidate
description: Nikil Saval is a socialist candidate running for State Senate in Pennsylvanias 1st district, which encompasses a huge swath of Philadelphia. He used to edit the literary and political magazine N+1, which is to say that he is more bookish than your standard elected-office-seeker. This occasionally gets in his way.

title: Soldier Stopped Shooting by Driving Into Gunman, Kansas Police Say
description: Master Sgt. David Royer was leaving Fort Leavenworth in Kansas on Wednesday, driving home in his Chevrolet Silverado and talking to his fiance via Bluetooth, when he hit some traffic on the Centennial Bridge, which connects Kansas and Missouri.

title: Coronavirus Continues to Disrupt Prescription Drug Supplies
description: For Michelle Weaver, hydroxychloroquine has been a miracle drug.

title: French Take Their Apros to the Streets, Testing Lockdown Limits
description: PARIS  Annoyed at their government, the French have taken to the streets brandishing drinks.

title: Legal Shield for Social Media Is Targeted by Lawmakers
description: This article was originally published in 2019 and has been updated.

title: Eduardo L. Gancayco, Who Kept Hospital Workers Fed, Dies at 62
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: A.C.L.U. Accuses Clearview AI of Privacy Nightmare Scenario
description: The American Civil Liberties Union on Thursday sued the facial recognition start-up Clearview AI, which claims to have helped hundreds of law enforcement agencies use online photos to solve crimes, accusing the company of unlawful, privacy-destroying surveillance activities.

title: Review: Central Park Is the Show We Need Right Now
description: New York City needs its parks in any summer, but never more than now. Shared spaces of play, sun, respite and peace (and yes, conflict and judgment) are reminders in a time of distancing that we are all in this together.

title: English Premier League Plans to Resume June 17
description: LONDON  The English Premier League, the most-watched sports league in the world, plans to resume play on June 17 after a two-month hiatus caused by the coronavirus pandemic, league officials announced on Thursday.

title: 6 Things to Do at Home This Weekend
description: Antoinette Nwandus play Pass Over had already closed in the summer of 2017 when Spike Lee called to propose filming it: rebuilding the set at Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, where Danya Taymor had just directed its world premiere, and reassembling the cast.

title: William J. Small, Key Official During CBS Newss Heyday, Dies at 93
description: William J. Small, who built the Washington bureau of CBS News into a journalistic powerhouse and protected his correspondents from the grievances of President Richard M. Nixon and other government officials, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: North Koreans Accused of Laundering $2.5 Billion for Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  North Korean and Chinese citizens are operating a multibillion-dollar money laundering scheme to help fund the Norths nuclear weapons program, the Justice Department said in an indictment unsealed on Thursday. The case underscores the Trump administrations inability to halt Pyongyangs nuclear weapons program through diplomacy.

title: Hungary Outlaws Changing Gender on Documents After Birth
description: BUDAPEST  Hungarys far-right government under Prime Minister Viktor Orban has for a decade demonized his long list of perceived enemies, including Muslim migrants, George Soros, Brussels, civil society, homeless people, foreign universities, Roma families and an independent press.

title: The National Anthems Path to Fame Began With Little Fanfare
description: One of the most important articles ever published by a 19th-century newspaper called The Baltimore Patriot & Evening Advertiser didnt even make the front page. It appeared on Page 2.

title: Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling Tweets
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Twitter continued to add new fact-checking labels to hundreds of tweets, even as the Trump administration issued an executive order to curtail the legal protections that shield social media companies from liability for the content posted on their platforms.

title: 1985: When Rambo Tightened His Grip on the American Psyche
description: Thirty-five Memorial Days ago, Sylvester Stallone was atop the box office pile, in Rambo: First Blood Part II, smooth, rippling and outrageously oily. The movie opened alongside a flaccid 14th Bond film (A View to a Kill) and a confusing Richard Pryor comedy (Brewsters Millions); it crushed both. This was a great Top 10 week. You had the countrys two most important comedians, Pryor and Eddie Murphy, at the back half and the beginning of their careers, movies with Cher, Madonna and Grace Jones; and Harrison Ford aligning his stardom with excellent, nonfranchise filmmaking.

title: Falling Into the Gap Year
description: It was only November when Hannah Book, 18, a high school student in Bryn Mawr, Pa., was accepted to her first choice, Emory College in Atlanta. I got accepted early decision, she said. I was really excited, and my mom and I jumped up and down. I felt like all my hard work had paid off in that moment.

title: A G.O.P. Lawmaker Had the Virus. Nobody Told Democrats Exposed to Him.
description: Democrats in Pennsylvanias House of Representatives on Thursday accused Republicans of keeping a lawmakers positive coronavirus test a secret to avoid political embarrassment, even at the risk of exposing their Democratic colleagues.

title: Management of Bailout Money Poses Political Test for Trump
description: WASHINGTON  When restaurant industry executives gathered at the White House this month, Tilman J. Fertitta pleaded with President Trump to let his chains of high-end eateries gain access to a government loan program meant for small businesses.

title: I Will Make You Mine Review: Three Times a Lady
description: For her first stab at writing and directing, the actor Lynn Chen imagines resolutions for characters originally introduced in Dave Boyles 2011-2012 movies, Surrogate Valentine and Daylight Savings. The result is I Will Make You Mine, described in the press notes as a semi-sequel to Boyles films and  at least in look, tone and temperature  not dissimilar to its predecessors.

title: The Vast of Night Review: Theres More to Fear Than Fear Itself
description: Something weird this way comes  and keeps on coming  in The Vast of Night. Its sometime in the 1950s in Cayuga, a fictional New Mexico town filled with deepening shadows, cruising cars and roaming teenagers. Everyone is heading toward the high school, where girls in saddle shoes will soon cheer boys dribbling across the court. Its evening again in America, and things are about to get murky and eerie and strange.

title: The TV Commercial, Once Advertisings Main Event, Suffers in the Pandemic
description: Before the coronavirus pandemic, the TV networks were expecting a strong 2020. The presidential election and Tokyo Olympics would keep people watching, and companies would spend more than usual on commercial time.

title: Amy Cooper and Christian Cooper: A Confrontation in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Should Bear the Financial Brunt of the Coronavirus in Baseball?
description: Kevin Cash wore a mask for eight years as a major league catcher. He never needed one as a manager until this week, when his Tampa Bay Rays began voluntary workouts at Tropicana Field.

title: Viewing Party! Lets All Watch Some Like It Hot!
description: Im tired of getting the fuzzy end of the lollipop, says Sugar Kane Kowalczyk, the ukulele player with a soft spot for saxophonists. A lot of us know how she feels. Everyone could use a little candy right now, and we cant think of a sweeter way to spend time than with Sugar and her pals Jo and Daphne watching Some Like It Hot.

title: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: In Silicon Valley, the natural order of time is reverse chronological: what matters most is what is newest, and can be constantly refreshed by swiping downward. Why, because the presents so great? Two decades into a profoundly unpromising century  and amid a pandemic whose social and epidemiological fallout strongly echoes plagues from centuries past  I take ever more comfort in the art of earlier times. These days, Ive been cleansing my Instagram timeline with Flemish painting, Mexican antiquities, Korean ceramics, and all sorts of beauty that has withstood the toughest critic of all. Even on my own account (@jasonfarago) I have a soft rule: no art after 1945.

title: Practicing Architecture in a Pandemic
description: The architect Elizabeth Diller typically works with pen on paper, bringing sketches to her West 26th Street studio, where she and her team at Diller Scofidio + Renfro puzzle over how best to realize those plans.

title: Tell Us Your Questions About Moving During the Pandemic
description: In normal times, the weeks when spring turns to summer are prime time for people looking for new homes and apartments. And while the coronavirus pandemic is not stopping leases from ending, it is prompting many to reconsider their housing situation.

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Maybe the pandemic is making us more stir-crazy than we realized. Nearly all of this weeks recommended titles take us far outside ourselves, to plunge readers into other lands, other lives, other eras altogether  from a consideration of the Arab Spring to a biography of the influential economist John Maynard Keynes to histories of immigration policy in America and anti-submarine warfare in England.

title: Playing by the Rules: Dutch Leader Offers a Sober Contrast in a Brash Era
description: AMSTERDAM  He likes to ride his bicycle to the office. If time is an issue, he opts for the aging Saab parked in front of his modest apartment in The Hague.

title: Facebook and Its Secret Policies
description: The Wall Street Journal reported this week that Facebook had studied for two years whether its social network makes people more polarized.

title: Genius or Amoral? Artists Latest Angers Indigenous Canadians
description: TORONTO  Many Indigenous activists in Canada consider Justin Trudeau, after more than four years as prime minister, as little better than the other white colonial leaders who have oppressed them for the past 150 years.

title: How Quiz, a Drama About Coughing, Captivated Lockdown Britain
description: LONDON  This Easter, James Graham, the playwright and screenwriter, was worried. His latest show, Quiz, was about to be broadcast in Britain, but the country had only recently gone into lockdown. He was concerned people might not want to watch a three-part drama on network TV, perhaps preferring to binge a Netflix series or do Zoom calls.

title: Looking for an Introduction to Taiwans Greatest Filmmaker? Start Here
description: Through the 1980s and 90s, American fans of the Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-Hsien regarded his movies as, essentially, too brilliant to be released: Although his films showed at festivals and occasional screenings in major cities, distribution companies in the United States largely shied away, even when his titles turned up on best-of-the-decade lists. Maybe Hou was simply too challenging, too singular and too uncommercial for any distributor here to touch, cinephiles scoffed. The longtime advocate J. Hoberman chalked it up less to difficulty than to regional bias: He speculated that if Hou were French, his films would draw crowds.

title: Trumps Order on Social Media Could Harm One Person in Particular: Donald Trump
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, who built his political career on the power of a flame-throwing Twitter account, has now gone to war with Twitter, angered that it would presume to fact-check his messages. But the punishment he is threatening could force social media companies to crack down even more on customers just like Mr. Trump.

title: Ramy and the New American Muslims of TV
description: Hes a rudderless, sexually frustrated millennial. Hes also deeply religious. Hes Ramy, the Egyptian-American at the center of the comedian Ramy Youssefs semi-autobiographical series, Ramy, returning Friday for a second season on Hulu.

title: Boston Marathon Canceled for the First Time
description: The Boston Marathon was canceled for the first time in its 124-year history, officials announced on Thursday, as the spread of the coronavirus made clear that earlier plans to postpone the race until September were too optimistic.

title: Keep Politics Out of Reopening Houses of Worship
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats It Like to Have the Same Job as Your Mother or Father?
description: People go into a parents line of work for different reasons. They might join a family business. They might have been inspired seeing their parents work close up. They might be drawn into a job by their mothers or fathers professional network. It might simply be the only option available to them.

title: I Graduated Alone. In My Pajamas. On My Moms Couch.
description: Less than three months ago, I started having this uneasy feeling in the pit of my stomach. It started in early March when Harvard announced that it would finish the rest of its semester online. A few other schools quickly followed suit. At my school, Vassar College, the administration emailed us to say that we would be going online for a few weeks and returning to in-person classes in April.

title: What Should You Say When Someone You Know Is Grieving?
description: Over 100,000 Americans have died from the coronavirus, and thanks to social media, many of us who arent personally in mourning are digitally connected to someone who is. Especially for people in the hardest-hit areas, death announcements in Facebook statuses, Instagram posts and tweets seem more frequent than theyve ever been.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: China officially has the broad power to quash unrest in Hong Kong, after the countrys legislature nearly unanimously approved a plan to suppress any acts in the semiautonomous city that might threaten national security.

title: Bank Regulators Battle With Anti-Redlining Law Comes to an End
description: Joseph Otting came into his job overseeing the nations biggest banks in late 2017 determined to rewrite the rules governing how financial institutions invest in poor communities.

title: Stung by Discord Over Officiating, the N.F.L. Puts a Coach in Charge
description: Perry Fewell improved those around him in many of the stops he has made during his 35-year coaching career. Repeating the feat in his new job may be far more difficult. On Thursday, the N.F.L. announced that Fewell had become its senior vice president of officiating administration, a newly created position that will involve overseeing an often-criticized department with increasingly complex duties.

title: Germany Wants E.U. to Sanction Head of Russian Military Intelligence
description: BERLIN  Germany wants to impose a European travel ban and asset freeze on the head of Russias military intelligence agency and several of its spies in response to a 2015 cyberattack on the German Parliament that was traced back to Moscow earlier this month.

title: What Students Are Saying About Quarantine Dating, Ghosts and Songs of Hope
description: Please note: This is the last installment of Current Events Conversation for the 2019-2020 school year. This feature will resume in mid-September.

title: House Overwhelmingly Approves Revisions to Small-Business Program
description: WASHINGTON  The House overwhelmingly approved legislation on Thursday that would relax the terms of a federal loan program intended to help small businesses weather the pandemic, giving companies more time and flexibility to use the money.

title: In Africa, a Drive to End Malnutrition Meets Covid-19
description: When I began reporting this article, before the pandemic, it was about an ingenious solution to a huge but hard-to-see problem: In many poor countries, most people get their grain from mom-and-pop local mills. But these mills dont fortify their flour with the basic nutrients that children (and others) need.

title: Carvel H. Moore, Who Found a Career in Bettering a City, Dies at 90
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Margaret Maughan, Medal-Winning Wheelchair Athlete, Dies at 91
description: Her back was ramrod straight, her arms steady and her aim true. When Margaret Maughan pulled back the string on her bow  from her seat in a wheelchair  she shot her way into Paralympic history.

title: Rediscovering Wine After Covid-19
description: This is a story about what happens when one of lifes joys is taken away, perhaps forever. In this case its wine, but it could as easily have been painting, cooking, dancing, or playing golf or tennis.

title: Roman Villas Mosaics Are Unearthed, Again, a Century After Last Dig
description: ROME  Italian archaeologists have again unearthed the well-preserved, colorfully patterned mosaic floors of an ancient Roman villa in a vineyard that was last excavated nearly a century ago and then lost to public memory.

title: For One Theater, a Marvelous Way to Perform in Lockdown
description: The Seacoast Repertory Theater revival of The Marvelous Wonderettes that opened on May 16 looked like fully produced live theater, because it was. The costumed cast of four was acting and singing up a storm in real time and on real sets, backed by an actual four-piece band. The retro, pastel-colored jukebox musical popped. But there was no audience in the house  the ticket-holders, kept home in the age of Covid-19, were all streaming.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: When a Close Friend Has Doubts About Vaccinations
description: I was at a barbecue with a few of my closest friends last summer when the topic of vaccines came up. In the kitchen, while grabbing plates and silverware for the table, I flippantly muttered something like, Anti-vaxxers are the worst. I assumed we all shared the same stance. I think I might be one, my friend replied.

title: F.B.I. Once Investigated Trump Campaign Advisers Ties to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. and the special counsels office investigated whether a former Trump campaign adviser secretly worked for the Egyptian government to influence the incoming administration in the months before President Trump took office, according to several people familiar with the inquiry.

title: C.D.C. Recommends Sweeping Changes to American Offices
description: Upon arriving at work, employees should get a temperature and symptom check.

title: Trump Signs Executive Order on Social Media, Claiming to Protect Free Speech
description: Denouncing what he said was the power of social media to shape the interpretation of public events, President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday directing federal regulators to crack down on companies like Twitter and to consider taking away the legal protections that shield them from liability for what gets posted on their platforms.

title: Richard Herd, a Baffled Boss on Seinfeld, Is Dead at 87
description: Richard Herd, who played lawmen, tough guys, a general, an alien commander and a Watergate burglar, but was best known as Mr. Wilhelm, George Costanzas supervisor, on Seinfeld, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: California Regulators Back PG&E Bankruptcy Plan
description: California regulators on Thursday approved a plan that would allow the states biggest utility, Pacific Gas & Electric, to emerge from the bankruptcy case it filed last year, clearing the last major hurdle the company faced.

title: On the Economics of Not Dying
description: America is now engaged in a vast, dangerous experiment. Although social distancing has limited the spread of the coronavirus, it is far from contained. Yet despite warnings from epidemiologists, much of the country is moving to open up for business as usual.

title: If We Had a Real Leader
description: This week I had a conversation that left a mark. It was with Mary Louise Kelly and E.J. Dionne on NPRs All Things Considered, and it was about how past presidents had handled moments of national mourning  Lincoln after Gettysburg, Reagan after the Challenger explosion and Obama after the Sandy Hook school shootings.

title: Albert Krieger, a Bulldog of the Criminal Defense Bar, Dies at 96
description: Albert J. Krieger, a defense lawyer who combined a prodigious memory, surgical interrogations and a courtly baritone to foil hostile witnesses against his often notorious clients, including the mobsters John Gotti and Joseph Bonanno and Miamis so-called cocaine cowboys, died on May 14 in Miami. He was 96.

title: U.S. Accuses Russian Military Hackers of Attack on Email Servers
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency publicly accused Russian government hackers of targeting email servers around the world in an unusual announcement on Thursday, showing that the agency is becoming more aggressive in calling out Moscows action as the presidential election approaches.

title: Does a Crisis Spur Political Unity? Not This Pandemic
description: It was not so long ago that the conventional wisdom in Washington was that a genuine crisis like the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks had the power to cool partisan hostilities, pulling elected officials together to present a united front to a stricken nation. In a pandemic that has now claimed more than 100,000 lives, that is not proving to be the case.

title: Millions Relying on Pandemic Aid Can See Its End, and Theyre Scared
description: For millions of Americans left out of work by the coronavirus pandemic, government assistance has been a lifeline preventing a plunge into poverty, hunger and financial ruin.

title: Trump Officials Consider Defying Congress to Sell More Weapons to Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is moving to sell another cache of munitions to Saudi Arabia, according to lawmakers and congressional aides, a step that would again defy Congress and ignore the objections of lawmakers in both parties about Riyadhs human rights record.

title: Why Is Police Brutality Still Happening?
